Ottawa, October 27, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from J. P. Kirkpatrick, of the Canadian National Railway, Sioux Lookout, requesting payment for damage to a suit of clothes at the time of the fire at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

In this connection I regret that the Department will be unable to pay for the damage occasioned. However, the Department desires to thank Mr. Kirkpatrick and the Canadian National Railway for assistance rendered at the time of the fire.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

October 28th, 1936

Dear Sir:

Replying to your night lettergram of 27th inst.

We will do what we can with the $2500.00 authorized for repairs at the Sioux Lookout Residential School.

We note you have no funds to erect a new engine room supply a Diesel engine, or install water tank in the old engine room.

Enclosed please find a letter we have received from the Reverend Principal in Winnipeg General Hospital, showing he is getting better.

I will visit him when I go there, which will be probably tomorrow or next day, and will try and rush things as I knew the inconvenience and trouble they are having.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Winnipeg General Hospital,
Winnipeg, Manitoba,
October 27th, 1936.

Capt. Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
KENORA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have some letters that haven't been replied to. They are on my desk in the school.

No doubt the Department will be wondering why I haven't replied to some of theirs as well, and most of them I have hunted up the various information required and will be able to attend to these letters as soon as I return back from the hospital to the school. Would you kindly let the Department know the cause of the delay.

I expect to be returning home next month. There are also estimates asked for about this time of the year, but I have been unable to look into this as well, and as you know Miss Taylor left our service about four months ago, and the present girl that I have would only bawl things up.

If you should be in Winnipeg in the near future, I am still occupying the same bed in ward 108.

Thanking you for your kind consideration of this matter, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

J. Marshall
Principal
Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter 129-6-5 of 27th inst. re repairs at the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout.

I was in Winnipeg yesterday and went into the matter very closely with Messrs Munford Midland Ltd., Dr. Westgate and Colonel Marmegan, of the Indian School Committee.

The following are absolutely necessary repairs and replacements to put the school in running condition:

- Fire Hose, $81.15
- Tools etc., $500.00
- Iron Uptakes $18.00
- Refills for Extinguishers $18.64
- Lighting Plant & freight $990.00
- Engine for Pump $200.00
- Battery repairs $25.00
- Piston leathers and valves $14.84
- Saw & Belt $150.00
- Munford Midland account for inspection report, loan of engine etc. $210.00
- Labour installing lighting plant $75.00
- Renovating wiring $300.00
- Cement Mixer $175.00
- Repairs to building $1029.00

There will also be a certain amount of freight and other minor expenses.

After discussing the matter with the above gentlemen Mr. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian School Committee, sent you a night lettergram saying that as you could not authorize an expenditure of more than $2500.00, the school committee would advance a further $1500.00 so as to make possible the carrying on of the school without closing.

Even if this is agreed to, the school would still be run at a great handicap owing to the trouble with the water tower.

Please note that in our latter of Sept. 29th we estimated the amount of damage done outside the engine room and engine etc., $2000.00. This of course did not include lighting plant etc.
The Fire Hose, Refills for Extinguishers and certain other articles have already been supplied under authority of your previous letters.

I saw the Reverend Principal at the General Hospital, and he is a very sick man, and I do not think he will be of much use around the school for a considerable time.

He informs me that the work in course of completion of the Barn, Meet House and Silo should be left till his return to the school.

Some of the material has been ordered and the work is underway.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
November 3rd, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Replying to Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 28th ultimo, requesting to be informed if it would be possible for the Department to purchase the electrical energy required for power purposes at the Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, rather than generate it at the school, I would say that, in the town of Sioux Lookout, there is only a local steam plant, operated by the Canadian Pacific Railway, and that no power would be available for distribution to the school. The Sioux Lookout School is located on Pelican Lake, a distance of approximately 7 to 8 miles from the town.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, November 4, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, in further reference to the cost of the work required in repairing the damage occasioned by fire in the engine room at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. It is noted that, after consultation with Messrs. Mumford Medland, Limited, and the authorities of the Missionary Society of the Anglican Church in Winnipeg, it is found the total cost of carrying out the repairs to the building, repairing the electric light plant and supplying the new equipment required will be approximately $4,000.

The Department understood, from previous correspondence, that an expenditure of approximately $2,500.00 would carry out the repairs occasioned to the building and equipment.

While the cost of completing the repairs occasioned by the fire is an unforeseen expenditure - no funds being specially provided - it will, however, be necessary to place the building and equipment in a satisfactory condition to carry on the school work. The Department will, therefore endeavour to provide the full amount required in purchasing the equipment, as mentioned in your letter, and in carrying out the repairs to the building and plant, to an amount which must be kept within $4,000.00. We are not prepared

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Indian Affairs, (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 3)
to consider the offer made by the church authorities, to advance the sum of $1,500, on the understanding that repayment would be made during the next fiscal year.

The Department will leave the matter of carrying out the repairs and supplying the equipment in your hands. All purchases should be made from firms on the approved list and the work should be completed at as early a date as possible in order to have the building and plant placed in a good state of repair.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of all materials purchased. Full particulars should be given regarding any outside labour employed, viz.: number of days or hours employed and rates paid. I would request that you forward all accounts covering the cost at the one time and as soon after the work is completed as possible.

It is noted the Principal desires that the work which is now under way, in connection with the barn, root-house and silo, be deferred until he is able to return to the school and resume his duties. This matter should be referred to the Department before any further work is performed. Full details should be given, regarding the cost of the work to be done. It is noted that some of the material has been ordered and part of the work underway.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Ottawa, November 4, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I beg to refer to your telegram of the 28th ultimo and the 4th instant, regarding the repairs occasioned by fire to the building and equipment at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and offering, on behalf of your Society, to advance the sum of $1,500 towards the cost of the repairs.

After considerable correspondence with Mr. Agent Edwards, Kenora, it has been found possible to defer certain work at other schools and apply the funds towards the carrying out of the work at the Sioux Lookout School.

While thanking your Society for the offer of contributing $1,500 towards the expenses, on the understanding that repayment would be made after next April, the Department, after giving the matter consideration, found that it would be unable to accept; and, as stated above, has made other arrangements to provide the funds required. Mr. Agent Edwards has been written and given instructions to proceed with the repairs.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. T. B. R. Westgate, D.D.,
Field Secretary, M. S. C. C.,
39-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Avenue,
Winnipeg, Man.
Dear Mr McGill,

I am in receipt of the Secretary's letter #129-6-5 of 4th instant authorizing an expenditure of $4000 for repairs to Sioux Lockout School.

Mr H. McKinnon, M.P., phoned me up yesterday and informed me he had received a telegram from the Minister re purchases of materials and labour on this work. He wanted to know if we were having the work done by Kenora firms, and I informed him that we were getting prices, and that we had had a report from Mumford and Medland's man in Winnipeg, who estimated what we would require, and also that as this firm had installed the engines, and the school authorities desired Mumford-Medland to do the necessary work of putting things in shape again, we would probably give them the work providing their prices were right, as authorized by Ottawa, and that the work of repairing the buildings would go to the Contractor in Sioux Lockout who was so we were informed the only firm there for this building work.

Mr McKinnon seemed very annoyed that work should be awarded to Winnipeg firms, although any firms in Kenora who might wish to tender would have to get nearly all their supplies &c from Winnipeg.

Mr McKinnon gave me the names of firms in Kenora he wished me to contact and get prices from, and I am obeying his instructions, but I do not think they will be in a position to do the work as satisfactorily or as cheaply as Mumford Medland. However I am awaiting their tenders and will give the work to the cheapest firm providing they can give me assurance the work will be satisfactory and everything put into good working order.

Mr McKinnon asked me if I had a preferred list for Kenora, I informed him we had not, but on any special jobs I received instructions where to obtain prices &c, he said I should have this and he would see I received it immediately; he rather blamed the Department for not having sent this before but I informed him we had never received any complaints from anyone as to where we purchased materials or with whom we dealt as we used good judgment.
It is very unfortunate, this will delay starting the work, particularly as the weather is so cold and the lakes are freezing up, and the pipes at the school are exposed to the weather, but I consider it is the only thing to do under the circumstances, and as soon as we are in position to go ahead with the work we will do so.

Please let me know immediately if these arrangements meet with your approval.

Yours faithfully,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent.
EXD.

Ottawa, November 10, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, regarding the repairs which you were authorized to have carried out at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. It is noted that the local member furnished you with names of firms in Kenora from whom to obtain prices and that you have asked these firms to quote. This is satisfactory. You should arrange to give the work to the firm quoting the lowest price. The Department understands this applies only to the work in connection with the equipment and repairs required to the electric light system and water supply and not to the carpentry work required in repairing the engine room and other damage caused by fire to the building. You should cooperate, as far as possible, with the local member mentioned in your letter, with a view to having the work satisfactorily carried out and at the lowest possible expense.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora,
Ont.

9th November, 1936.

H. B. McKinnon, Esq., M.P.,
Kenora / Rainy River,
Parliament Buildings,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 6th inst re repairs and replacements to buildings and equipment at Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

From your letter it appears you are under a misapprehension.

No arrangements had definitely been decided upon as to who was to do this work, all that had been done was to get an estimate from the firm in Winnipeg who had supplied and installed the engines in the buildings as to what damage had been done and an estimate as to the cost of repairs and materials necessary to make good the damage done to the machinery. The reason this firm was asked to make the estimate was that they have supplied the plant previously in the school and the Church and School authorities asked me to get their advice, and this firm was on the preferred list.

I asked the School authorities to get me a price for repairs to the buildings and they got Mr. Wright Contractor of Sioux Lookout, who they informed me was the only available Contractor.

No purchases would have been made until we got prices from different firms who would have been eligible to tender, and until we had been to the school again to see if we were employing the right people and that their prices were right.

I have seen all the firms you mentioned and am getting prices from them, but there is no doubt that the firm who is the lowest price will have to get the Winnipeg firm to supply a lot of the materials and also to send his own men down to do some of the work.

We purchase everything we can in Kenora, except where there is a big difference in prices, and I think this is the proper thing to do.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

Kenora, Ont.
9th November, 1936

Dr H. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Dr McGill,

Reference my letter of the 6th instant, I enclose copy of a letter to H.B. McKinnon, M.P., in reply to one of his, as Mr Meikle, my clerk, informed me Mr McKinnon was in on Saturday whilst I was out of Town and that he was very annoyed and seemed to think the work had already been awarded to some Winnipeg firm, which was not the case.

I saw Mr Mumford, on Saturday, he and other firms had not been asked to tender, the only thing we had got, was an estimate from Mumford and Medland as to what it would cost to make good the damage done by the fire, and this firm sent a man down to make an estimate for which they were charging us, and also for the rent of engines temporarily to give light and water, whilst we were awaiting the decision of headquarters.

Mr Mumford informed me Mr Fife (one of the firms from Kenora) who I was asked to get a price from, had been in to see him, and informed him a Kenora firm had to get the work, and asked Mr Medland if he would do the work for Fife. Should he be awarded the work, Mr Medland agreed to do this, although both his firm and Fife's had been asked to put in a price.

If Fife does this, he will, no doubt, put in a lower price, and will probably get the work, but he will only be able to do this, by getting the engines &c Medland can supply, as they happen to have suitable ones on hand, and they are working on an electric light contract they have at Hudson, 7 miles from the School.

I am writing this letter for your information, as Mr Meikle informs me Mr McKinnon has to go to Toronto, and that he was going to Ottawa after to see you, and I think you should have all the information on hand.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent

November, 17th. 1936

Dear Sir:

Re fire at Sioux Lookout Residential School and reference previous correspondence, I went to the school on Thursday last and met Colonel Fife of the Fife Hardware Co. and H. Cheyne of the Cheyne Electric, there, both of Kenora, who inspected the school and then made a tender on the work to be done.

On discussing the matter with the Acting Principal, the Contractors and later with Dr. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian Residential School Commission, it was decided, if possible to only do temporarily carpenter work and save wherever possible to a later date, so as to enable us to put in a water tank, as the tower in present use is almost useless.

Mumford Medland Co. made a tender of $2844.39, Fife Hardware of $2755.23 and the Cheyne Electric of $3080.20, for the material and labour including a 2000 gal. tank so as to put the water and lights in good serviceable condition.

In addition to the above we have accounts of $100.63 for C.N.R. work on fire. $750.98 Mumford Medland, expert, wages and accounts for other material supplied by them and other firms.

In connection with the rebuilding so as to enable the school to get a tank, the school and church authorities agreed to limit the amount of repairs, which will cost $300.00.

This work will be given to Mr. Edmonds of Sioux Lookout who is the lowest tenderer.

As the names of Fife Hardware Co. and Mr. F. Edmonds were given to us by Mr. H. B. McKinnon Kenora and their tenders were lowest we wired you last night asking if we could award the contracts to them.
If your reply is favourable, work will be started immediately on contract basis.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Dear Sir:

We have received your telegram of 17th inst. re repairs at the Sioux Lookout Residential School, and have today notified the A.T.Fife Co and F. Edmonds to proceed with the work.

We inclose a copy of a letter to the Principal in the hospital at Winnipeg and have also sent a copy to the acting Principal.

Referring to your letter 129-6-5 of 4th inst., last paragraph, the acting Principal informs us the work in connection with the Barn, Root House and Silo is being left over as instructed except that the barn floor is being completed.

The cement cost $262.50 and the labour and other material for work already done or in course of completion will cost about $300.00, and in this way there will be a saving on the amount authorized in your letter to the Principal which was approximately $840.00.

The Acting Principal also informs us that they can do without the Hay Mower, Hay Rake, and Ensilage Cutter, for the present.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario,
Reverend J. F. J. Marshall,
West 1-108 General Hospital
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Marshall:

We hope you are getting better and did not wish to bother you with the school fire when you were so sick, however everything is getting straightened out.

The Fife Hardware Co. of Kenora have the contract to put the equipment in condition, and P. Admonds, of Sioux Lookout for the carpentry work.

We intend placing a 2000 gal. water tank in the school and this will do away with the troubles with the water tower.

The Contractor will be starting work immediately, so you have no need to worry in this connection. We understand they were short of wood at the school but no doubt this will be attended to. We believe that the floor in the barn is new in but Mr. Mayo wants some wood blocks for this.

He informs us that the interior painting is practically finished including the Chapel, Dormitories, Staff Sitting Room etc. He will require about $150.00 for labour and $150.00 for material for the work already done or in course of completion.

The work that is not done in the barn ceiling, Ray loft floor and joists and silo pit, these we think will have to be left over till you return, as the Department does not wish to go to any further expense, owing to the cost of the fire.

I saw the Bishop yesterday and believe he is taking up the matter of new pupils with Canon Sanderson. If there is any way we can help, let us know.
I expect to be in Winnipeg 4th or 5th December, and will drop in and see you then.

Kind regards and wishing you a speedy recovery

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, November 23, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the tenders you received for the carrying out of the repairs occasioned by the fire at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. It is noted that the Fife Hardware submitted the lowest tender for material and labour in placing the water and light service in a good, serviceable condition and that the carpentry work will be given to Mr. Edmonds, Sioux Lookout, who was the lowest tenderer.

You were authorized, by telegram, on the 17th instant, to accept the lowest tenders. It is noted that the entire cost of the work, as per the lowest tenders received, and also to pay the accounts of the C. N. R. and Mumford-Medland, will be approximately $5,900. You should see that the work in connection with the repairs is started immediately and completed at an early date. After the work has been completed to the satisfaction of yourself and the school authorities, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, in payment for the work. These accounts should be fully itemized and the tenders received should be attached to the accounts.

You should also forward, properly certified, the account of the C. N. R., for work at the time of the fire and the account of Mumford-Medland for material and work supplied by them.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

On my inspection trip to the Sioux Lookout Residential School last Monday the Acting Principal informed me that the A.T.Fife Co. had completed the work to the school's satisfaction, but they are not satisfied with the fire protection and have asked that they be authorized an amount for the erecting of an engine house and to install a pump at the lake. They estimate $250.00 for this work, the school authorities to do the necessary labour.

They also say that the water pipe from the lake to the school broke some years ago and was temporarily repaired, the pipe passes over a ledge of rock and owing to the heaving of the ground with the frost, this pipe has broken or cracked and is leaking air, causing a lot of trouble. They would like to have authority to dig this pipe up and replace it with a copper one, or blast away the rock ledge.

It is hard to estimate this cost but presume it would be $50.00 to $100.00.

The Fire Escapes are all at the back of the building and close to the engine house, the most dangerous place and they would like to have two escapes erected at the front of the building or one at each side.

Some of the telephone poles require renewing and they would like authority to do this.

We would suggest the school authorities be instructed to do this themselves.

The Principal would also like an amount set aside next Spring for Painting outside, and general repairs,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I am sending you a list of requirements that are very necessary for our School this summer:

First: The water line as I explained to you back in the winter has a leakage somewhere and we will have to dig it up to ascertain where the leakage is, that will involve a considerable amount of labour.

We had somewhat similar trouble about six years ago and found the breakage to be in one of the joints, caused through a pipe that was lying on a rock. Instead of the rock being blasted out when the line was put in, the pipe was bent over the rock which left it bearing hard on the rock. Although this is a way below the frost line I have been told by two different engineers that a pipe bearing hard on rock like that is very apt to break. Any way, there is a leakage and we are not able to get our water without priming the pipe every time we pump and sometimes that fails. We have been carrying on during the winter as best we could as it would have been double the work digging through frost.

I would like the Department to give us a little help with the expense of this.

I am also asking for engine and jump and connections that we could place over the top of the well and connect up to the present water line. It would give us an unlimited supply of water in case of fire as our tank, engine and pump are enclosed in the main building and if a fire occurred in the building like happened last fall we would have no provision at all to fight the fire.

Of course the pump and engine would have to have a little house to enclose it over the well but would be always ready for emergencies.
Captain Edwards.

If the Department could allow us Five Hundred Dollars it would cover the expense of this as we should do most of the work ourselves.

I hope you will see the necessity of giving us some further fire protection to what we have.

Secondly: The fire escapes and roof on boiler room, hall and the kitchen. I pointed out to you in the winter the necessity of getting these roofs repaired. The water is coming through and destroying the lath and plaster, also the ceiling in places.

We have ten feet lying here to repair and fix these places. I have not attempted to do anything with that at present as the wet would destroy it.

Removing the fire escapes round to the front of the building, which was suggested by Dr. Westgate, who has written the Department on this matter. I had a man out here to give me a price on the cost of this and I feel sure that Two Hundred Dollars would cover these items.

Thirdly: The uptakes and pipes leading from boilers to the chimney will have to be renewed before next winter as they are burnt through in several places. The cost of these pipes will be Ninety Dollars.

I would also like to get sufficient galvanized sheets to line the engine room and cover the boiler room ceiling. It was a metallic ceiling that saved the building from total destruction last fall.

As the funds were cut down to the minimum when repairs were done last fall, the lining of the engine room with metal was not able to be considered.

Seventy-five Dollars would cover the cost of metal for that. We would put it on ourselves.

Fourthly: Our telephone line is down in several places, in fact, it needs new poles and re-stringing. Would the Department allow us One Hundred Dollars towards this expense?
Captain Edwards

Fifthly: I would like to call your attention to the outside condition of the building. The School has not been painted outside since 1929, therefore is very badly in need of paint for preservation. In a number of places, windows particularly, it is down to the bare wood. The amount allowed for painting the building in '29, that is, the School and all the out buildings, was Eight Hundred Dollars, Five Hundred Dollars for paint and Three Hundred Dollars for labour. Although there is a little extra work now I think that will very well cover the cost.

I should very much like to purchase the paint from the Bradham-Henderson people again in Winnipeg, as we found their paint of first class quality. The labour can be obtained locally again.

I should very much like to get an early reply as possible to these requirements as you know our season is very short here and we would like to be able to get right away to work at some of these things.

I would also like to get permission from the Department to take down the old wooden gravity tank. It is a great eye-sore to us. It also spoils the yard for boys play ground.

Would you kindly put these matters before the Department for consideration at your earliest convenience,

and oblige,

Yours faithfully,

Fred A. Mayo,

Acting Principal.

Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School (C.E.)

Dear Sir,

As requested in Department letter 129-6-5, dated April 28th, I inspected the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School on May 26th, 1937.

I found 92 pupils enrolled, 45 in the junior room and 47 in the senior room. Miss Dole is the teacher for the juniors and Miss Kilford for the seniors. I consider the class room work only fair; the reading could scarcely be heard and there was no expression. The children appeared indifferent and displayed lack of interest. Miss Kilford is only supplying and Miss Dole started her work last September; consequently neither of the teachers have had much chance to make a showing.

The children were clean, and both boys and girls had their hair neatly trimmed and combed. Their clothes and footwear appeared quite satisfactory.

The girls' dormitories were well aired, clean, and all beds neatly made. The row of posts supporting the roof on top of this dormitory were all loose. Apparently the lower floors have sunk and the roof is holding its original pitch. These posts should be tightened by means of blocks, and I am writing Mr. Mayo, instructing him to have this work done.

The boys' dormitories were both in good condition. The school was built for 130 pupils. Consequently with only 92, there is no overcrowding. One toilet bowl was

looking at the connection and I pointed this out to the principal, requesting him to have it repaired at once.

The building throughout was clean, and the interior decoration in fair condition.

The boys' washroom needs V-joint in the lower part of the wall. These walls were originally plastered but the plaster is badly broken and V-joint would be more serviceable.

The roof leaks over the passage leading to the boiler room and this should be repaired at once. Mr. Mayo has wallboard with which to fix the walls. I am authorizing this very necessary repair.

The fire hose are in good repair and extinguishers and axes are located on each floor throughout the building. The fire escapes are on the back of the building, directly over the kitchen and boilers, and the inside stairs pass down along the same side of the building. A different arrangement is absolutely necessary. I consider the fire escapes should open directly off the dormitories and these could be located either at each end of the building or in front. A veranda across the front with sliding poles from one floor to the next would be ideal. I hesitate to make a definite recommendation until a new principal is appointed.

The water system now in use I consider good, but believe another tank is necessary, as well as the pump suggested by Mr. Mayo. The stand pipe leaked too badly to be of use and was too costly to heat during the winter.

It is necessary at once to repair the pipe line and I am writing asking Mr. Mayo to do this. The well needs some repairs and a new trap door should be provided and locked.

At present, a lid 24" square is simply laid on top of the platform, which is not safe where little children are concerned. I am also writing regarding this matter.
The cattle number 32 head. I consider, at a school located such as this one is, that 15 milk cows would meet their requirements and that only two or three heifer calves should be raised. All the feed must be shipped in and I am sure it costs over $2,000 per year for feed, besides the full time services of a man. This is a bush country and even sufficient pasture is not available.

The cattle are in good condition and receive excellent care. This herd was tested some time back for Bang's disease but Mr. Marshall did not kill all the reactors. The inspector made a re-test this spring and insisted on the disposal of the two reactors and their offspring. Mr. Mayo has the four head isolated and will carry out instructions. I approve of having milk for the pupils but do not approve of expensive hobbies which the principals sometime acquire. A grade herd of 12 or 15 good milk cows is all that is needed and the young stock should not be raised because the purchase of feed makes this impossible. I am sure a 3 year old heifer, raised under present conditions, will cost three times the price of a good milking grade cow. A herdsman gives all his time in the care of this stock, which makes an added expense of at least $600.00 per year, and board. In a wooded country such as this, where all feed must be purchased and shipped in, only producing animals should be kept and the number should be reduced to the minimum.

The poultry house is used as a stock barn. I consider poultry a necessity and they certainly do not require grain in quantities to prohibit keeping a reasonable number. I think the Department should insist that certain stock and poultry be kept at each school and, if necessary limit the quantity.
The cultivated land does not exceed 18 acres. They have 4 good horses, a Fordson tractor, disc harrows, plough breaker and garden scuffler. I consider they have plenty of machinery for their cultivated land. There are no hay meadows, consequently there is no need for a mower or rake.

The telephone line needs repairing but there is staff enough at the school to do this work.

The building would be better for a coat of paint; but if the necessary program of work is carried out, there will be little, if any, money for the purchase of paint.

The staff at this school is the largest I have known, considering the number of pupils. Not counting Mr. Marshall, there are six men and, as pointed out above, the farm work is little more than gardening; outside of the cows and four horses there is no stock and all feed is purchased. There are eight lady members on the staff but I have no doubt they are kept busy.

Mr. Marshall, in my opinion, is still a very sick man and I doubt if he will again be able to do any work. He is confined to his bed, is very weak and has a trained nurse in constant attendance. Dr. Westgate is away and will not be back for a month. Before incurring any large expenditure, I would like to discuss matters with Dr. Westgate and learn his plans in connection with the principalship. A new principal will have his own ideas and by waiting we may save considerable expense. The work authorized should not cost more than $150.00. I will again write the Department after discussing the situation with Dr. Westgate.

Attached is Mr. Mayo's letter.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

With reference to the fire escapes, I am inclined to leave the present ones alone, but I would recommend a veranda across the front of the school and that sliding pole fire escapes be installed. The veranda makes this system ideal. The veranda would cost approximately $500.00, which is very little more than would be required to change the present fire escapes. The school is willing to provide most of the labour for building the veranda.

The uptake and pipes from the boiler need renewing and this will cost approximately $100.00. These pipes are badly burned and must be renewed. I feel the following is necessary and would recommend that authority be granted for the work -

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Already authorized    | $100.00|
| Pump and engine       | $400.00|
| Tank, 2,400 gals.     | $700.00|
| Boiler repairs        | $130.00|

If funds are available, the veranda should be erected as outlined and this would give adequate means for escape in case of fire.

I realise only $1,000.00 is provided for repair at this school but I am convinced the work outlined should be carried out and, with freight charges, the total expense will no doubt reach $1600.00.

The telephone line has been repaired and I consider the painting can wait, although Dr. Westgate made a strong plea that a quantity be provided.

I will be absent for almost a month and would ask that the Agent, Mr. Edwards, be instructed concerning the improvements recommended.

Mr. Mayo would like permission to remove the old stand pipe. It is now only an eye sore and the lumber...
could be used in building a pump house which will be required for housing the new pump unit. I would recommend that permission be granted to dismantle the stand pipe. I understand the necessary labour will be provided by the school.

Dr. Westgate assures me all reactors will be destroyed and the herd will be reduced to only sufficient to accommodate the school. The cost of feed makes it impossible to continue keeping the number now carried.

I have received no definite commitment regarding Mr. Marshall's future but, as stated before, I doubt if he will recover sufficiently to again take charge of the school. Mr. Mayo is reliable and is doing good work.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,

Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours dated July 28th, I am sorry for this delay, I have not been at home and did not get your letter.

What we need is a pump only, Typhoon type as #5 as on leaflet Gal per Hour 2500, Suction 2" Discharge 2' and the necessary fittings to connect it to service line in the well. We have a six H.P. engine which we can use for the purpose which will save the Dept expense of engine.

Yours faithfully,

Fred. A. Mayo,
Acting Principal

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. I29-646,

I am enclosing you as near as I can tell the necessary fittings etc., needed for pump to draw from well and discharge to the main service line and connect with tanks. This also provides for a take off in case of emergency for the main surface direct from the well.

The pump would have only a 10' lift and then push the water through the main line 250 ft. with about 15' rise to engine room and tank.

The engine we have to use for pumping is a 6½ h.p., 500 revolutions per minute, fitted with 12" flat pulley. We would need 12' 4" double ply composition belting.

The size of tank must not exceed 7' in diameter and must not exceed 9' in length, fitted with intake and discharge holes at the bottom, water gauge on one end and pressure gauge and blow off valve at 75 lbs. This corresponds with the tank we have.

Would you please give me instructions relating to the third paragraph in my letter of Aug. II, for alterations in engine room to make room for tanks. I would also like an answer to the other questions regarding the dismantling of the old wooden tank building. You also made no mention in your letter of the suggestion by Mr. Hamilton and Dr. Westgate for the fire escape solution.

An early reply to these questions would greatly oblige as the season is getting on.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Fred A. Mayo,
Acting Principal.

Memorandum: The Deputy Minister.

With further reference to my memorandum of the 6th of August and yours of the 30th asking for further information regarding the pump and tank to be purchased for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I beg to give you the following information.

The engine to be used to drive the pump is a 6½ H.P., 500 R.P.M., fitted with 18" flat pulley. 12 feet of 4" double ply composition tubing would be required.

The pump would only have a 10 foot lift and thus push the water through the main line 250 feet with about 16 feet rise to engine room and tank.

The size of the tank must not exceed 7 feet in diameter and 9 feet in length, fitted with intake and discharge holes at the bottom, water gauge on one end and pressure gauge and blow off valve at 75 lbs.

A list of the necessary fittings, etc., needed for pump to draw from well and discharge to the main service line and connect with tanks is attached.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th regarding fire escapes, which was turned over to me by Mr. Mayo.

Evidently the question of moving the fire escapes from the back of the building to the front of the buildings has been under discussion. It was first looked into as a matter at the time of our visit to Dr. Westgate's hut when we measured them we found there would be more than half of these stairways to be discarded. They do not come to the windows on the front the same as they do on the back. To stretch them out from the windows in the front would be a different angle from what they trend and as they are riveted to the side pieces it would take considerable labour to drill the holes by hand. The stretch on the girls' side is divided into five different pieces, two of them being short pieces coming to an opening in the middle of the stairway.

Then again, the moving of these fire escapes to the front of the building would not overcome the greatest difficulty that we have to contend with, that is, ice and snow. In the winter time these fire escapes have always been nothing less than death traps owing to the fact that the building has no screen trough and that there is a continual drip from the roof onto the centre of the stairway of these fire escapes, making them very dangerous. We carry out the Department's instructions as well as we can in keeping the fire escapes free of snow and ice and we try to keep them free of ice all through the winter; but it is absolutely impossible. I have worked on these fire escapes myself together with boys and before we get down to the bottom the top part is lead again. Then there is the danger of the accumulation of ice on the roof sliding off when least expected. Now this accumulation is not just mere icicles but we have seen them fall during a blizzard as high as twelve to fifteen inches and in some cases these chunks have damaged the fire escapes and smashed in the doors so that I wish to bring before your attention the fact that removing them from the one part of the building to the other is only moving out of the frying pan into the fire.

I, personally, have brought this matter before the different government inspectors who have visited the school from time to time. I have also submitted recommendations and prices for other types of fire escapes. I made a study of fire escape systems in the buildings in Winnipeg and Toronto, especially their schools and strongly recommended a spiral tank fire escape such as are in use in the Winnipeg Public Schools but the Department thought they were too expensive.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 4)
I understand that a recommendation was put in last year which I think would overcome a lot of our difficulty regarding fire escapes, that is building a verandah on the front of the school, giving exit from the dormitories and with a chute or stairway from floor to floor. The cost of such a verandah might be round about one thousand to twelve hundred dollars. I am just making a rough estimate as I have not obtained any prices on lumber for some time.

The main thing is to have doors opening out of the dormitories directly on whatever type of fire escape may be installed. The present type, which is on the back of the building only touches the two smallest dormitories and then you have to climb up out of a window and in one place over the top of a dwelling before reaching the fire escape itself. So I have always contended that so far as a help in case of fire they would only cause delay and waste of time. We are therefore depending entirely on our regular stairway as the chief exit in case of danger. So that I wish you will place your report before the Board next month and attention should be made or money expended on moving the present fire escapes from the back to the front of the building and I strongly recommend either the spiral tank or the verandah system of fire escape.

I have just received my duties and find a number of important things need immediate attention. None of these matters were discussed with me during my illness and I have a great deal to read up to find out what has been going on.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,
John F. J. Marshall (signed)

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter dated March 2nd, I enclose copy of a letter received from Mr. Marshall, principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I submitted a report on June 5th, 1937, on this school and in the report pointed out the need for some immediate action in connection with the fire escapes. Mr. Marshall suggests the spiral tank type of fire escape or a verandah, as suggested in my report. I am of the opinion that the type of fire escape suggested would be very expensive and perhaps cost as much as it would to build the verandah. The verandah will serve two purposes - as a means of escape in case of fire and, if closed in, will help to make the main building warmer.

In discussing this with Mr. Maye some months ago, he was of the opinion that $600.00 would go a long way towards building the verandah and perhaps another year it could be completed and enclosed with storm sash, necessitating a further expense of approximately $500.00.

The school needs the best protection we can give, and I am convinced that the verandah would supply this protection.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Re Night Watchman's Salary Cheque.

I have been requested by the Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, Winnipeg, to trace the Night Watchman's salary cheque for the amount of One Hundred and Twenty Dollars, ($120.00) for the months of October, November and December, 1937. This comes under letter from the Department No.129-3-6, Oct. 28, 1937.

It seems this cheque has not been received by the office in Winnipeg. I find on our files that the requisition for Night Watchman's salary for the quarter of October, November and December, 1937 was sent in with the quarterly returns on Jan. 13, 1938.

I wrote to Capt. Edwards who gave me the following information: "Our records show that voucher No. 6681 in the name of F.A.Mayo for One Hundred and Twenty Dollars, ($120.00) Night Watchman's allowance for the period of October, November and December, 1937 had been sent in from here on Jan. 14, 1938."

The Assistant Secretary Treasurer in a letter under date Sept.7,1938: "Will you be good enough to take up the matter again with Captain Edwards and ascertain if he can find any record of voucher #6681 having actually been mailed to the school or to this office."

I may say that we have no record of it being received in the school. Mr. Fred A. Mayo who was at the time acting principal during my illness said he had no further record of it.

We would greatly appreciate it if you could let us know if this cheque has been issued. If it has been issued and returned to you please give us dates and the signature of who signed it.

We regret very much to have to bother you on this matter but the Auditors would like this cleared up before the end of this quarter.
The Secretary

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

Reference my letter to you of 30th ultimo, and your reply of the 3rd instant re boiler inspectors report on the boilers at your school.

I took up the matter with the Department of Ottawa and their letter dated 8th inst., authorized me to arrange for a new uptake pipe between the boiler and the smoke stack of the heating boilers at your school.

You inform me in your letter that you are writing to the Fort Augustus Shipbuilding Company who built these boilers to ascertain the cost. As soon as you get this providing the cost is reasonable, you may order them, get the accounts in quadruplicate, certify each receipt, and forward to me for transmission to Ottawa for payment.

I do not know why the Boiler Inspector missed getting in the need for water, burned out, he generally includes those in his reports. Let me know what these would cost and I will see if I can get them for you.

As regards the sewing machines, you say many of the stoves are almost ruined through same that the manufacturers advised a new wheel which would cost $200.00. If so, Toronto, and that you would dismantle the machine and install the new wheel without costs. I am communicating to Ottawa about this.

Let me know what the Inspector suggested as safety devices in the laundry. He recommended certain precautions at the "Glenmore," C. and "Collin Jeffrey Schools," and those have been carried out.

I say Fifo today and informed him Chymo had made the necessary repairs regarding the wiring, and that now everything is in first class order. Says the cost will be borne by his Company or Chymo. I will write Doctor "regate" to this effect.

I am happy to inform you that Julia Land died at the Fort William Sanatorium the 6th instant; we could not get in touch with her mother so asked Inspectorium for her to be buried at Fort William. Agent Burrows having asked for us, we had not received your letter of the 3rd. We have orders for her to be buried at Fort William. She will be buried where other Indians are so no doubt her grandfather old Robert Land will be satisfied; will you write him and the mother, it might be better said from you. I had previously written the mother that Julia would likely come away very soon.

Sorry I have not been able to visit you lately but stress of work must be my excuse. This has been the busiest fall we have ever had, and the Indians have had a hard time to exist.

With kindest regards, and trusting your health is still improving.

Yours very faithfully,

For 1939

1. Repairs to front of building, constitutes verandah and fire escapes. Estimated cost $500.00

3. Lumber and material to seal in root house. This is a very necessary item and has been requested for years. I may say we have lost that amount in potatoes and vegetables being frozen in the course of the years since the root house was built. Estimated cost $400.00

This amount was withheld at the time the school was built until the decision of the Hydro Power was made. They have now blotted out the falls with the rise of the water on Lac Seul since they constructed the Ear Falls dam, for electrical purposes. This land is very close and has a good supply of wood for fuel purposes. Estimated cost $775.00

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing the time sheets filled up and signed for the work of installing pressure tank, dismantling the tower tank and tower and erecting pump house and installing pump and engine at the lake shore.

When we came to tapping into the well the wooden top cover on the well was so rotten it was inadvisable to put it back so instead of using wooden plank we raised the wall of the well eighteen inches and put a cement top and put a manhole in it to get down into the valves in the well. The pump house being located so close to the water we also put up an eight inch cement foundation and fitted in rock to eighteen inches and put an entire cement floor in. This raising of the well and pump house, I believe, should take care of the rise of water caused by the extra heavy rains in the spring and the backing up of this lake on account of the dam at Bas Falls and flooding of LaSeul.

When we dismantled the tower and tower tank we saved a considerable amount of lumber with which we were able to erect the pump house so that there was no extra expense caused for material other than the cement. We now have a pump house 12' x 12', with cement foundation and floor. Cement covered well and the two pressure tanks in full working order, so that I think our water supply should be adequate for our needs. The cement that we used I would like replaced later on as we had it on hand to complete the feed alleys in the barn but owing to the amount of work on hand at the present season we are unable to finish it. We used thirty-two bags of cement in all.

The pump and well caused us much delay as we were not able to complete it owing to the circumstances over which we had no control; that is, the extremely high water in this area. We had to get down a considerable distance below lake level to make the necessary connections which would have involved considerable expense in cribbing if we had not waited for the water to go down.

I am enclosing copy of letter from Inspector Hamilton as no reference number is given.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

I wish to acknowledge your letter 129-6-5 dated November 19th, and regret that unfortunately there has been some misunderstanding in connection with the expenditure authorized at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I was worried about this matter and on October 29th, 1937, I wrote the Department pointing out the amount already authorized, the balance required, and asking that I be advised what further expenditure might be incurred. The Department replied on November 10th, file 129-6-5, and would draw your attention to the following paragraph: "Hon. A.A. quoted me that the total of $1107.00 had been expended and I gathered from the reading of the remainder of this letter that I was free to authorize a further expenditure of approximately $800.00; With this in mind, I wrote Mr. Mayo on December 3rd, 1937, pointing out that the work could be carried out and emphasizing the fact that the amount of $800.00 allowed must not be exceeded. A copy of this letter was attached to our letter to you, file 211-11 A, of December 3rd.

In this connection, I quote the following extract from a letter received from Mr. Mayo, dated November 30th, for your information -

"I have this day seen Mr. Otto and while he is quite willing to do this work, he does not care to quote a price for it so I have arranged with him to do our end and assist with the installing the tank and pump etc. at rate of $50.00 per month. I will find some labour to assist him from this end. I don't think I shall need to keep him much over the month. I will manage to get the iron for the boiler room and keep under the $200.00 you mention."

The Department will note that Mr. Mayo thoroughly understood what work was to be carried out and that this work did not include the dismantling and taking down of the tower. It was quite clear from my letters that approximately $800.00 was to be used to install the equipment and the balance to put the metal ceiling on the boiler room. I suggested in the letter that if

Extract from Inspector Hamilton's report on the Sioux Lookout Indian residential school visited on June 2, 1939.

The proposed veranda across the front, to be used as a means of fire escape, is under construction. Mr. Marshall states it will yet require about $600.00 for material and $100.00 for labour. I consider both figures quite conservative, especially as regards to labour. In fact, Mr. Marshall is prepared to do most of the labour except for certain finishing work which requires first class carpenters. This veranda is most urgently needed as a fire escape and indeed is perhaps the cheapest, of a suitable kind, that can be constructed. I trust funds are available to complete this work.

The barn is in good repair but Mr. Marshall would like lumber to refloor the upstairs of the barn. The present floor has dried out, allowing all kinds of dust and dirt to filter through. A second floor, with paper between, would prevent this and make the stable much warmer for the cows during the winter months.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your report of the 2nd instant on your inspection of the Sioux Lookout Indian residential school. In this report you mention that the verandah across the front of the building is under construction and that the Principal estimates that an expenditure of approximately $700.00 for material and labour will be required to complete it.

In reviewing our files I find that the last communication we received with regard to the erection of this verandah was your letter of May 16, 1938. At that time we supplied cement, galvanized iron, nails and lumber. No subsequent request for additional material has been received from the Principal.

In preparing our appropriation for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an amount of $500.00 only for repairs and improvements at the Sioux Lookout school. Owing to the present setup of our appropriation it is practically impossible to exceed this amount.

Please communicate with the Reverend Principal and let me have requisitions covering the material which you consider should be supplied, it being understood, of course, that the cost of the material requested will not exceed $500.00.

Dear Sir:

As the snow will soon be gone work should be commenced on the
front verandah and fire escape to try and bring it to completion.
When we stopped on it last November we found we had to use more
of the galvanized iron slipped up under the main shingles of
the roof so that we could not complete covering the roof of the
verandah and we are short twenty pieces as follows:

14 pieces 8 foot length
6 pieces 6 foot length.

We would like very much if the Department would sanction the
purchase of this as soon as possible. We can put it on and that
will get the work covered in.

We have built as far as we can with what labour we have and have
now come to the place where we need a first class carpenter to
do the finishing work. The re-adjustment of radiators which are
under the present windows and piping can be done by our own
engineer. The window spaces have to be cut down and made in to
door frames and that is a ticklish proposition in itself as well
as putting down the top floor and the trimming of the outside
verandah fire escape. There are also two sets of stairs to be
built so you can see that this will require more than a jack knife
carpenter. We would like to be able to engage one by day labour.
The school can provide him with board and room and render what
ever helpers assistance is required. A good carpenter could be
obtained locally as there are several of them in Sioux Lookout.

Galvanized iron can be obtained from the J.H. Ashdown Co. Ltd.,
Winnipeg, who supplied the last lot. Estimated cost about
Twenty-Five Dollars.

Galvanized iron shipped flat: 14 sheets 96"x30" 28 gauge
6 sheets 72"x30" 28 gauge

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,
Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(Rev.) J.F.J. Marshall, Principal.

Memo: From Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

July 16, 1940.

Mr. G. Swartman,
Indian Agent,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Am enclosing list of material necessary to complete the verandah. All lumber on hand has been checked up by Mr. Harju, the carpenter, and together we have gone over the things that will be required to finish the job. I may say we have kept our nose down so far as we could, and the carpenter went out put up the frame work and laid the biggest part of the sub floor. We also used bridge timbers which we got from the Canadian National when they were replacing their bridge at the Fourth Mile. This meant buying four lengths of 12 x 12, 30' longs and 5 1/2 x 10, 12' longs. We also used on the sub floor some of the material that was saved out of the tank when it was taken down. We are assisting the carpenter in every way possible, keeping the lumber at his hand and putting one of the men on to help him when he needs extra help in putting on long boards.

You will also note that in all the material so far there has been no request for nails as we have supplied them out of school funds.

There should be a certain amount of paint procured and would suggest that we buy white lead, oil and turpentine and we can add the color to it ourselves. Mr. McLaughlin our Nightwatchman and gardener is a painter by trade and he would be delighted to be willing to brush for a short time. Even one hour could help preserve the lumber and keep it from cracking.

Paint I have taken this matter up with Mr. Harju and Mr. McLaughlin, they are both of the opinion that about

100 lbs white lead
20 gals. raw linseed oil
5 gals. turpentine

would be sufficient to give the work a priming coat and one covering coat. I haven't any prices on paint or oils as these fluctuate with the market.

As regards the railing for the top that we were speaking of using 3/8" iron pipe. This would take 150 lin. ft. 3/8" galvanized iron pipe together with the necessary fittings.

I am also enclosing list of material and necessary hardware.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully

(Rev.) J. F. J. Marshall, Principal.

Dear Sir:

With regard to your order of material supplied for repairs to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School on purchase order #129-6-5, order $3200, material supplied by Geo. Farlinger, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

This material arrived here last night about seven o'clock and on checking it over this morning with the carpenter we find that there is only about two or three items that will be usable to complete our present job. On the bill of material sent in to the Indian Office at Sioux Lookout we had on it "Note - All the above material to be in clear B.C. Fir," and as for Hardware "All above in antique copper." The lumber is the commonest spruce, some of it not even planed. I asked Indian Agent Swartman when he was out here when we checked up on what would be needed to complete the work if he would suggest to you the advisability of purchasing this small order from the Beaver Lumber Company who had supplied the finishing material so that we would be sure to have all the different sizes and types of wood match. Now most of this material is for two stairways and steps at the front of the school and needs clear B.C. fir.

The stairway material which consists of:

- 22 pcs. 2x6 - 10 No. 1 Com. fir,
- 3 pcs. 2x12 - 12 No. 1 Com. Fir.
- 4 pcs. 2x10 - 16 No. 1 Com. fir.
- 6 pcs. 2x4 - 16 No. 1 Com. fir.

This is nothing more than common spruce and jack pine. The 1100 Lin. feet of 2x2 spruce is just 2x4 scantling re-sawn and not even planed. This material had been asked for in fir as it is to be made up into the spindles on the stairs, the 350 of 2x2 quarter round is also spruce.
The Secretary,

The Hardware: The hinges are just the common iron hinges and the mortise locks are plain brass. We asked for all these to be in antique copper so as to match up the different rooms in which they are to be placed.

Would it not be possible to have these things exchanged for what is called for on our bill by returning the material that is of no use to us to Geo. Farlinger and getting the correct material from the Beaver Lumber Company.

We are awaiting your early reply as this is going to hold up the work by the end of the week.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

(Re:) J.F.J. Marshall,
Principal.
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On my way back to Winnipeg from Ottawa, I visited our Sioux Lockout School, not knowing until I arrived that about forty of the children were afflicted with measles. I was informed that they brought the disease with them when returning from their summer vacation, and that it was now reported to be widespread in the semi-remote Indian settlements from which they came. As there were approximately one hundred children in the School, with prospects that all would gradually be afflicted, we sent a nurse to assist the one on the staff in looking after them. Under the circumstances you will readily understand that other children cannot be admitted until those who are ill have recovered.

Mr. Marshall, the Principal, was not quite so well as he had been for the past year or two, having sustained some injury to his back when the School motor-boat he was driving collided in the darkness with a canoe operated by a man and his wife who were visitors in that part. The School boat had "navigation" lights burning, but there was no light on the canoe, and had it not been that Mr. Marshall was running at a very moderate rate, the results might have been much more serious than they were. Just before the collision, the man and woman in the canoe stood up, with the result that the woman was thrown into the water. She was rescued, however, by Mr. Marshall, but when he managed to get her over the side of his boat she fell against him, causing him to strike his back against part of the boat's furnishings. Mr. Marshall was able to move about at the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6215, file 470-5, part 4)
time of my visit, and as he has a very capable staff, no department of the work is being neglected.

There are two important requirements at this School to which I feel it my duty to refer, namely,

(1) Paint for all buildings. As they have not been painted, so far as I know, since they were built, I will include this item in the list of our requirements for next year.

(2) The new verandah is nearing completion, and I found the materials and workmanship to be of first rate quality. It did seem to me to be a great pity that no provision was made for glazing the spaces between the supporting pillars. This action is strongly recommended by the Principal, and also by the carpenter foreman, partly as a means of preventing rain and snow from beating in, with injurious effects on the material fabric, and partly as a means of increasing the comfort and usefulness of the verandah space itself.

The nearest estimate of the cost of glazing the nine large spaces, with three window sash in each, two of the same to be on pulleys, was $200.00 (it would be somewhat more if the carpenter had to come back again at a later date to do the work instead of finishing it off now), and I am wondering if this sum could be secured from any unexpended balance you may have in connexion with any of our other schools.

As the Principal informed me that he had secured without cost to your Department $125.00 worth of material used in building the verandah, I greatly hope you may be able to authorize the glazing suggested. Should the cost exceed the $200.00 estimated, our Commission will agree to find the balance. Immediate action will be necessary if the work is to be done before the men now building the verandah leave the School.

I greatly appreciated the opportunity afforded me during my recent visit to Ottawa of discussing together some of the problems of the Indian educational work, and I am more convinced than ever that this work, with all its difficulties, is well worthwhile. The development and strengthening of the physical, intellectual and moral fibre of the Indian segment of our country's population, must surely help to strengthen the position of our country as a whole.

Very kind regards,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

At the time of my recent visit to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School on November 16th fire drills were carried out which proved to be quite satisfactory. From the time the alarm sounded when the children were in their class rooms they were all outside in two minutes. This was a surprise alarm. The practice drills were then repeated with the children in the dormitories in order to demonstrate the value of the new verandah fire-escape. This was also highly satisfactory. The children were all out of the building in less than three minutes. The verandah appears to be a very valuable addition insofar as fire escape is concerned as well as adding to the appearance of the building.

A few discrepancies were noted in the fire protection system but these could be remedied at no great cost. These are listed as follows:

(1) There are no bells in the dormitories. The bells are in the corridors and are scarcely audible in the dormitories with the doors closed.

On the girls' side of the building there is only one bell on the first floor in the corridor and none on the top floor at all, although it has been wired for a bell. For some reason the bell has never been installed. I would recommend that an electric bell be placed in each of these dormitories in addition to the existing bells in the halls.

The bells should be screened with heavy mesh wire to prevent the children from molesting them.

(2) There are no bells in the laundry, boiler-room, engine-room, dining-room nor in the connecting basement halls and with the machinery in operation it is almost impossible to hear the alarm from the floors above. It is recommended that a double bell be installed in the basement, one above the door in the engine-room - which would serve both engine-room and boiler-room. A second bell of the same type should be placed above the door in the laundry - which would serve the laundry as well as the laundry kitchen hall.

(3) Extra fire hose - 1½ inch - should be readily available at all times. All the fire hose is now on the racks and is in fair condition but there is no spare hose. At least 500 feet should be available as extra hose.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of November 14, 1940, reporting on your inspection of the Sioux Lookout Residential School on November 6.

In paragraphs one and two of your letter you requested bells for the dormitories and other rooms because, as you stated, "A few discrepancies were noted in the fire protection system but these could be remedied at no great cost". You enclosed a requisition for 6 fire alarm gongs 6", 2 double gongs 4" and 400' of covered electrical wire. On obtaining prices from different firms it was found that these will cost in the vicinity of $300.00. This appears to be a rather heavy expenditure, especially in view of your statement that the system could be remedied at no great cost. Possibly you had in mind a cheaper type of bell from that included on the requisition and on which we have obtained quotations. Please let me hear further from you in regard to this matter.

Would it not be possible to install a siren alarm on the steam boiler? This could be done at very reasonable cost and when in operation should rouse everyone in the school.

The recharges for the fire extinguishers at present in the school have already been ordered and arrangements are also being made to secure the fire hose, nozzles, spanners and fire axes.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

We are in urgent need of the hose replacements which were placed on order on Nov. 9, 1940.

For your information I may say that when we have a fire drill the basement hose is run out and turned on, thus enabling us to test the hoses. The hose is then dried and put on the rack on the top floor, thus the hose from upstairs work down to the basement and they all get their turn in testing.

Dear Sir:

Further reference is made to Mr. Hoey's letter of January 16th, file 129-6-5, with reference to the fire alarm system at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I have taken this matter up with the Acting Principal and learn that the steam boilers only carry a pressure of two pounds and are not in use from May to September. The compressed air water tank has a maximum pressure of 75 pounds but as the water is used the pressure drops and since the pump is not working all the time it is doubtful if a siren would be satisfactory or reliable if attached to the compressed air tank. These facts would seem to preclude the use of the steam boiler and compressed air tank unless there is a type of siren alarm that could be adopted to operate from such a low pressure.

As previously pointed out, there is only one gong installed on the girls' side of the building, although on the top floor on the girls' side there are wires for a gong which has never been installed. When a fire alarm sounds it is necessary for the staff members to go around to each bed in order to wake the children up—which requires a great deal of extra time. It has been brought to my attention that it takes the girls twice as long to get out of the building as it does the boys during a night fire drill although during day drills the girls are often out sooner than the boys.

In order to remedy the situation I would suggest that one gong could be installed on the top floor attached to the existing wires. This would help considerably and there should be no additional costs. This would not complete the fire alarm system but would go a long way toward improving it.

Yours very truly,

Gifford Swireman,

Dear Sir:

During your visits to the School you have observed from time to time how the outside of the main school building is deteriorating from lack of paint. In our Estimates for 1941 we asked for paint for the main school building. For your information the school was last painted in 1929 and for the last eight years we have been estimating for paint for the school. However, nothing has been done in this connection to date.

The last few winters the school has been very difficult to heat, especially the north side while a north wind is blowing. At times we have had to move children from the classroom to one of the other back rooms and have also had to utilize the Chapel in this connection.

A great many of the boards on the outside of the building have no paint on at all and they are warping. There is also considerable space between them, so much so that in places the builders paper between the siding has also become dilapidated by the weather. If the building is left in this condition it is going to cost more as each year goes by.

You will remember from our last conversation regarding paint on the school that we thought it would be unwise to re-paint it as the boards will all have to be scraped and a large number replaced. This would take considerable time and labour. Instead we thought it might be better to Insul-Brick the building.

Since then I have taken the liberty of calling on Mr. Josgrove, Manager of the Beaver Lumber Company who very kindly came out and measured up the building and gave us an estimate of the cost of Insul-Bricking the main school building.
Mr. G. Swartman,

The total estimated cost, including labour and material will be One Thousand seven hundred and fifty dollars, ($1750.00). Of this Fifteen Hundred Dollars would be for material and the balance for labour. The Insul-Briak, as you know, is fire-proof and has an insulating value. I believe in the long run this would be the most economical and should be able to stand up for a good many years.

Should the Department see their way clear to complete this work I think it would be a great improvement in the appearance of the building. It would be more especially appreciated now by all concerned as you are aware the road is now completed from Sioux Lookout to the Trans Canada Highway and the last few summers we have had a large number of American Tourists coming out to go through the building and it is certainly most unsightly for our Southern visitors to see and take back a report such as they might with the School in its present condition.

We realize the handicap the Department is placed under owing to the present conflict, however, we think if it is at all possible this should be done now.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,
Yours faithfully,

Geo. L. Marshall,
Acting Principal.

Dear Sir:

In the list of requirements forwarded to you on Oct. 2nd last and which our Commission desired your Department to meet during the current fiscal year, the sum of $800, to paint the outside of the Sioux Lookout School was included, also the sum of $400, to complete the root house at this School. Additional amounts were included for other items, but in view of the addition of the outside walls of the main school building and in view of the difficulty caused by wet conditions of securing all the funds required for Indian educational work; our Commission keenly desire that precedence be given to the question of saving the walls of the main building from further deterioration. The completion of the root house and other requirements may be allowed to stand over for another year.

From information received from Mr. G.L. Marshall, Acting Principal of this School, it appears that during the last few winters the School management has had considerable difficulty in heating the building, especially along the north side when a north wind is blowing. He states that at times it had been necessary to move the children from the classroom on that side to one of the other back rooms and that the Chapel had also been used for classroom purposes.

As the School has not been painted for twelve years, he states that many of the boards on the outside of the building have no paint at all and have warped so much that there is a considerable space between them, leaving the builder's paper exposed to the weather.
From communications received from Mr. Marshall, I gather that he has talked the situation over very carefully with Mr. Indian Agent Swartman, with the result that they consider it would be a waste of money to attempt to re-paint the building. They recommend that it be Insul-bricked instead and have estimated the total cost including labour and material at $1,750. Of this amount approximately $1500. would be required for material.

In support of their recommendation they point out that Insul-bricking is not only fire-proof but has, as its name implies, an A1 insulating value as well. Our Commission have approved this recommendation and strongly recommend that action be taken immediately. Should your Department agree to this expenditure, our Commission, in view of the urgency and importance of the need, would be willing to contribute should any contribution be necessary, the sum of $200. to help to meet the total cost.

Should you agree to the work being undertaken at once, I will be obliged if you will notify your representative and Mr. Marshall accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Further reference is made to previous correspondence regarding Art-Bric siding for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. It has been exceedingly difficult to secure the services of a carpenter locally to quote a price on the work. Mr. O.A. Hardju, whom we had previously engaged is no longer available.

Mr. Wisenberg, a local carpenter has sized up the job and states he would not be willing to contract for the work but would take it on an hourly basis at .75¢ per hour. He estimates it would require four men working approximately six weeks to complete the job.

We also had Mr. Preiss of Hudson, Ont., who is a carpenter and builder estimate on the work. He quotes $825.00 to complete the job. He could commence immediately but Mr. Wisenberg informs us he would be unable to undertake the work before the middle of August.

I am not familiar with the work nor the ability of Mr. Preiss. Wisenberg has the reputation of being a first class carpenter and has had considerable experience with this type of work.

Both Wisenberg and Preiss strongly recommend that Insul-Bric mould be used around the windows and doors instead of the present casings. They claim that such a heavy wooden casing would detract from the whole appearance of the insul-bric. Approximately 2000 ft. of mould would be required. This retails locally at .42¢ per foot. In lots of 100 or more we could purchase same for .33¢ per foot. I am also informed that no labour costs would be saved by using the old casing material.

Please let me have your advice regarding the foregoing at your earliest convenience in order that we may get the work under way before the cold weather sets in.

Yours very truly,
