Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phelan's letter File 129-6-5 of July 22nd with respect to the estimated costs for applying Art-Bric siding to the Sioux Lockout Indian Residential School.

I am unable to state exactly why there is such a difference in the quotations. Our original estimate was based on quotations furnished by Mr. O. Hardju and from the North American Lumber Co'y. The North American Lumber Co'y, estimated 3 hours labour per square. Their labour figure was .80¢ per hour. There were 135 squares furnished for the job which brought the total figure to $324.00. Hardju's estimate was based on 5 weeks labour working 10 hours a day at .70¢ per hour for himself and .40¢ per hour for a helper, making a total of $330.00.

Since the above estimates were furnished, Hardju is no longer available and the North American Lumber Co'y informs me they are unable to secure carpenters for immediate work. They could not estimate when carpenters could be obtained.

The Beaver Lumber Company quotes $3.75 per 100 lineal feet for mould in B.C. fir. This material is now also obtainable from the George E. Farlinger Company at $3.00 per 100 lineal feet. This is pine and when painted would be just as suitable as fir.

There is another carpenter in Town whom I have asked to estimate on the job, Mr. [Frank Hakala], but he is working on a contract at present and will not be finished until sometime next month. His estimate will be forwarded as soon as received. If this does not prove satisfactory I would suggest arrangements be made with a contractor from some outside point to do the work.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of August 7th, file 129-6-5 with reference to quotations from Mr. Frank Hakala for work at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Mr. Hakala today, advises as follows:

He does not wish to tender for the job as he is of the opinion it would cost from $75.00 to $100.00 more than if he undertook the work by day labour.

He estimates that it will require approximately 20 days for three men at cost of $1.75 per hour—working ten hours per day—the total cost would be $350.00. He states he did not have an opportunity to examine all the siding that may have to be replaced, but the length of time required for the job will also depend on the amount of the old siding that will have to be replaced. He also estimates that approximately 2000 feet of shiplap may be required to replace the siding boards. This maybe furnished locally (Farlinger Lumber Co.) at $30.00 per thousand.

Mr. Hakala states that he could commence work September 5th or 10th. Please advise what action may be taken.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of advance of $550.00 to pay wages due to the men employed applying the Insul Bric siding at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, and to advise that the work has now been completed.

Final pay list are in and it is found that the total due for wages is $510.75. Consequently we will require an additional $160.75 to pay the men in full.

It is noted that I submitted the figure of $350.00 as quoted by Mr. Hakala in August, and when I approached him on the subject of the discrepancy between his original estimate and actual cost he explained that this was partly due to general increase in wages since August—at the time he was employing helpers at 35¢ and 40¢ per hour and was charging 60¢ per hour for his own services. He also pointed out that the present rate locally for experienced carpenters is 75¢ per hour. Hakala also states that there was more work required for the application of the siding than he estimated due to so many windows and corners, also that possibly $20.00 to $25.00 in labour costs could have been saved by using the old window casings instead of the new brick mould, but that much of the old moulding was partly rotten and would eventually have to be replaced.

Dear Sir,-

Your communication of January 8th, addressed to the Superintendent of the Bar Falls Power Plant, Goldpines, Ontario, has been submitted to the Commission for attention and reply.

For your information the Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario supplies power to the Town of Sioux Lookout and the Hamlet of Hudson. We understand that the school which you refer to is some five or six miles from Pelican Narrows, and would be at least that distance from the Commission's nearest line.

At the present time all extensions to consumers in rural districts throughout the province have been curtailed, for the purpose of conserving materials such as iron, steel, copper, etc., for war purposes, and therefore, under such circumstances, it would be impossible for the Commission to supply service to the school until the present war is over.

In any event, the construction of five or six miles of line would cost anywhere from $5,000.00 to $10,000.00, and it would be necessary for the Commission to be assured of a sufficient revenue from power supplied to meet the carrying charges on the capital investment, as well as to meet the cost of energy supplied.

As it is impossible, under present war conditions, to make any capital expenditure at the present time, we would recommend that the matter be withheld in abeyance until the war is over, at which time the Commission would be pleased to go into further details.

Yours truly,

TOJ/AP (sgd) R.T. Jeffery, Chief Municipal Engr.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

When our Commission learned that new batteries would soon be required at their Sioux Lookout School they began to explore the possibility of having this School linked up with the Ear Falls Power Plant which provides the Town of Sioux Lookout with power and light.

On the 8th inst. I wrote to the District Superintendent (Mr. W. Dowds) of this Power Plant at Goldpines, Ontario, inquiring about the possibility of securing the electric service we needed. On January 13th he replied stating that he was forwarding my letter "to his superiors in Toronto".

From Toronto I have received the enclosed letter written on January 21st by the Chief Municipal Engineer.

While his letter does not appear to embody much hope of our securing the hydro electric service we desire, I might point out that he is mistaken in his understanding that our School is so far away as five or six miles from the nearest point on their power line. I have the assurance of the Principal that the School is not more than a mile, or a mile and a fraction, from the nearest point of the power line, and I am wondering if this fact would alter the decision set forth in the enclosed letter. The cost of installation, if the School management provided the poles, should not amount to a very great deal more than the cost of a new set of batteries, and our Commission
January 26, 1943.

will be very grateful if you will take this matter up direct with the Hydro Electric Power Commission of Ontario and do what you can to secure their service for this School.

Should it be impossible to persuade the Power Commission to furnish us with this service during the duration of the war, then it will be necessary to have 56 new battery cells provided with the least delay possible. The ones now in use have been there since the School was built in 1926.

It is practically certain also that a new engine will be required to generate the light as the Lister engine which has been in use so long, is about worn out, and it is practically impossible to secure repair parts for this engine at the present time.

I have inquired from the Globalite Batteries Ltd., regarding the cost of 56 cells, and they inform me that the type they recommend (W 1S, 110 volt, 270 amperes) would cost approximately $875.00 f.o.b. Winnipeg.

Commending this very important matter to your careful and sympathetic consideration, believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

Your letter of Jan. 29th received for which we thank you. As per your request I have made inquiries as to the nearest point at which our School could be linked up with the Ear Falls Power Plant.

Mr. E.J. Cole, Manager of the Sioux Lookout Hydro has just informed me that they supply power to the Airways Beacon, situated a mile and a small fraction from the School. The power line from Sioux Lookout is run cable-like under Pelican Lake and up over the railway track to the Beacon, situated four and a half miles from Sioux Lookout. Our School is situated about a quarter mile directly in from the Five Mile Post. I trust that when your Department is aware of the true facts concerning our nearness to the power line and our urgent need of some such reliable source of power that we shall not be deprived of such for the duration of the war.

I regret that I am unable to give you any first-hand information as regards the care of our batteries now in use as I took over the Principalship here late as June 15th last. It is true some of the batteries have been in use for many years while others have been replaced. At the present, however, they are in no condition to be relied upon to supply us with either light or power. In an institution such as our School it is, to say the least, most difficult to have to use our lamps and lanterns periodically, but when one presses the fire alarm button and there is no response due to weakness of batteries it is high time, in my opinion, that something was done.

Thanking you for your kind attention,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

(The Rev.) A.B. Charles,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I have endeavored to list different materials in order of the urgency of our need for the same. As to batteries, we have just received word from the local Indian Agent that they are arriving within ten days. We wish to tender our sincere thanks for your efforts in procuring same.

The Hot Water Tank now in use is in very poor condition. There are at least eight pit holes along the side from end to end. The tank sprung a leak every two or three weeks during last winter and holes were promptly plugged. On his last visit the boiler Inspector suggested having the tank replaced. We strongly urge that a new tank be prepared and shipped to us ready for installation, so that we will not suffer the inconvenience of being without hot water when the cold weather sets in.

As regards the farm, we have never had sufficient wire to enclose the fields in which we grow vegetables for our own consumption. The result is that the cows are continually breaking through the makeshift fence and destroying our produce. We would be obliged indeed therefore if wire as listed could be shipped to us at earliest convenience.

The White Lead, Turpentine and Linseed Oil are required for the painting of brick moulding around all windows and doors of the school building. This work, I believe, should have been completed by the contractor who put on the Insul Bric. Due to cold weather the painting was not done, and the moulding will deteriorate if left as it is. We hope to be able to do it ourselves with the help of the men on the staff.

Barn Paint has been requisitioned because the paint is scaling off the barn, and we feel that painting in time will preserve the building, which is a credit to the school.

Drinking Fountains have been ordered for two of the children's dormitories. We had 26 to 36 pupils in each dormitory. During the night they often require a drink. For this purpose they have had a jug or pail of water just inside the door on the floor or on the small table, with one enamel cup beside it from which all drink. We consider this very unsanitary, and inviting the spread of disease germs. Thus we feel the need of drinking fountains is urgent.

The roof of the new verandah on the school building leaks like a sieve in several places. This we hope to repair at a cost of about fifty dollars. The foundation of the school building and residence is cracked, so that at times of heavy rain, water come in on the basement floors. We have a few bags of cement on hand, but may have to get an experienced man locally to assist in the repair of the same.

Faithfully yours, (sgd) A. B. Cheales, Principal

Dear Sir:

Referring to Mr. Phelan's letter of July 24th,
File 123-6-5 with respect to repairs, replacements, etc.,
received at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,
we have today received a sketch of the water tank
requested, showing the position of the holes with connecting
pipes. Same is attached hereto, also copy of letter from
the Rev. Principal supplying information as requested in
paragraph three of your letter.

Regarding the roof on the new verandah at the
school, my inquiries reveal that the leaks were caused by
the nails in the corrugated iron roofing not being soldered.
The school authorities were to attend to this themselves but
neglected to do so. It is estimated that two men working for
part of two days could complete the job. When the roof expands
it has a tendency to draw the nails, and in order to make a
good job with corrugated iron roofing, the nails should always
be soldered. The cost of this repair should not exceed $25.00
although an expenditure of $50.00 has been authorized.

With reference to the repairs to the foundation,
I had an opportunity to inspect and examine the requirements
very thoroughly last week, accompanied by Mr. Klym who is
experienced in such matters. Mr. Klym estimates that approx-
imately forty bags of cement will be required and $35.00 or
$40.00 required for labour. This will be in excess of the $50.00
authorized for the job, but it is essential and I recommend that
the additional funds required be provided. It is expected that
we can commence the job about September 25th. The cause of
the trouble is due to lack of eave troughing on the building.
Originally a cement open drainage system was built around the
foundation of the building to carry off the water from the
roof. This however, did not prove to be very satisfactory
after it had been heaved and cracked by frost.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Would you please bring the following matter to the attention of your Department at your earliest convenience.

We feel that you should know of the rather difficult situation in which we are placed at times. For the past year or more, since I became principal, we have had only the large launch with "Kermath" engine as a means of getting to town by water in summer. This launch has been in use since the school was built and it has sprung leaks at different times; the bottom also getting quite rotten and unserviceable.

I bought an 18 foot Peterborough from Bowley House, which is the only other means we have of travelling on water. Last fall we managed for a month or more before freeze-up by borrowing an outboard Johnson motor from Ontario Lorentz (local), and using it on my Peterborough. A few weeks ago, when our launch sprung...
another leak, I had to call on forestry again and they readily and willingly loaned me the help outboard they had—a 1½ H.P.

When we have to make several trips each week to town—a distance of seven miles, this is very inconvenient. We get there, but it requires over three hours on the water with the small 1½ H.P. engine. Then again, we have two pupils 12 and 14 years of age who have to go to Sioux Lookout for pneumothorax treatment every ten days. A somewhat faster means of travel would be much more convenient and not so tiring.

Considering the foregoing will you please let me know if your Department will finance the purchasing of a five or seven horse power outboard engine (Johnstone) for our school. A three H.P. motor would be a convenient size for use on my Peterborough which is in good condition and which I would be willing to sell very reasonably, that it might be the property of the school.

Wishing to hear from you soon,

faithfully yours,

(Rev.) Alan R. Charles
Sioux Lookout,

Dear Sir:

Attached please find letter handed to me today from the Reverend Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School with respect to repairs required for the School Boat. The craft is certainly in need of reconditioning and my inspection reveals that a new bottom may be required. The planks appear to be rotten from the keel to the water line. This should have been attended to in the spring before the boat was launched. It is recommended that authority be given to have the necessary repairs made as soon as possible. The estimated cost is $100.00, although it will depend on how much of the planking must be replaced.

The School should have some sort of an auxiliary boat and engine, but the one owned by the Reverend Principal is too small. It is only suitable for one or two passengers as well as the man running the engine. The boat described in the letter is only 1½ long. I would also recommend that the school be provided with an outboard motor, to be used strictly for business purposes only.

It is unfortunate that this School is without a general utility or handyman as most of their equipment shows lack of attention or repairs.

Dear Sir:

Referring to Mr. Hoey's letter of September 21st, File 129-6-5, with respect to repairs required for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School boat, I wish to advise that we were unable to have the necessary work done before the boat was laid up for the season. If the season permits, we will have the boat brought into Sioux Lookout from the School, in order that we can proceed with the work in the early spring. Will it be necessary to obtain authorization for this expenditure at a later date?

List of requirements Sioux Lookout School—1943-4

1. The Rave Troughing I mentioned during my visit at the Indian Affairs Office last August. The rain water from the roof rests on, and has cracked the foundation in several places. This has resulted in both Basement Playrooms floors being flooded at times of rain.

2. Plumbing connections throughout the school are very much in need of a thorough checking over and repairs put in where required. Toilets, taps and pipe unions are forever sprung leaks.

3. The Sewage System is also in need of a thorough inspection. The Main Drain backs up occasionally causing a flood on the Laundry or Kitchen floors. We conclude there is a break in the Drain Tiling, and intended to investigate and if possible repair this Fall. Being very short-handed on staff however, we have been quite unable to do all that is to be done.

The present system of Toilets in Girls' and Boys' Lavatories is quite old—a water tank near the ceiling which flushes the toilets once every few minutes. Then there are no covers at all on the toilets, which is quite unsanitary. We could make the Toilets do for a time if necessary, but would urge that proper covers be made for them.

A large pipe is required to convey smoke from the two large boilers to the Chimney. Last Fall this pipe had small holes burnt through it at the time of a Chimney fire. A large sheet of galvanized tin was wrapped tightly, completely round it and made secure with metal bands.

As regards the farm, three implements are urgently needed; this year we had about ten acres of hay and green feed all of which we had to cut and rake by hand. This resulted in some feed being spoiled by wet weather before we were able to complete harvest and storing. Our hay acreage is increasing each year. Much the same is true as regards the potato crop. We plant and harvest the potatoes by means of a plow and this necessitates much scratching by hand to land all the potatoes. In a wet season such as we have had the past two years some of the crop is lost. A Gang Plow is required as we are quite unable to do the necessary fall Plowing with a walking plow.

Lastly having no other boat or engine to travel on the water, we are indeed handicapped when our launch springs a leak (as happened this Fall), or the engine refuses to start. We do feel that we should have an auxiliary outboard engine of some type, and a Peterborough to use in case of emergency.

I have discussed all the above requirements with our local Indian Agent, and with his approval I respectfully submit same.

It seems odd to me but Local Indian Agent informs me that the list of requirements submitted to him in June, (a copy of which I enclose) is the 1943-4 list. Believing it to be the 1943-5 I have as per your recent request, prepared another list dated Oct. 8th, 1943.

R. A. Hoey
Superintendent Welfare & Training
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Mines & Resources
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

Re. your s of June 4/43

You request that I advise just what is meant in a certain statement re. equipment and repairs at our school.

By the phrase "insurmountable obstacles" I meant nothing more than the fact that due to war conditions, priorities etc. on many articles, it is difficult and even impossible to obtain necessary equipment. I had particularly in mind, the 1926 Fordson tractor at our school. We have had, to say the least, several nerve wrecking experiences with this old tractor. In June 1941 a serious break occurred to this tractor while at work in the field so that it was of no use for months. During the past several winters we have had to build a fire under the tractor in order to get it started to enable us to saw wood with it; this a regular weekly experience. Periodically it would break down in one place after another so that we had to resort to Mandisswe to keep up a supply of fuel. This spring a part of the inside of the tractor broke, crashing out a large hole in the head and break case, an irreparable break. We have tried for months through the Indian Residential School Commission, Winnipeg to obtain a new tractor with no results as yet. We sincerely hope that such will be available by September at the latest.

A Hay Mower and Rake have been requisitioned for in past with no result. As we are growing more and more hay each year, it has become practically impossible to harvest the crop entirely by means of hand scythe and rake. We trust therefore, that this equipment may be available in not too distant future. We are endeavouring to rent a mower to harvest this year's crop.

Trusting the foregoing information satisfactory and hoping that, if at all possible, the Indian Department will hasten the procuring of a tractor for our school.

Thanking you,

Very truly yours

(The Rev.) J. B. Cheales
Principal.

Sioux Lookout, Ont., Sept. 10, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept.of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to advise that the plumbing system at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School is at present unserviceable. The main sewer line is apparently blocked and the sewage has backed up into the dining room portion of the basement, and fumes, sewer gas etc, are throughout the building. Temporary measures have been taken to clear the moisture from the basement and it was not until yesterday that I was able to get in touch with a plumber who would undertake the supervision of the necessary repairs. He is unable to give me even an approximate price, as it will largely depend on the amount of excavating necessary, providing some of the sewer tiles or soil pipes are broken. If complete excavation is necessary, it would probably cost three or four hundred dollars.

I have requested Mr. Hamilton to purchase a long sewer rod in Winnipeg and ship immediately, in order that the plumber may commence the necessary probing without further delay. I trust this action is approved, and regret that at present I am unable to supply an estimate of the cost. Dr. Bell suggests that this work be attended to immediately before any serious condition develops at the school.

G. Swartzen,  
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re Sioux Lookout Sewage system

We have recently been advised by Principal Cheales of our Sioux Lookout School that the sewage system at this school is giving considerable trouble and although we have asked Principal Cheales to consult Indian Agent Swartman in this connection, we are now writing to inform your Department of the matter and to ascertain if the Department will assume responsibility for the urgent remedial measures which it would appear must be taken in the near future. As you will know, this school was erected by the Government and the sewage system now in use, installed at that time.

For your information I enclose a plan of the system as furnished by the Principal and about which he writes as follows:—

"Enclosed you will please find a rough plan of the Sewage drain at our school. I regret that there was apparently no blueprint or correct plan of any kind to be found. I have endeavoured therefore to make it as clear as possible. There are no doubt some errors and omissions in this plan but I trust it will give you a general idea."

In this connection I may say that we understand that the full plans of the sewage system would be in the possession of the Department.

As stated we have asked Mr. Cheales to get in touch with Indian Agent Swartman and endeavour to secure a local Plumber to look into the matter and submit an estimate of the repairs he considers must be carried out.

In the meantime, however, I will be obliged if you will
let me know if the plans mentioned are available and also if your Department will be prepared to assume the full responsibility for the repairs which, it is evident, must be effected in the very near future.

Dear Sir,

As directed by Dr. Alderwood Secretary, Indian Res. School Commission, we submit the following list of what we wish the Dept. of Indian Affairs to purchase for us this year out of the amount still available for the use of our school. We have endeavoured to list items in order of the urgency of our need.

1. We have no Flue Cleaner with brush and require same just as soon as it can possibly be provided.

2. The large smoke pipe leading from the boiler to chimney is in a dangerous condition and has burnt through in one or two places. It is badly bent and has at least two patches on it. We have been urged by the Boiler Inspector to have it replaced before the real cold weather sets in. A diagram of the pipe is enclosed.

3. The Hot Water Tank was listed on our previous estimates, and a detailed description along with diagram was sent to the Commission or the Department. We enclosed another diagram of this tank showing how it is fitted from end to end along the upper side. We would urge that an effort be made to replace this tank as soon as possible. The present tank appears to have been made in two sections joined together in the centre. (see diagram)

4. Our only Stillson Wrench was accidently broken recently; a tool badly needed regularly.

5. The Water Glasses on both our Cold Water tanks need replacing.

6. A plow as listed has been ordered on previous estimates. Each year more land is being cleared and broken, and we now seldom get more than half of the land plowed before freeze up sets in. Having only a One-Narrow Walking Plow, we are thus handicapped.

7. A Laundry Stee as listed was recently ordered from Ashdown's Winnipeg but their invoice lists same as One Stock. This store is urgently needed as the one now in use is falling to pieces. Said store is used not only for heating of the Laundry irons, the Laundry work, but senior girls do considerable ironing by hand.

8. Tractor. Though we have had considerable correspondence as regards tractor, no definite word has been received to date as to one being shipped. Unless one is procured for us we are faced with the rather impossible problem of having to saw our winter wood supply by hand. Though we have a small one cylinder engine which is sometimes used for sawing, it has not the power required for sawing the larger wood needed in the furnaces, and keeping an adequate supply of wood on hand. We would urge therefore that if possible, any amount of grant left be used towards the purchase of a tractor. Any assistance the Department of Indian Affairs could give in speeding up the procuring of a tractor would indeed be appreciated.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

I have your letters of the 9th instant, with reference to the Sioux Lookout Residential School. You must have misunderstood me when you were in the Department, as I certainly did not intend to intimate to you that the Department could pay the salary of the engineer, either in whole or in part. Members of the staff at residential schools are hired by the school management and paid by them from their per capita grant or other receipts. I simply wanted to have on file a definite statement from you to the effect that you consider the present engineer of the Sioux Lookout School is sufficiently competent to adequately look after the machinery that is under his care. It is my intention to communicate with the Secretary of the M.S.C.C. in regard to this matter.

With regard to the requests made by the principal, you may authorize him to purchase a boiler flue cleaner with brush which it is noted can be secured from Ashdown's in Winnipeg at a cost of $6.20.

The Purchasing Branch is being requested to secure a new smoke stack and a hot water tank, although at the present time I am not exactly certain that the information given is sufficiently detailed to satisfy their requirements.

You may also purchase the water glasses for the cold water tanks.

If the Principal supplies exact information regarding the type of laundry stove he considers is necessary, an endeavour will be made to secure it in the future. We have not yet received any information that will permit our submitting the matter to the Purchasing Branch.
It is not our present practice to supply farm machinery to residential schools and consequently favourable consideration cannot be given to the request for a plow.

What has been said regarding farm machinery applies also to the tractor, though it is noted that you consider a heavy duty, stationary engine would be suitable. In this case too detailed information will have to be supplied to this office regarding the type of engine required before adequate consideration can be given to the Principal's request.

I regret that at the present time we are unable to supply the flags, as these are extremely difficult to secure. We hope to have some in stock within the next few months and, if so, will keep in mind the request from the Sioux Lookout School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I wish to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 15th, with respect to the employment of an engineer at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, as discussed in conversation during my visit to the Department last month. Mr. Hoey did not give me the impression that the Department would pay the salary of an engineer, either in whole or in part. However, I did recommend that the Department provide a grant to the School in order that they might employ a competent man at $60.00 per month.

Mr. Pratt, applicant for the position was in to see me today and stated that he had been in communication with the Secretary of the M.S.C.C. They had offered him a monthly wage of $57.50. Dear Sir,

Quoting File I44;78

You state in yours of Oct. 16th, that if we could give you exact specifications regarding Laundry Stove required, the Department will endeavour to secure one for us.

The stove was listed on our 1943-4 estimates as:

"Charm Laundry Stove" Page # H148, Amdown's Winnipeg.

One requisite in particular is that the stove purchased have a large surface on which the (sand) Flat Irons may be heated. A stove such as the "Charm" with top 14"x20" or somewhat larger, would be satisfactory, particularly as we could have a back placed around the outside of the Fire box, on which additional irons could be placed for heating.

We trust that this type of stove may still be obtainable as the one now in use is cracked beyond repair in several places, and may fail to please any day.

As regards a machine for the sawing of the school wood, we feel that a heavy duty stationary engine would be quite satisfactory. An engine with plenty of power to operate a saw blade 36" in diam. is required. We have no power at the present time for sawing wood, other than a small one cylinder engine which will drive the through only the small logs. I have thought to ask our man who is also in the bush to cut the logs into three foot lengths to fit into the furnaces. As soon as real cold weather sets in we will be unable to keep enough fuel cut, even if we have two or three men cutting in the bush. We trust therefore, that you may be able to assist us in procuring a stationary engine, with the least possible delay.

Thanking you,

(The Rev.) [Signature]
Principal.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your memorandum of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to our requisition of the 16th ultimo for a gasoline engine for the Sioux Lookout Residential School.

Immediately on receipt of the above memorandum I communicated with the Indian Agent and he advises me this morning that, in his opinion, the 8 to 9 H.P. motor should be supplied.

As pointed out on our requisition of November 18, this machine is required for cutting wood and the Agent again stresses the necessity of supplying a machine immediately. I, therefore, trust that you will be able to arrange for its early purchase.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Referring to Mr. Hoey's letter of November 25th File 129-6-5, with attached memorandum from the Departmental Purchasing Agent with respect to the Gasoline Engine required for the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I have to advise as follows:

At present a seven horsepower single cylinder Lister engine from the auxiliary pump-house is in use as a temporary arrangement for sawing the wood. Rev. Cheales informs me that this engine does not deliver sufficient power to saw large logs. Many of the logs used for fuel-wood are up to 20" in diameter, and with the small engine the saw will efficiently handle pieces up to about 10".

I might point out that the engine in present use should be returned to the pump-house as soon as possible in order to be available in the event of fire.

Last year the saw was driven by the 1926 Fordson tractor motor, 15-20 horse-power. If a smaller engine is supplied it would be necessary to re-model the whole sawing outfit, consequently under the circumstances I believe it would be advisable to obtain the 8-9 horse-power engine.

Re: Heating System, Principal's Residence
Sioux Lockout Indian Residential School

I have been informed by the Reverend Principal of the Sioux Lockout Indian Residential School that he has received a Hot Water Heating System from Cranes Limited, Fort William, for installing in the residence. Inspector Hamilton informs us that there is no authority for any expenditure in connection with installation of same, and apparently the School Commission will not undertake the expense.

The residence urgently requires additional heat, and it is recommended that the installation be proceeded with immediately. Until a competent steam-fitter or plumber inspects the proposed installation, it is impossible for me to give an estimate of the cost. It is suggested that I be given authority to engage a competent man to submit an estimate, providing the installation is the responsibility of our Department. We have no correspondence on file here regarding the purchase of a heating unit, nor is the Reverend Principal able to shed much light on the arrangements, other than that he believes the purchase to have been made by the Commission.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Referring to Mr. Phelan's letter of January 10th, File 129-6-5, with respect to heating system for the Principal's residence at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I wish to report as follows:

Rev. Cheales informs us that the new plant, which includes radiators and pipes, was purchased by the Commission at considerable cost, and that they do not now wish to go to the expense of the installation. Personally I am not sure that the new radiators are required. To install same would involve a considerable amount of labour and expense which might be avoided if the present radiators could be used with a new heating plant. Last fall when Mr. Carroll, the local plumber and steam fitter, was attending to the sewage system at the School, he made a hasty examination of the existing heating system in the Principal's residence and made certain recommendations or suggestions for improving same, but as I recall, this would not run into a large sum of money.

This portion of the school certainly requires additional heat and it is recommended that either the Department or the School Commission make arrangements to have this attended to without further delay, and before spending any money on the installation or equipment, that a qualified man be engaged to look the situation over and submit his recommendations.

"We are now submitting quotation on a Steam Heating Boiler, Electric Condensation Pump and Receiver for use on 110Y C.C. Sioux Lookout, Ontario,

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

We have a letter from the Indian Residential School Commission in Winnipeg pointing out the need for repairs to storm windows, glazing broken panes, storm doors, coal chutes etc., in order to conserve heat at the Sioux Lookout School, particularly in the basement. If this does not prove satisfactory, the alternative suggested of installing separate steam heating plant for the Principal's residence would appear to be the only solution. The letter goes on to state that since the school was erected by the Department it is therefore a governmental responsibility, and we are requested to arrange to have the necessary work done, before winter sets in. The attached extract of a letter from Cranes Limited, was enclosed with this letter.

Rev. Cheales, the Principal, informs us that approximately $500.00 is owing to Cranes Ltd., for material supplied during the past six months. He has requested that the Department pay this account. Since the negotiations for the work and materials were carried out directly between the School and Cranes, I am not familiar with the arrangements, although I do know that during the sub-zero weather the Principal's residence is very cold. Some time in the fall of 1943 it appears that the Principal or the School Commission ordered a complete new heating system from Cranes and after it was delivered to the school, it was found that it was not exactly what was required. I understand part of the material was used, the rest returned.

From the foregoing you will see that it is somewhat difficult for me to make any specific recommendations at this stage. However I felt that this should be brought to your attention and the matter presented as I see it.

G. A. Swetman,
Indian Agent.

Re: Circular Saw for Sioux Lookout Indian School.

I am writing this letter independent of my report because a circular saw is needed and the purchase should not be delayed.

Wood is used for fuel and the logs sawn are from 6 inches to fourteen inches in diameter; therefore a large saw is required. The one in use is cracked, and in my opinion unsafe. The Indian boys assist in the work and when the saw is cracked it is possible for a portion to come apart. The saw travels at a terrific speed and should only be in operation when the equipment is in first-class working order.

The saw required should be at least 36 inches in diameter, although 38 inches would be even better.

I understand from Mumford & Medland that a 36" saw will cost $47.00 and a 38" saw will cost $54.00, f.o.b. Toronto, both subject to 30% discount. It might be advisable to purchase the saw in the East and have it shipped direct to Mr. Cheales, Principal of the School, thus avoiding any unnecessary delay.

A.G. Hamilton,

The kitchen range is apparently quite old and in need of several repair parts. I suggested to the Principal that he list the parts needed and find out if they are available; and if so, the price. The wash sink leaks and consequently dirty water has got in around the stand which holds the tubs. The result is quite a sour smell. These tanks should be renewed.

The kitchen floor is cement and very hard on the feet. If Battleship linoleum is available the floor should be covered. The full size of the kitchen is 16' x 25'. All should be covered, but if funds are not available, then the portion most essential measures 10' x 16'. This is between the kitchen range and the table where the staff member does most of the work. AA quality of linoleum should be supplied.

The boiler room was quite tidy and the equipment in fair condition. This boiler room is very cold and a lot of heat is lost even before it reaches the school. I would recommend that the roof of the room be sealed in with plaster board and gyprock insulation be used overhead. The doors should be repaired and refitted. I am enclosing herewith copy of letter recently received from the Reverend Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School with regard to overhaul and repairs required for the Kermath motor. This was authorized in your letter of March 5th, 1945, File 129-6-5.

In view of the estimated cost to put the engine in running condition, and the fact that it is an old obsolete model, I thought it would be worth while to inquire if Reverend Chellas has written to the Kermath people inquiring if they have a later model, in good condition, for sale, but I presume they would have mentioned this as an alternative when submitting the report on the engine.

It might also be possible to obtain a St. Lawrence or a Buchanan engine. Both these firms, a few years ago, were manufacturing marine motors which were very suitable for this type of boat. You are probably aware that the hull is not in very good condition but it should be possible to get another year's use out of it, and the engine could be installed in a new hull which might be built locally at a reasonable figure. Another alternative which might prove more economical would be to obtain a complete new outfit, or a used boat if possible, in good condition, through the War Assets Corporation. Nothing else seems to me quite so desirable as a boat whose main characteristic should be a sturdy boat with a reliable motor, something about 25' with sufficient beam to make it sea-worthy.

In my opinion a good boat is just as necessary at this school as the lighting plant or kitchen stove, and I believe many of the difficulties at the Sioux Lookout school during the past few years have been largely due to lack of transportation. I cannot stress too strongly the necessity for taking steps to remedy this condition.

April 4th, 1945

Rev. R.B. Cheales,
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Rev. Sir:-

Your engine has just arrived and has been physically examined by our Superintendent and Shop Foreman.

I am afraid Sir, that this is one of those rare cases where Mr. Engine is just about at the last gasp. She has, practically speaking, run herself out of her useful life in the ordinary sense.

We have had quite a conference as to what to do, as we fully appreciate your circumstances and the positive necessity of having transportation this coming Summer.

The engine, unfortunately, is many years obsolete, and even at that, as during war time we are not building any parts or equipment for even standard engines, except certain models for use in the war Services, the difficulty of getting parts,- is paramount.

I appreciate also, that a change in engines would mean a complete change in your installation in the boat. And unfortunately-very few engines are available and would not be suitable.

In round figures- it would cost in the neighborhood of $500.00 to completely, rebores, and refit this engine throughout- as not only the engine proper is in badly worn shape, but all of the accessories, including the reverse gear-are also in the same condition.
We operate under Dept. M&S price formulae in our costing, limited to 5% profit on a fixed overhead.

So that, anyway, the only way we could handle it would be on this cost plus basis, which would be, of course, for your protection.

That the engine can be successfully rebuilt is without doubt, but it will require extensively building even the camshaft would have to be ground and all new bearings throughout, which are not very frequently required. The cylinders reboared, new pistons, crankshaft ground, all new bearings throughout— all new valve springs, valve guides, valves and about 75% or 80% of the reverse gear— outside of other bearings and your accessories, such as pumps, generators and distributors etc.

I am giving you this estimated figure, purely for estimated purposes, as I do not know whether your Service or the Dept. of Indian Affairs will accede to this.

If so, I would like you to let me know IMMEDIATELY and we will make every endeavor to hurry the job along as fast as possible, although I cannot give you any date when it can be shipped, as it would depend upon the services and the supply and the priorities we can obtain.

One thing is positively certain—that your engine would not have functioned very many more miles as it stood. So, whether you wish to have it replaced by some other manufacturer, or whether you want us to go ahead with this on the basis above mentioned—is for your kindly decision and may I stress again, the urgency of getting that information to us as rapidly as possible please.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Captain L.S. Webster

I quote from a letter just received from Rev. A.B. Cheales, Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School:

"As we are re-decorating the school kitchen, we would indeed like to have the linoleum to put down on this rather dreary floor. We trust that this may be obtained in some rather light, mottled green shade, with continuous pattern throughout—not a dark color.

"The chairs for pupils' dining-room, cream separator, sewing machine, toilet-seats and covers, circular-saw, and last but not least a boat of some type, are needed just as soon as ever possible.

"With our old Kermath Marine engine in Toronto, our outboard engine awaiting repairs, and no boat to put it on, when repair is available, we are indeed stranded, even as in winter. This, you will agree, is a most trying state of affairs, especially in case of sickness or accident. We trust that you may be able to convince the Indian Department of our immediate need of some type of boat with which we could at least get a pupil to hospital when deemed necessary."

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6216, file 470-5, part 6)
Schools:

During the quarter visits were made to both the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Indian Residential Schools. At McIntosh an attempt was made to have the children familiarize themselves with the outside pole-type fire escapes. The boys were very proficient but the girls, especially the younger ones were unable to use the escape with any degree of confidence. However, the Reverend Principal assured me he would see to it that they had plenty of practice in future. I might add that under certain conditions in the winter months, the iron pole fire escapes are dangerous for the inexperienced.

At the Sioux Lookout School the poles are inside the building. This arrangement permits the pupils to have more practice, although the efficiency of the arrangement is open to question. At the Sioux Lookout School twenty-two of the older pupils are enrolled in the Air Cadets. They are being trained by Miss Richardson, a staff member who was previously in the Women's Division of the RCAF. These boys are all greatly interested in this movement and look very smart in their uniforms.

At both Residential Schools in this Agency lack of recreational and athletic opportunities is very noticeable. I believe that much more thought should be given to this phase of school life, as the Indian children seem to enjoy sports and games even more than our own children do. Under proper supervision this would go a long way toward developing character and physique.

G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

We have an urgent request from Reverend Cheales to supply the Sioux Lookout School with a 2-ton Dump Truck, a Station Wagon and a Jeep.

It is expected that the new road to the Sioux Lookout School will be passable in a short time, but if the School has not any means of transportation, the road will not be of very great value. The dump truck would be required for maintaining the road and general work at the School, such as hauling wood, which is now being cut at a distance too far for economical hauling with teams. The jeep would be of considerable value in the winter time to keep the road open. The station wagon would be used mostly for transporting the children to and from the school and for emergency hospital cases as well as numerous other important uses.

During the interval between treaty payments, I took the opportunity to visit Pelican School, in company with Mr. Swartman. Generally the condition of the school was good, but attention should be drawn to two features which have in one case direct, and in the other indirect relation to the physical welfare of the pupils. Firstly, the boys' dormitory and to a lesser extent the girls' are overcrowded. In the former the beds are so close that they touch at the sides. This is bad, especially where the children are as susceptible to respiratory disease and tuberculosis as are Indians. It might be possible to put up quarters outside the school for the farm employees, who at present occupy an entire upper dormitory, freeing this space for pupils. Alternatively, double-decker beds, 18" to 2' apart, would be better from a droplet-infection standpoint. Until something permanent can be done, the pupils should sleep head to foot alternately. I do not wish to be over-critical, but from the standpoint of public health the designation of a couple of three-bed rooms in Indian schools as preventoria is a travesty; if the entire residential school is not a preventorium what are we spending our money for?
Extract from Report of Gordon L. BELL, M.B., Physician & Surgeon, Sioux Lookout, Ont., dated October 12, 1945 (September report) regarding Medical Services rendered to the Indians of Sioux Lookout Agency.

I wish to submit the following report on the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School inspected April 16, 1946.

At present there are enrolled Boys - 74, Girls - 83, a total of 157 Pupils. The grades are arranged in three classrooms and the pupils are making fair progress.

The dormitories were tidy and the beds neatly made. The beds are very close together and I am convinced that there is overcrowding.

One small dormitory about 16' x 36' x 10' high is used to accommodate staff members. If this were used for the pupils it would certainly relieve the crowded situation in the larger dormitories.

The laundry was not in use on the day of inspection. The stove used for heating the flat irons is only a cheap sheet metal stove and should be replaced at once. If a proper laundry stove is not available then a small kitchen range should be provided. I instructed Mr. Cheales, the Principal, to have the stove moved at once from its present location and to see that the pipes are made secure and the flue will be closed with sheet metal. For some unknown reason the owner had set the stove in one corner of the laundry room and the fire box and pipes were almost against the wall.

In my last report I stated that the building needed painting throughout and gave a list of paint which was supplied. Mr. Cheales stated he had been unable to secure his help and so none of the paint has been used. If this school is to be put in good condition a foreman with at least three helpers should be engaged for a month or six weeks. This work should be done in the summer while the children are away on holidays. The work should be started at one end of the building, and carried out in a methodical manner from top to bottom.

A night watchman has been provided but on checking I find that the stations were only punched at 12, 2 and 4. I instructed Mr. Cheales that in the future the night watchman should make hourly rounds, starting at 9 p.m. and continuing until 6 a.m. He should visit all the stations and use his punch clock. In this way there would be an accurate record and reasonable protection.
The school is heated with wood. The supply at the school is small. The policy at this point in the past has been to start in and get the wood as required during the fall and winter. The pupils assist with the work. I think in fairness to the pupils and for the safety of all that there should always be available at the school at least a four months' supply of wood. I consider it the Principal's duty to hire men to cut, saw and split the wood before the snow is heavy and dangerous. I would request that this matter be brought to the attention of the Principal and also Dr. Alderwood.

At present eight cows are being milked. The supply of milk fluctuates about 15 gallons at night and 10 or 12 gallons in the morning. Cheese is now made to freshen so the quantity will gradually be increased.

Mr. Cheales stated that each week he received from plowing approximately 360 lbs. of beef, 70 lbs. of fish and 26 dozen eggs. He allowed the children one meal with two eggs each, two meals of fish although it appears slim rations. The arrangement leaves four days or about 640 meals that must be provided for with the 260 lbs. of beef of which probably 40 or 50 lbs. is bone. I consider the meat ration insufficient.

A quantity of vegetables was grown at the school; but if the information supplied by Mr. Cheales is correct the children must have received a very light helping of potatoes. He stated their crop of 180 bushels lasted for six weeks. I purchased bread for 1½ pence, most of them growing children could only provide a small helping and certainly no second serving. I would like to see the pupils provided with a good serving of meat, potatoes, gravy and if possible one other vegetable. Such a meal with a good helping of warm bread and dessert would I am sure provide a fairly adequate meal. Bread is used as a spread on bread and for some desserts the bread is spread with peanut butter, jam, honey, syrup or black molasses. Other desserts consist of pudding, dried apples, or prunes. The variety is quite good, but the quantity per individual at times appears small.

There has been a lot of sickness at the school during the winter; and some of the children appear pale and somewhat run down. No doubt now that the warm weather has come the children will be out more and health conditions will improve.

The war years has made it difficult to secure suitable staff help. At present several new working are well along in years and would recommend that as soon as possible they be able to replace the younger men and women. A younger staff would be more interested in the projects and would be able to join the pupils in these amusements. They would also have a greater capacity for work. Mr. Cheales claims some of the members are not physically fit to carry out the duties which go along with their position, thus it is impossible to keep the school as clean and tidy as is expected. The question of staff was also mentioned in my previous report.

I am enclosing a classroom Growth Record Chart published by the Manitoba Department of Health and Public Welfare. I believe a similar chart should be issued to all.

Dear Sir:

We refer to your letter of May 10th, 1946, in which you quote a paragraph from Inspector Hamilton's visit to our Sioux Lookout Residential School. We agree that the availability of wood for immediate consumption was no doubt low at the time of the inspector's visit but feel Inspector Hamilton has promoted a completely wrong impression, inasmuch as stating, and I quote: "I consider it the Principal's duty to cut, saw and supply the wood because the work is heavy and dangerous. We have for several years employed at least three men for wood-cutting and sawing and have throughout this entire winter retained them at salaries and food costing in excess of $1,230.00 for the year. To elaborate on my point may I quote you a paragraph from a letter received in this office April 29th from our Principal. "We have three men still working at the wood, and assigning Mr. William (Farm Instructor) in other ways, who will be entitled to another months' salary early next week. Will you please, therefore, send us the amount requested ($300.00) that we may pay the men and keep our account (fuel) in the local bank in good standing?"

I personally visited the school last fall and wood-cutting operations were under way but the boys did not appear to be doing more than the normal task of stacking the cut-lengths into piles. Dr. Alderwood and I feel confident that you need have no worry in respect to the boys being over-worked or employed in a highly dangerous occupation.

You will perhaps recall the statement in Dr. Gordon Bell's report mentioning the fact that school dormitory space was at that time being utilized for a gang of labourers. This happened so be our wood-cutters and although we feel alternative arrangements must and will be made for their accommodation in the future; it proves beyond doubt that we had employed men for this very purpose.

Thank you for drawing Inspector Hamilton's comment to

Dear Sirs,

Re: Estimates for current year
Painting of school interior

On our list of estimates for the year 1946 submitted through local Indian Agent August 31/45, you will please note we listed:

Building of a garage $500.00
" " " dock $400.00
Material for well $300.00

We have already converted an outshed into a garage large enough for two cars; the school well is apparently in need of little repair, while the construction of a dock can be postponed for another year. I would urge that the amount of $1200.00 be granted to meet a more urgent need.

You will note from Doctor Bell's report on his last visit to our school, his statement that the whole interior of the school is in need of painting this summer. When Mr. Hamilton visited our school last year he remarked how much it was in need of re-decorating. On his recommendation over fifty gallons of paint was provided by your department for this purpose. This paint is still on hand. We have endeavoured for months to get local men to do the work, but all seem to have too much work in town to come out to the school. Again, on his recent visit just a few weeks ago, Mr. Hamilton agreed we need a crew of five or six painters to undertake and complete the work while the pupils are on holiday.

Might I suggest therefore, that approximately $1200.00 of the amount granted by your Department to our school for this year, go toward painting of the school and residence interior. Furthermore, since we have been unable to obtain painters locally, will you please authorize either Mr. Swartman (absent for several weeks on treaty) or the Principal of the school, to secure painters wherever possible that the work may be begun early in July.

Secondly, in regard to current year's estimates, we listed:

Building of a small storehouse $500.00
Small Ammonium refrig. Plant $700.00

It will not be possible to have this storehouse built this year. Might we suggest therefore, that about $1200.00 be granted
ward either of the following:

1. Having the school linked up with the Hydro line, via the new school road, which would require approximately three miles of poles and wiring.

2. Constructing of a small residence near the school for the use of the Farmer or Engineer, both of whom are often married men desiring a separate residence.

As to the other items on our list of estimates, we still require them as listed, namely:

- Chairs, dining room: 1 dozen: $50.00
- Cream Separator large: $60.00

Thanking you,

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Neary's letter of July 19th File 129-6-5 (W.T. 1), with respect to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I only recently had an opportunity to discuss the situation with Reverend Cheales, and my impression is that he is very much discouraged and feels that he has not been given the consideration he deserves both by the School Commission and the Department. I understand he is resigning in the near future.

Regarding requirements, Rev. Cheales has already stated these, and from what I have seen, every item listed is a necessity. My recommendations are as follows:

1. Paint, and all materials necessary for the painting, should be supplied immediately, including lime for patting the walls and arrangements made to hire painters to do the necessary work. The work to be done as soon as paint can be supplied and painters are available. This has already been recommended by Inspector Hamilton, and a fairly recent report from Doctor Bell indicates the necessity of this work. The whole interior is so dingy and drab that it must be as depressing for the staff as it is for the pupils.

2. A portion of the linoleum on the floor in the kitchen and dining room should be re-laid. There should be cement set between the cement floor and the linoleum, and this should be well cemented in order to keep it from bulging.

3. Mattresses are urgently required—approximately two dozen. We have no record during the past five years of mattresses being supplied to this School.

4. Chairs are also badly needed. During the term, many of the children had to sit on boxes around the dining-room tables. In the winter, these boxes should be replaced. We have had some of the Indian parents tell us that while their children are at home they at least have chairs to sit on, if they wish, and in many cases this is quite true.

5. A complete installation of eaves-troughing is required. This should be arranged so that it may be taken down in the fall, as the ice and snow which accumulate on the roof in the winter has a tendency to break the eave-trough. Without eaves-troughing the rain runs off the roof and finally into the playrooms. This of course makes the playrooms useless during a rainy period.

Dear Sir,

Re. File I29-6-5

We have as yet hardly recovered from the discouraging note in yours of June 19th., to the effect that your department has allotted the sum of but $500. for the current year's requirements at our school. It is inconceivable, to say the least, just why this school should be practically overlooked in this way, despite the fact that both Inspector Hamilton of the Indian Affairs, Winnipeg, and Dr. Bell, (the school Doctor) strongly recommended, on their recent visit to the school, that improvements be made.

You state further that you are prepared to allow a slightly larger amount if the work recommended is absolutely essential. I wish to go on record in reporting that such work as mentioned in the accompanying list is absolutely essential. Furthermore, unless a considerable sum is spent on repair and redecorating of the school building soon, it will not be a suitable place in which to house from 140 to 160 children and 17 of a staff. For instance, even as I write there are pools of water all over the floors in school basement, pupil's playroom, dining room and kitchen, from rain which has been falling intermittently for three days and running directly in through cracks in the foundation. Reason, no eave troughs ever put on school building, rain water rests on narrow walk round foundation causing depressions and cracks through which it runs into basement. Only solution I can see, is repair to foundation and eave troughs. Then again, the school veranda roof, not having sufficient slope, and many nail holes, leaks like a sieve, resulting in pools of water, //and, if cold enough, ice forming on veranda and fire escape stairs. We have applied tremco roofing, which lasts for a season, but if snow and ice left on roof during winter this material comes off with it. A solution would be putting more of a slope to the roof, and applying tremco or shingles.

As to redecorating interior of school, might I urge the need for action in this. The whole interior is terribly drab, dull, and prison like, never having been painted in over fifteen years. Being unable to obtain painters last summer I painted ceiling of pupil's dining room, and one dormitory myself. I found it a most tedious task -- alone -- and I do not intend a similar venture this summer. There being but one man here besides myself during the summer, and no boys, we can do little or nothing in this regard. The only way therefore, to get the job done satisfactorily and in record time, is to hire a number of painters, locally or elsewhere.

Dear Reverend Sir:

I attach a copy of a letter which I have sent today to Indian Agent Swartman. You will note that we are going ahead with practically all the repairs which you have requested.

This has been a most difficult summer for departmental officials. There has been a very heavy flood of requests for repairs, improvements and replacements from practically every Residential School in Canada. This had been anticipated as a natural result of the war years. But coupled with this have been the increases in costs of materials and labour. As a result we have been very sorely pressed to spread our very limited appropriations over the wide range of expensive requests received.

Your letter is but one of the many that have been received, pointing out the urgent needs for repairs and improvements. We allotted you $500.00 as a temporary measure in our letter of June 19. During the summer we have kept your needs among the most urgent and pressing. Now we are in a position to allot more money. We hope you will understand the circumstances. If you could but see those appealing letters, you would better realize our position.

When this year's repairs are completed, will you discuss thoroughly with Indian Agent Swartman your next year's requirements, so that they will be ready for submission by him for appropriations.

Re:- Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

We have your letter of the 23rd instant drawing to our notice our lack of attention to this subject.

Due to lack of personnel available in this office, we had our Resident Engineer at Keewatin accompany Mr. Swartman, Indian Agent, on an inspection of this Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, some six weeks ago. However, his report was not in sufficient detail to permit us to outline definitely what was considered necessary and some additional data were required. These data have now been received and we are having a plan prepared, together with an outline of what is considered necessary to overcome their difficulties. As the work will involve excavation and etc., it is not considered advisable to proceed with the same during the present fiscal year. However, an estimate of what is required together with the probable cost will be prepared and forwarded so that money can be made available early in the coming fiscal year.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Food Survey of Nine Indian Residential Schools.

I attach for your study copies of reports made upon nine Indian Residential Schools by dietitians of the Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare.

On the whole these are fairly satisfactory with one exception - that of Sioux Lookout Residential School.

In this instance, the former Principal as you know, was not satisfactory and was removed from his duties in the middle of September. He was replaced by the Reverend Mr. Fisher, former Principal of Lac la Ronge Indian Residential School. At the time Miss McCready visited this school, Mr. Fisher had only been there a fortnight. He has since visited the office and I feel certain that he will do everything possible to improve conditions at this school. I have suggested to Miss McCready that she visit this school again in the near future.

It is my intention to do as follows with these reports:

(a) To send one copy to the Religious denomination concerned with the request that they be passed to the Principals of the schools inspected.

(b) After the Head Office has seen copies of these reports, then I would like to send them to the

Indian Agents concerned for whatever action on their part is indicated. Then I would have them returned to this office for file.

1. The use of better equipment, especially potato peelers, stainless steel dishwashing sinks, and a better quality of dishes.

TORONTO, ONT. 28th May, 1965

41-43 The Bible House,
Alexander Ave., Winnipeg, Man.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Architect for the Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Orr:

I enclose herewith for your information a copy of my report to our Indian and Eskimo Commission on the site for the proposed School for the Lac Seul area. This report has been adopted by the Commission, and in due course our General Secretary will forward to your Department the action taken by the Executive Committee of our Society on the same.

An effort is being made to secure the services of the Rev. J.F.J. Marshall, Missionary to the Indians at Jack River, Norway House, for the position of Acting Principal from July 1st next. As he is now receiving $100.00 a month Bishop Dewdney is apprehensive that he may not be willing to accept a smaller amount.

In my opinion he is well worth the $100.00 and believe it would be to the advantage of your Department to secure him at this rate and pay his travelling expenses to Sioux Lookout, rather than engage an inferior man at a smaller allowance.

I should, I suppose, address this letter with the enclosure either to the Secretary or to the Deputy Superintendent General, but I am forwarding it to you in keeping with my promise in this connection.

With kind regards,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.O.C.

Ottawa, June 2,
1925

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo enclosing a report with reference to our trip to the Lac Seul area for the purpose of selecting a site for the new residential school. I understand that the Rev. Mr. Marshall is a very practical man, and if he is appointed as Acting Principal it might be possible that we could arrange to employ him as Inspector of Construction on the work and in that way pay his salary. This matter will be taken up as soon as the contract is let for the building.

I may say that the Ontario government have been communicated with officially with reference to the land we selected, but to date we have not heard from them. As soon as the site has been secured I will be glad to advise you.

Yours very truly,

R. CUMBERLAND,
Architect for the Department.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6216, file 470-5, part 8)
Ottawa, 16 January 1947.

Mr. G. Swartman, Indian Agent,
SIoux LOOKOUT, Ontario.

With reference to our telephone conversation this afternoon, I wish to confirm the authority given you to purchase a new jacket heater and boiler from Vulcan Iron Works, Winnipeg, at a cost of approximately $930.00. It is understood that this is an emergency replacement at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Please let me have a written communication from your office regarding the matter in order that we may have written information for our Purchasing Branch.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Sioux Lookout, Ontario,
13th January 1947.

Mr. G. Swartman,
The Indian Agency,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As I reported to you by telephone a few days ago, the hot-water jacket for supplying hot water to the whole of our school building cracked in such a way that it has been found impossible to repair it by welding. This means it will be necessary for a new one to be supplied as early as possible.

May I ask you to take immediate steps to approach the Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, with a view to obtaining the necessary replacement.

From my personal observation since coming here last September, I would say the old hot-water jacket was not large enough. There never appeared to be sufficient hot water for our needs, and I would suggest that the Department be asked to supply something rather larger, possibly more of the boiler type of heater. The hot water storage tank is of about 2000 gallons capacity, and this should be a guide as to what is required.

I feel sure the Department will not need to be reminded of the urgency of this matter, as at the present time we are entirely without hot water throughout the building, and we are hard put to it to carry on the laundry, wash rooms, and kitchen.

I am,
Yours faithfully,

(signed) G.W. Fisher,
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to report that the hot water jacket heater at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School is broken. An expert welder from one of the local garages examined it and reported that repairs would be impossible. It had cracked a few years ago and temporary repairs were made at that time.

Vulcan Iron Works in Winnipeg advise they can supply a suitable unit for $935.00. This is larger than the one originally installed and should prove adequate to take care of the 2,000 gal. hot water storage tank.

In view of the urgency of the matter I am phoning the Dept. today. A copy of Mr. Fishzer's report on the subject is attached hereto.

May 23rd, 1947.

Mr. G. Swartman,
The Indian Agency,
SIOUX LOOKOUT, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing an estimate of the cost of providing dwelling space for locally hired staff, who at present occupy Dormitory "C" in the school building. With a pupilage of 71 boys this dormitory is urgently needed to provide adequate space for these boys.

If part of our present warehouse is taken for the above project, it will be necessary to provide additional warehouse space. This can be done by making a floor three feet below the plate of the building used for an ice-house, which would give an icehouse with nine foot walls, with warehouse space above. The warehouse would be entered by building an outside stairway.

The prices given are approximate, and are based on prices for material obtained from the Beaver Lumber Co., and the Patricia Lumber Co., of Sioux Lookout.

It is hoped the Department of Indian Affairs will see its way clear to provide funds for this work.

As you know, the whole of the interior of the School building requires re-decorating, and even if the Department were to provide the necessary materials, it would not be possible for the school staff to undertake this work. We are short-handed at present, and the everyday work of the school must fill available time. May I ask you to place this matter before the Department with a request that the work of repairing and redecorating of the buildings be placed in the hands of competent contractors. If this were done I feel sure a more efficient job could be done.

It would be of great help if a decision in this matter could be obtained without delay, so that if possible all this work could be done during the Summer vacation.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines
and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to report that the hot water jacket heater at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School is broken. An expert welder from one of the local garages examined it and reported that repairs would be impossible. It had cracked a few years ago and temporary repairs were made at that time.

Vulcan Iron Works in Winnipeg advise they can supply a suitable unit for $935.00. This is larger than the one originally installed and should prove adequate to take care of the 2,000 gal. hot water storage tank.

In view of the urgency of the matter I am phoning the Dept. today. A copy of Mr. Fisher's report on the subject is attached hereto.

(Sgd.) G. Swartman,
Indian Agent.
Sioux Lookout, Ontario,
13th January 1947.

Mr. G. Swartman,
Indian Agency,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

Dear Sir:

As I reported to you by telephone a few days ago, the hot water jacket for supplying hot water to the whole of our school building cracked in such a way that it has been found impossible to repair it by welding. This means it will be necessary for a new one to be supplied as early as possible.

May I ask you to take immediate steps to approach the Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, with a view to obtaining the necessary replacement.

From my personal observation since coming here last September, I would say the old hot water jacket was not large enough. There never appeared to be sufficient hot water for our needs, and I would suggest that the Department be asked to supply something rather larger, possibly more of the boiler type of heater. The hot water storage tank is of about 2,000 gallons capacity, and this should be a guide as to what is required.

I feel sure the Department will not need to be reminded of the urgency of this matter, as at the present time we are entirely without hot water throughout the building, and we are hard put to it to carry on the laundry, wash rooms and kitchen.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) G.W. Fisher,
Principal.

Dear Sirs:

Sometime ago Mr. Swartman told me he had received a reply from you authorizing the building improvements asked for in my letter of May 23rd.

As you are aware, Indian Agent Swartman has since written saying that the rough lumber required to make storage space in the school ice house could be obtained locally at lower prices than those quoted in my letter. Mr. Swartman gave me authority to purchase this material.

In thinking over matters, I have come to the conclusion that rough lumber could be used in the place of the ship-lap asked for, without impairing the appearance of the work in hand, since this lumber would in any case be covered by wall board.

Since the lumber required, will be made from trees cut on the School's concessions, there will be no stumpage dues, therefore the saw-mill operator will supply rough lumber for $45.00 per M. B. M. I shall be glad if you could send me an accountable cheque for the $175.00 allowed for labour costs.

I am,

Yours faithfully,

Memorandum

Mr. D.B. Gow
Re: Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

On Thursday, June 26, an examination was made of the above mentioned school with the view of determining the cause of leakage of water into certain parts of the school's basement, together with a suggested remedy and estimate of cost.

At times of rain it was reported that considerable water leaks through the front wall of the building and to a lesser extent through a side wall into the kitchen and girls' lavatory (see accompanying sketch). Good natural drainage is provided on three sides of the building. In front of the school, where the serious leakage occurs, a level lawn extends some 50 feet to an embankment. There are no eavestroughs on the building; consequently all storm water from the roof falls at the foundation walls, causing erosion scouring. A three-foot concrete walk in the form of a shallow "U" has been built partially around the school to prevent scouring and to lead the water away. This walk is now badly broken, very uneven, and has pulled away from the foundation walls. Instead of leading water from the foundation, it retains much water allowing it to seep through the ground near the foundation.

It is believed the following work would remedy the existing situation:

1. Damp proof the north foundation wall from grade to footing,
2. Lay 4" field tile along this front wall at floor elevation connected to a line of tile leading to the edge of the embankment.
3. Rebuild the grade in the vicinity of the kitchen and girls' lavatory to allow rainwater to run away from the building.

D.B. Gow, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
