MEMORANDUM

Re: Indian Residential Schools,
Sicamous Indian Agency, Ont.

Your attention is directed to our memorandum of October 26th, 1946, with which we forwarded a copy of Mr. Dew's letter of October 26th, 1946, replying to our request for an inspection report and estimate of cost for the repair of certain faults which had developed at the above schools.

It is evident that Mr. Dew did not have staff available to carry out this assignment until June 26th last, at which time Mr. Stormeter carried out an inspection. Under date of July 7th last, Mr. Stormeter submitted a report to Mr. Dew with an estimate of cost. Copies of the report and Mr. Dew's covering letter are attached for your information.

It will be observed that Mr. Stormeter confines his report to conditions affecting the school basement, and that no reference is made to ventilating repairs, the need for which was pointed out to Mr. Dew when the matter was initiated by our letter to him dated August 26th, 1946.

On analyzing Mr. Stormeter's report, it appears that he considers three items of work would prevent infiltration of water into the basement, namely:

1. Damp proofing the north foundation wall from grade to footings.
2. Lay a line of 4" field tile along this front wall at floor elevation, connected to a line of tile leading to the edge of the embankment.
3. Rebuild the grade in the vicinity of the kitchen and girls' lavatory, to allow rainwater to run away from the building.

Commenting on these items we may say that in Item 1, we feel from Mr. Stormeter's estimate of cost, the type of damp proofing in mind, is an application of pitch or waterproof paint to the exterior of the north wall. If conditions are as described by the Reverend Principal, from whom a quotation was contained in Mr. Hoey's memorandum of August 19th, 1946, and in Mr. Stormeter's attached report, this treatment will not be satisfactory. It is recommended that a concrete waterproofing be applied to the exterior of the north foundation wall, consisting of two layers of heavy asphalt saturated felt with three coats of pitch binder applied hot. Over the membrane waterproofing there should be applied a protective coating one inch thick, composed of one part of cement to 5 parts of sand, to which should be added hydrated lime, amounting to 10% of the volume of cement. This treatment should be satisfactory for the north wall.

Referring to Item 2, the laying of a line of 4" field tile along the northerly wall, connecting to a runoff through the embankment should be satisfactory.

Enclosure,

Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,

Dear Sir:

Re: Estimates 1948-49,
Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

The Principal of the above-mentioned school advises that the following services are needed. They are listed in the order of urgency indicated by him and with his remarks:

(a) MAJOR REPAIRS TO BUILDINGS

Departmental Engineers have inspected the cracks in our foundations and the useless cement footing. Parts of the basement become flooded during periodical heavy rains, causing much inconvenience and discomfort. The footing should be removed, the foundations laid bare, and either tar, Tremco or Aquella applied to seal all cracks.

(b) MAJOR REPAIRS TO WATER SUPPLY

There is an auxiliary or emergency pump engine in the pump house situated on the lake shore by the well. In case of emergency, water cannot be pumped by this engine from the well as the short piece of intake pipe from the well to the pump was cracked by frost two or three years ago and never repaired or replaced. At present, in case of emergency, water is pumped direct from the lake through a length of 2-inch piping. In winter there are obvious difficulties with this, and repairs should be effected before the frost sets in.

The well is about 4½ feet square and about 8-10 feet deep. There is a bad crack horizontally about 6 inches wide just below the water level. This needs repairing and sand and dirt which has washed in needs to be cleaned out.
(c) NEW CONSTRUCTION OF BUILDINGS

An outside residence, preferably an eight-roomed duplex centrally heated to serve as married quarters for either farm instructor or engineer and also as quarters for the night watchman and permanent outside helper or for the accommodation of Indian visitors. There is more visiting here than I have found elsewhere.

With a full staff there is no waiting room in the school for visitors, no guest room, and, of course, no suitable accommodation for married staff members. There is a general shortage of storage rooms.

(d) WARDROBES

Additional wardrobes of the type commonly supplied by the Department, for the children's clothing. At least a dozen could be built in the passage on the second floor, and another two or three dozen could be built into the four main dormitories. There is a general shortage of these.

(e) GYMNASIUM AND WORKSHOP

A two-storey outside building to serve as a gymnasium and workshop is desirable.

(f) BREAD SLICING MACHINE

A bread slicing machine (110 volt D.C.) is needed in a school with a large enrolment to eliminate one of the chores. Miss McCready, a recent visitor from the Nutrition Division, Dept. of National Health & Welfare, has strongly recommended this addition to our kitchen facilities.

(g) REPLACEMENT OF GARAGE

The shed which serves as a garage is fit to collapse and its foundation also needs repair. It should be torn down and rebuilt as far as possible with the lumber salvaged to serve as a combined garage and workshop.

(h) WATER LINE

Owing presumably to the site of the former water tower, water is at present pumped into the school tanks by a circuitous channel and the lift is something like 25 feet. It could be brought by a straight and shorter course from flowing water and the lift reduced to 10 feet.

As mentioned in a previous letter, I am not certain whether you can assist us in the provision of machinery but,
in case you can, I quote the following from the Principal's submission:

"Medium-sized Fordson Tractor for general farm work.

The school formerly owned one. There is a good deal of land, heavy clay for the most part, which could be cultivated more economically and efficiently with a tractor than with horses. A fair amount of freighting has to be done throughout the year and our local roads are bad. A tractor would help to keep roads open and do heavy hauling."

Anything you can do towards the inclusion of these services in your Departmental Estimates for 1948-49 will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Insulating of Attic,
Anglican Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ont.

In a recent letter the Principal of our school at Sioux Lookout mentioned the need of insulating the attic, pointing out that a considerable saving in fuel would be effected if this were done.

I wrote him for particulars and in reply he stated that he understood that your Agent there had requisitioned 1,000 bags of Zonolite for this service and that he understood that your Purchasing Branch had invited tenders for its supply.

Later I requested the Principal to make inquiry of your Agent and find out how the matter stood. He has just replied that he has been in touch with your Agent who has informed him that the work had not been approved by Ottawa.

The Principal goes on to say that, apart from the heavy consumption of fuel, the fact that the attic is not insulated creates a dangerous situation which he describes as follows:

"The entire roof of this school is covered with metal sheeting. Snow settles on it and since a great deal of heat goes out through the roof, this thaws and freezes into ice. Dangerous icicles form and falling ice sheets are a positive menace to the children, particularly on the girls' side. One or two in recent times have had narrow escapes from serious injury or death. The wooden outside steps from the chapel and the cement walk around the footing of the school show evidence of this periodical battering.

"From the point of view of efficiency and economy, it
would be money well spent to insulate this building."

The Principal advises that the only expenditure necessary would be the actual cost of the insulating material because his engineer is an experienced carpenter and builder who can easily perform the work of installing the insulation.

I understand that some funds still remain in the allotment provided in your 1947-48 Estimates for this school which would go far towards the cost of the insulating material. If this is correct and if there is no technical objection to installing this insulation, it will be appreciated if the matter can be reconsidered. It would appear from what has transpired that the Principal's recommendation has the support of your Agent.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Heating System - Anglican Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout

The Principal (of the above School) reports as follows on the heating system:

"The trouble here seems to be that steam condenses in the pipes at certain points to create blockage. Classrooms, situated on the wings, become unpleasantly cold at times, while the principal's residence, an annex at the east end, is notoriously cold in the winter. It is my opinion that a steam engineer should inspect this place for the Department (perhaps a local expert from the C.N.R.). It may be that the formation of air or water pockets in the pipes can be obviated by relatively small changes. None of the radiators are provided with valves."

Could it be arranged that an engineer from either the Surveys & Engineering Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, or the Department of Public Works who may be proceeding west in the near future stop off at Sioux Lookout and look over this plant with a view to determining the remedy required? Failing this perhaps, as the Principal suggests, the C.N.R. would be prepared to let one of their engineers passing through Sioux Lookout look into the matter.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Refrigeration Facilities,
Anglican Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario

Recently I have been drawing the attention of several of our Principals to the extremely uneconomic practice of purchasing small quantities of meat at a time and in every case the reason given is lack of refrigeration facilities. I then asked for reports on the existing refrigeration facilities.

As regards Sioux Lookout, the Principal's report is as follows:

"Our refrigeration facilities are certainly not modern. Outside there is an icehouse which probably stands on poor foundations since it has settled on one side. Here it is very difficult to keep a week's supply of fresh meat and fish in good condition during the summer months. Inside the school, in the pantry, there is an old-fashioned icebox refrigerator, 5 ft. high by 4 ft. wide by 27 ins. deep.

I rather think that Mr. Fisher requested from the Department as part of the 1947 appropriation for this school an ammonia refrigerating unit operated by 110 V. D.C. electric plant. The locker would have to be big enough to hold up to about 400 lbs. meat, etc. There is room in the pantry for a good-sized Frigidaire or similar unit capable of serving the domestic needs of a school of this size. Perhaps I should add that the principal's residence has a smallish ice-box refrigerator which seems to be very imperfectly insulated."

I imagine that, if the various services we have requested already for this school (insulation of attic, overhaul
of heating system, provision of heaters) are carried out, the allotment in this year's estimates for this school will be exhausted. Further, I presume that your Departmental Estimates for 1948-49 already are prepared and it is now too late to make special provision for any additional items in them. However, I presume also that, following your normal practice, you have made some provision in your 1948-49 Estimates for general services at each school, including Sioux Lookout, and perhaps this would cover the provision of adequate refrigeration facilities there next spring; if not, would you be good enough to keep this service in mind when you prepare your Supplementary Estimates for 1948-49?

The storage of meat, fish, etc., should present no problem at Sioux Lookout from now until the end of next winter but I would like to see more adequate refrigeration installed there before the warm weather sets in next year.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

Re: New Equipment (Electrical) For the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School

The following information is required:

1. A detailed description of the generator now in use including all available information regarding watts capacity, voltage, speed and type of winding. Nameplates are usually furnished on the generator giving this information.

2. Describe in detail the control panel listing all equipment and describe exactly how the prime mover is controlled i.e., whether automatic relay electric start, manual push button electric start or by some other method.

3. Have the controls given any trouble in the past and if so state fully and give dates. Are the controls now operating satisfactorily?

4. Determine how many days the fully charged battery will supply the load demand before recharging is necessary.

5. List the wattage of all lighting outlets, appliances and motors (indicating their service) in use in each building supplied by the lighting plant and state the time in hours each is used daily. Observations should be taken each day over a period of one week, the results tabulated and forwarded with the report.

6. Prepare a sketch showing the relative locations of all buildings supplied with electricity and indicate the distance between same. Mark the location of power plant and power lines between buildings.

7. Give any additional information in detail concerning the operation of the equipment at the school, that requires power in its operation, and which may have a bearing on the size of the diesel electric unit required.
Yesterday we had Mr. L. A. Anderson of the Fairbanks Morse Co., of Winnipeg, visiting the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School for the purpose of inspecting the pumping equipment etc.

His recommendation is to replace the present generating unit with a complete new Diesel 110 Volt A.C. outfit. This would mean that a separate electric motor would be used to drive the line shaft or a motor for each of the various pieces of equipment operated by electric power. Such an outfit would cost in excess of $6,000.00 which is probably out of the question. Mr. Anderson informs us that the Fairbanks Morse stock a Continental motor 20 H.P. at $850.00 which is immediately available to replace the Lister. He also reports that the generator requires an overhaul. The bearings are loose and the commutator is worn. This should be attended to immediately. The auxiliary pump is also reported beyond repair and should be replaced with a new 2500 gallon typhoon pump.

Some years ago I recommended that an investigation should be made as to the possibility of extending the hydro into the school. There is at present a power line to the Radio Range Station situated approximately two miles from the school.

GS/VE

IMPORTANT FACTORS which should be taken into consideration in selecting an Engine.

HORSE POWER AND GOVERNOR SPEED at which Engine is to be operated. Variable Speed Control Fitting can be supplied as an extra.

ROTATION—Engines will be supplied with Rotation Clockwise looking at Flywheel with flywheel on right hand side.

COOLING—State whether the Engine is required for Temperate or Tropical Climate and whether Tank or Radiator cooling system is required. State whether load is continuous or intermittent.

AIR CLEANERS—Engines to be operated under Dusty or Gritty conditions should always be fitted with efficient Air Cleaning equipment. A Lister Air Cleaner is suitable for average dirty conditions. The Cyclone type or the Vertical type for more severe conditions where abrasive dust is present.

GENERAL CONDITIONS—The following allowances should be made when estimating nett H.P. required:

ALTIMETRIC—A reduction of 4% per 1,000 ft. above 330 ft. above sea level.

TEMPERATURE—A reduction of 1% for every 5° F. over 60° F.

INSTALLATION—Particulars of Engine mounting and type of Drive should be stated wherever possible. When a special Exhaust pipe layout is to be used please consult us and give us as much information as possible.

NOTE—When Reduction Gear or Reduction and Clutch is fitted, dimension “A” on page becomes 14½" 357 m.m.
THE ENGINE is provided with a specially designed Combustion Head incorporating the "Lister Patent Combustion Chamber," which ensures a positive start from cold by hand without need of Cartridge, Heating Lamp or Electric Ignition. A variable compression ratio initially ensures easy starting and subsequently gives long low minimum pressures.

THE CYLINDER BORE is treated with the LISTARC process of chrome hardening (Van der Horst Patents) which gives a toughened surface yet known whether the wear may be due to heat, chemical action or abrasion from the piston rings; thus giving a greatly lengthened life throughout which the engine retains its ease of starting, fuel and lubricating oil consumption, and develops rated power.

THE PISTON AND RINGS are of high grade material, and finished to an accuracy equal to that employed in the finest precision engineering. Long life and full compression are thus assured.

THE CRANKCASE is totally enclosed and dust proof, making the engine especially suitable for work in dusty and gritty surroundings.

THE CRANKSHAFT is made from high grade steel, heat treated and accurately finished by grinding. It is extended beyond the Flywheel on both sides allowing the pulley or coupling to be fitted on either side or if necessary a pulley on each side.

THE CAMS, CAMSHAFT AND ROCKERS are of high grade steel and accurately machined. The Cams are hardened and tempered. The Rockers have hardened wearing surfaces.

THE CONNECTING ROD is of Steel forging with renewable Phosphor Bronze Bush at the small end. The Large end Bearing is of Steel, white metal lined.

THE BEARINGS for Crankshaft are of ample size to provide maximum durability.

THE VALVES are of the finest alloy heat resisting steel, and the valve seatings are efficiently water cooled to ensure long life.

FUEL PUMP & FUEL INJECTOR. C.A.V. Bosch Fuel Pump and suitable Fuel injector is fitted.

GOVERNOR is of the centrifugal type and operates on the fuel injection pump, varying the quantity of fuel injected in accordance with speed.

LUBRICATION is automatic. A Gear Pump submerged in oil supplies all parts, except the small end bearing and camshaft, which are lubricated by splash.

GENERAL EQUIPMENT. Tank or Radiator to suit requirements. Exhaust Silencer, Fuel Tank and Piping, Starting Handle, Tin of Touch Tin of Cleaning Oil and Fuel Funnel with Strainer where necessary. Tank Cooled Engines ordered without Water Cooling Tanks are supplied with water connections unless contrary instructions are given. Where Radiator cooling is supplied an allowance of ½ h.p. should be made for temperate fan and ¼ h.p. for tropical fan.

ENGINE ACCESSORIES

HOUSING. The Engine is available with a strong sheet housing affording complete protection.

REDUCTION GEAR of high efficiency with 2 to 1 ratio can be supplied built integral with the Engine, less 2½ h.p.

May 6, 1948

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of February 19 concerning the type of refrigeration installation required at this school, and further to recent conversations upon the subject, I now wish to submit the following recommendation in writing.

The proprietor of Cosco's Grocery, Sioux Lookout, Mr. Pete Cosco, intends to enlarge his premises this summer and, incidentally, to increase his refrigeration facilities. He has for disposal about the end of June a Walk-in Refrigerator of the type and dimensions required here. It has a 6 ft. by 8 ft. floor with a nine foot ceiling. There is a blower type coil in the refrigerator and freon gas is compressed by a Brammer compressor operated by a half H.P. motor. The manufacturers are Ryan Bros., Winnipeg. I understand that the refrigerator has been in operation for about five years. It is in excellent condition and has been regularly inspected and maintained. Mr. Cosco is asking $350.00 for it.

Personally, I feel satisfied that The Indian Affairs Branch could do no better in purchasing a refrigeration plant for this school than by dealing with Mr. Cosco. I, therefore, request that you satisfy yourself that this is a good business opportunity and that you will kindly submit my recommendation to The Director of The Indian Affairs Branch. It should be noted that the motor for this installation is for 110 v., A.C., whereas we should need a 110v., D.C. motor. An exchange of motors through some Winnipeg agency would involve little extra expense.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

I am writing to you direct after recent discussions here with Mr. A. G. Doucet and Mr. G. Swartman, Superintendent of the Sioux Lookout Agency. The latter will be unable to deal with matters calling for urgent attention at the school owing to absence on Treaty trips.

Last October I, when writing to our Administration in Ottawa in connection with your Departmental Estimates for the year 1948-9, I listed as Urgent our need at this school of outside accommodation for married staff members. This need has become the more apparent during the current year, for our ability to retain the services of our young farm instructor, married since October last and with his wife expecting a child next month, will depend upon our providing him with suitable married quarters. Whereas none in the school itself, positively. For the summer months he is prepared to take up quarters in the warehouse, where a single room, 9 ft. by 23 ft., was lined with ten-tent and otherwise made fit for habitation last fall. At present this room is entirely lacking in furniture and equipment, apart from a new kitchen range and stove pipes provided by our Administration. A double bed can be transferred from the school, but for other necessary items we have to look to the government for assistance. I may say that this warehouse is built over the main school root-house - this cellar being decidedly unsatisfactory for the safe storage of potatoes etc., in severe weather - and for this reason Mr. A. G. Doucet is opposed to any additional expenditure by The Indian Affairs Branch with a view to making permanent married quarters in the warehouse.

We had the idea of hauling a commodious log structure from its present site in a pasture, where it has been used as a coal shed or implement shed, to better one, and of applying for a grant for building material and labour in order to have it converted into a dwelling. But to this scheme Mr. Doucet also said No. He was not satisfied with the present condition of the shed. He did say, however, that you might be prepared to provide a two-bedroomed prefabricated bungalow of the type erected for the Forestry Branch and latterly for small day schools etc.

Since it is absolutely vital to the success of our school...
work in general that we secure and retain the services of able-bodied men I am making this urgent request that immediate sanction be given for the provision this summer of such a dwelling as Mr. Doucet recommends. I may say that I have on my staff a young man skilled in the use of tools who will be here during July and August and free to work full time on such a building project. We will be returning to college in the fall. It would also be possible for my two other male workers to devote a good deal of time to the building, provided it is undertaken without delay.

Mr. Swartman advised me some while ago that no funds were provided in the appropriation for the year 1948-9 for further work on the branch road to the school, but suggested that I provide for an amount of, say, $2000.00 towards road improvement in my estimates for next year. May I state now that while the road needs considerable attention I would much rather see such a large sum devoted to improvement of our actual school premises and establishment as being far more vital to the well-being of both pupils and staff.

Let me add another word to give point to my request. Lack of married quarters, as much as anything else, has kept the school without an engineer (other than the principal) since the retirement of our former engineer at the close of 1947. It appears that the only prospects for the position of engineer have been married men with families, and for such, as I have already said, there is no proper room inside or outside the school. Those charged with the administration of this school are placed in an unfavorable light when things go wrong with the pupils, as they do occasionally. Any inefficiency, however, attributable to staff deficiencies resulting from inadequate accommodation, cannot fairly be blamed upon us.

I append a list of furniture needed to make our warehouse ready for occupancy and I trust that you will kindly have these articles supplied at your earliest possible convenience. In ordering I am considering the possibility that some of the items may later be transferred to permanent married quarters:

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

We have had a visit recently from the Reverend Mr. Wickenden, Principal of the above Residential School. He has again drawn to our attention the difficulties which our residential school Principals are encountering in retaining the services of competent farmers and engineers.

The type of man who will remain steadily on these jobs is usually married and with a family. Most of them are unwilling to accept these positions unless they are assured of adequate housing.

We have also recently received from Canon Cook, of the Indian School Administration, of the M.S.C.C., a letter reading as follows:

"More and more, the Administration is finding it difficult to retain the services of competent farmers and engineers at its schools because of inadequate housing for the staff agent and his family. In particular is this true at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

"It is therefore respectfully requested that the Indian Affairs Branch make funds available for the erection of two dwellings on the property of the above mentioned..."
school to house a married engineer and married farmer. One building is urgently needed this present summer and the other might be constructed next year.

"Buildings such as North American Buildings Limited model 422 R.B. design 3 S, without basement, would be adequate."

The building to which Canon Cook refers in his above letter is a small four-room bungalow which we have purchased in the past from North American Builders as a teachers' residence for some of our Indian reserves.

This building has proven quite satisfactory when completed to our specifications. The cost of the building is approximately $2,000.00. The cost of freight, erection expenses, excavation, foundation, etc., will amount to approximately $1,500.00.

It is therefore recommended to you that authority be given for the inclusion of the sum of $3,500.00 in our next estimates for the purchase and erection of this building.

Director,

I have only requisitioned for articles essential to ordinary comfort and to the credit of the institution. Table tops in the children's dining hall are in bad condition in some instances and the linoleum in staff bathrooms is worn into holes. (b) The engine in the Pumphouse is in a very bad state of repair and should actually be replaced, but I believe we could have it repaired or overhauled so that it would serve its purpose for another year. The intake is now being repaired by the plumber and helpers who are at present working on the septic tank system.

(c) Regarding the foundation, it is difficult to estimate the repairs required. I had Mr. Head, contractor, look it over, and he was of the opinion that considerable excavating would be required before it could be properly inspected, but as mentioned in a previous letter, he is in a position to take on the work required. On this type of job, he will only work on a cost plus 10% basis. I would suggest that the necessary work in connection with the repair of the foundation be attended to this fall. There were certain recommendations submitted by an Engineer of the Engineering and Survey Branch about two years ago and the
work could be carried out according to his suggestions.

(e) The road leading to the School has not had any maintenance for the past two years. It requires considerable graveling and filling in certain sections. At present it is almost impassable, particularly in wet weather. However, I believe that for an expenditure of approximately $500.00, the road could be put in shape to handle the necessary traffic until early next summer. I would recommend that sufficient funds be provided next year to do a proper repair and maintenance job on the road. This would probably require $3000.00 or $4000.00 depending on the extent of the work.

(f) Painting: A paint job is badly required, both inside and outside from the basement to the top floor. Some of this work could be carried out during the fall, but it is rather difficult to do much indoor painting while the children are in school. It is also difficult to estimate the cost of such a job since a great deal of preparatory work is necessary such as plastering, cleaning the walls, preparing surfaces, crack filling etcetera, prior to painting. However, I believe $1000.00 would go a long way toward completing this work.

The floors in the dormitories are actually in a very bad state of repair, and something should be done. The beds have no castors or other protective device on the bottom of the legs, and I believe this should be rectified before the floors are repaired. While this appears to be a very simple matter, it is actually rather difficult to keep anything on the legs of the beds, as the children will remove anything movable. Possibly someone in the Department may have some good suggestions in this respect.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

We have received the following letter from W.J. Wood, M.D., Regional Superintendent of Indian Health Services, Winnipeg:

"The following extract from a letter from Dr. G.L. Bell, Sioux Lookout, is forwarded for action by the department concerned.

"In looking over the school I find that there was originally a room set aside for showers but the showers were never installed. Bathing 150 children in half a dozen bath tubs is rather a formidable job. I am told that at some of the residential schools the children slip on a simple cotton bathing suit (home made and cheap) and go into the shower room a dozen or more at one time. I would recommend that these showers be installed and that some such bathing routine be instituted.

"It would be appreciated if the Indian Affairs Branch would advise us if any action is proposed."

Please let us have your comments on the above.

Again we have had inquiry from the Principal of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School with respect to an electric ironer for the laundry. We explained the necessity for this purchase in our letter of September 8. Mr. Evans, however, is unable to give us any specifications of the ironer required as he has no catalogue showing equipment of this nature. We have requested that he let us have further details in order that a requisition may be prepared but it has occurred to me that you or someone in the purchasing department might have knowledge of an ironer suitable for a school laundry.

G. Swartman
Superintendent
Sioux Lookout Agency
During a recent visit to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School the condition of the lighting system was brought to my attention. It appears that when the motor is not running the lights will only come on very dim and are of no value whatsoever unless the motor is operating.

With the winter months approaching I would recommend that arrangements be made to have a service man sent in as there is no one locally familiar with this type of lighting system. Those whom I have asked for an opinion state that it may be the batteries and to replace them would be very expensive. Consequently before making any recommendation I would like to see the plant checked over by an expert.

Yours very truly,

G. Swartman
Superintendent
Sioux Lookout Agency

Dear Colonel Neary:

Electric Lighting Batteries
Anglican Indian Residential School
Sioux Lookout, Ont.

On my visit to the above school on 15th and 19th October, 1948, I found that the Battery Bank was not holding its voltage with the result that the generator had to be operated continuously to provide illumination or any current required for electrically driven equipment at the School. During Mr. Swartman's visit to the School on 19th October we discussed the situation and I undertook to ascertain from Globelite Batteries, Limited, Winnipeg (who had supplied the Battery Bank in question) if they could send a serviceman to the School to look into the matter and determine what the trouble is.

On my return to Ottawa I wrote Globelite Batteries accordingly and on 25th October we received a copy of a letter written by the Company to the Principal from which the following is an extract:

"Unfortunately, we do not have a serviceman available at the moment and therefore request that you complete the enclosed questionnaire and return it to us as soon as possible. On receipt of the information that we have requested on this questionnaire, we will in turn then advise you accordingly."

Canon Cook visited this School on 7th and 8th November, 1948, and the following are his comments on this Battery Bank:

"Globelite people sent form asking all types of questions re batteries in use and claim to be able..."
to tell trouble from answers. My personal observation is that sediment collected in the bottoms of the jars is so high that in places it touches the bottoms of plates and thus short circuits and reduces voltage of the bank."

Today we received a copy of a letter, dated 18th November, 1948, addressed by Globelite Batteries Ltd. to our Principal and, as arranged during our telephone conversation this afternoon, I send you a copy herewith. As you will see, the Company's solution is a NEW Battery Bank and the price list accompanying their letter quotes

$1,781. for a new 56-cell, 110 volt, Type W 17,360 ampere hour capacity - the type they recommend.

It is noted from the last paragraph of their letter of 18th November that the Department would get a substantial discount on the list price but even with a substantial discount the cost of providing this new battery bank would be considerable.

As mentioned in our telephone conversation, the amount involved is such that I suggest that it would be desirable for one of the electrical engineers of your Department to look into the matter and see if it is possible to put the present bank in good working condition at a reasonable cost. I have wired the Principal to take no action until he hears further from me as I have asked your Department to look into the matter.

It seems strange, to say the least, that a firm such as Globelite Batteries are not prepared to send a representative to look into the matter on the spot. Further, I should think that when the plant was installed in 1942, the probable maximum load was fully considered and the required capacity of the Battery Bank determined accordingly. So far as I am aware, the load has not been increased materially since 1942 and it may be that in studying the answers to the questionnaire, the Company have overlooked the fact that it is extremely improbable that the maximum current required for illumination and for operating all the power equipment in the School would be needed at any one time.

Will you please advise us, at your earliest convenience, of the action you propose to take in this matter.

Yours truly,
(Signed) G.R. Turner.

Attention: Rev. J.N. Evans

Dear Sir:

Since receiving the Globelite battery questionnaire we have established that your type W13-56 cell, 110 volt - 270 Amp. Hour Globelite Battery was purchased in July 1942. Your present load is far in excess of the capacity of the battery, with the result it is necessary to run the plant every day. In view of these operating conditions, we would say the battery is ready for replacement; in fact, you are fortunate it has carried this load and has evidently given you reasonably good service since July 1942.

You will note, in referring to our current price list enclosed, glass jar farm light batteries are guaranteed seven years and the guarantee is based on 600 cycles, that is 600 complete charges and discharges. We would say that this battery, under existing operating conditions, has delivered 600 cycles in the first two years of operation.

In establishing the seven year guarantee, it is based on the average use of isolated lighting units, chiefly in farm homes. It is recommended to purchase a battery of sufficient capacity to carry the load for four or five days and under these operating conditions the batteries serve, in most instances, for considerably more than seven years.

As pointed out previously, the battery in use in the school is a type W13-270 Amp. Hour capacity and it would be our recommendation when replacing the battery to buy a much larger capacity battery and as the minimum size we would suggest our type W17-360 Amp. Hour capacity.

Incidentally, the department purchase batteries at a substantial discount off the list prices shown and we would like you to know that an order for a replacement battery will be taken care of promptly.

Yours truly,

GLOBELITE BATTERIES LIMITED

I wish to refer to Colonel Neary's communication of November 30, File 470-5 (E1).

The batteries referred to are certainly in very bad shape and the lights are practically useless unless the meter is running.

I was discussing this particular school a few days ago with Dr. Wood and Mr. Davis. Mr. Davis informed me that one of the schools in Manitoba was in the process of being connected to the Hydro system and that he understood there was a fairly new set of batteries. I would suggest that this be investigated and, if there were not sufficient cells in the bank or set, new ones could be added which should not involve a great deal of expense.

There is a Hydro line to the radio range station which is within approximately 1/2 miles from the school and, if arrangements could be made to have a line extended to the school, our difficulties regarding light and power would be ended.

Dr. Wood informed me that he gained the impression during a recent visit to this school that it was unnecessarily dirty. I assured him that I would request the Principal to correct this situation and it would be appreciated if you asked the Superintendent of the School Commission to do likewise.

I wish to report that the new meter (power plant) at the Sieux Lookout Indian Residential School broke down about a month ago. It was only on Tuesday that I learned of the accident but in the meantime the Principal had arranged with Head Construction for the necessary repairs and replacement parts. Mr. Head informs me that the main bearings, the connecting rods and valves were burned out and had to be replaced. His theory is that the damage was caused to start with by lack of water in the cooling system. This allowed the motor to heat and burn up the oil. I am also informed that on a previous occasion the rings seized up possibly due to overheating. The school was, of course, without lights and sufficient water for four or five days which is quite a serious situation particularly at this time of the year. With proper attention a motor of this type should run for two years or more with only minor adjustments.

This school insofar as maintenance which includes cleanliness of the buildings and pupils is making very little progress. It is all very well for the Department to take all the necessary steps to affect repairs and spend money on equipment and maintenance but this is practically wasted when there is not sufficient staff or staff of the proper calibre to do their part.

Re: Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School

I wish to explain some of the reasons for employing Mr. Peter Seymour in a temporary capacity at the Sioux Lookout I. R. S. from December 28 to January 9 inclusive.

Mr. Seymour was formerly engaged as manual training instructor at McIntosh and has been employed as handyman, carpenter, etc., at the Lac Seul and Osnaburgh nursing stations during the past several months. He reported here the morning of December 28, enroute to Lac Seul, but owing to the conditions at the Sioux Lookout School, I persuaded him to go there for a few days and to remain if possible until his services were urgently required elsewhere, or at least until the Principal and Night Watchman returned. No person at the school seemed to know exactly how long they would be away.

I was particularly concerned regarding the total lack of supervision of the boys. During the holiday season they came to town en masse and had been seen at different times crossing the thin ice just below the stretch of open water, west of the C. N. Railway bridge.

The Night Watchman's duties at this time had been delegated to Joe Aschin, a very unreliable boy for this type of work. I believe that he was the only adult male staff member living in the main building at the time as Mr. MacDonald and Mr. Barker were living in the cottages. During this period I visited the school every day as I was very worried about the whole situation. Mr. MacDonald, the Vice-Principal, did not know, according to his own admission, the exact location of all the fire hose outlets. I discussed this with him, also with Seymour.

Mr. Seymour was instructed to be on the alert during the night and to keep the boys occupied during the day and prevent them from coming to town if possible. He did all this and more, consequently it is recommended that he be paid at the rate of $5.00 per day for his services during the time he was at the school. This has been covered by our Voucher No. 16.

It is also recommended that Mr. Seymour be engaged as manual training instructor at both the McIntosh and Sioux Lookout Schools. He could spend three days a week at both schools. I fully realize that there is a full time job for such a man at either school but three days a week would be much better than the present arrangement. I also feel that there is an urgent need for a man of Seymour's ability and character at both schools. Mr. Doucett will be discussing this matter in Ottawa but I thought it advisable to place my views on record also.

Superintendent, Sioux Lookout Agency

DIRECTOR,
LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.
Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

The Superintendent of Education has recently had a visit from Canon Cook of the M.S.C.C., with regard to the major plumbing and heating repairs required at the above school.

On reviewing the Donald Inspection Company's report, we find that the Engineer has commented as follows:

1. "Plumbing. This is in very bad condition and needs a thorough overhaul."

2. "Heating. This is by low pressure steam system or gravity type. It is found difficult to heat the classrooms and sewing rooms and principal's house. A vacuum pump should be installed without delay. The boilers are two Pascol locomotive type No. 410, manufactured by the Port Arthur Shipbuilding Company."

Canon Cook advised that the situation with regard to the plumbing and heating at this school has been becoming worse and that he is concerned with the possible effects on the health of the staff and the pupils. Therefore, it would be appreciated if you could have one of your Engineers visit this school and prepare the plans and specifications for the repairs and replacements necessary to restore these systems to the proper state of efficiency.

Director.

February 11, 1949.

Re: Cottage

Dear Colonel Neary:

During my recent visit to Sioux Lookout School I had the opportunity of inspecting the recently constructed cottage, for the use of the engineer or farmer on the premises. It is a very fine building, well constructed and most suitable for the purpose for which it was constructed. However, it was noticed that the interior was unpainted, without water and bathroom facilities, without floor coverings and furniture. In discussing this with Indian Superintendent Swartman I was informed that no further funds were available from this year's appropriations. This I can well believe considering what has been done in the way of supplying new electrical equipment and work on the roadway.

I am wondering if sufficient funds have been asked for in the next fiscal year to do the work necessary, properly to establish the cottage and build and establish a second such building as was considered in 1948.

At the moment furniture is urgently needed for use of the farmer at present occupying the cottage. Would the Indian Affairs Branch be willing to reimburse the Administration out of the next fiscal year's funds if the necessary furniture were purchased now by the Administration and the "paid" accounts tendered after the first of April?

Your consideration of this point and others above would be appreciated.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Superintendent.

I wish to acknowledge Colonel Neary's letter of February 23, File 470-5 (E.1), with respect to furnishings for the new bungalow at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. We submitted a requisition covered by our letter of December 1, 1948. The requisition listed every item asked for by the Principal. We were informed by communication from the Superintendent of Education, dated December 20, File 470-5 (E.1), that owing to lack of funds the furniture would not be secured at the present time and we advised the Principal accordingly.

I agree with Canon Cook that the interior should be painted and that water and bathroom facilities should be installed. However, I do not feel that it would be practical to undertake any of the plumbing work required until the frost is out of the ground. I also suggest that the items listed on our requisition dated December 1 be revised and that someone more competent than either Messrs. Mac Donald or Evans prepare a more suitable list.

While on the subject of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, I would recommend that some thought be given to having the school closed at least a month earlier this year and that plans be made to give the building a complete renovation. This would include painting, plumbing, building repairs outside and inside, etc.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School,
Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

With reference to your marginal notation of February 7th on Major MacKay's memorandum of February 4th in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

Our heating engineer carried out an inspection of the mechanical services at the above, on the 6th and 7th of March, and the results of his survey are summarized below together with recommendations; for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

Generally the condition of the building and its mechanical services may be described as having had hard usage and there is little evidence to show that reasonable care and maintenance have been provided in the past. In spite of this, the building appears to be sound and could be put in better than average condition, if immediate steps were taken to carry out repairs and revisions hereinafter outlined.

The Donald Inspection Company's survey indicates serious plumbing and drainage discrepancies. While it was impossible to check the condition of the sewage disposal field owing to the presence of several feet of snow, it can be safely assumed, that the arrangement of gang closets would contribute to unsatisfactory operation of the sewage disposal field as well as the septic tank. The two groups of gang closets are under continuous flushing by overhead automatic water tanks. This keeps the septic and disposal field flooded and prevents proper bacterial action from taking place in the tank. It is also likely that the disposal field will be sour and sodden.

The drainage lines appear to be properly sized and careful enquiry showed that most of the trouble due to blockages, result from bottles, tins, and other sundry items being forced into the system. It was suggested to the Acting Principal by our officer, that stricter discipline be maintained in the recreation rooms to prevent the pupils from wilfully throwing such items into the drainage system.

The domestic hot water system is served by a generously sized jacket heater which is connected to a 300 gallon domestic hot water storage tank. No complaints were received about the inefficiency of this system, but it was noted that the distribution piping to the fixtures, was undersized. Many of the faucets on basins and bathtubs were in need of overhaul and in some instances, replacement.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6216, file 470-5, part 9)
Since no complaints with regard to this system were brought to the attention of our officer, it is felt that for the time being this layout should remain undisturbed. It is also felt that satisfactory repairs to the existing faucets can be made by the new caretaker as required.

Most of the complaints centered on the heating system. While the original plan was followed closely, a careful study indicates that the design is not suitable for a building of this character. No traps were installed on the mains and as a result, they are not well drained. Instead of traps, bleeder connections between the ends of the main and the wet return were installed. These connections were hooked up in such a manner as to cause many short circuits, and as a result, distribution of steam to various parts of the building is very unequal. Some rooms are cold while others are greatly overheated. The branch mains to the Principal's quarters, are too small, improperly installed, not dripped, and not graded in accordance with required standards. These branch mains will have to be removed and replaced by piping of proper size.

About 65 to 70% of the radiator traps were found to be passing steam and will have to be replaced. Repairs to traps as old as these, is not practical and could be more costly than replacing them with new traps. Most of the radiator traps are damaged or worn out and quite beyond repair. For your information under good conditions, radiator traps can not be expected to perform their functions longer than 15 years. This system has been in use over 20 years.

There are two Pascol steel low pressure steam heating boilers, each rated at 4000 sq.ft. E.D.R. Either one should be able to handle the entire load under normal conditions, except in the most severe weather when both must be used. They are hand fired and a fair grade of bituminous coal is provided. These boilers were found to be in relatively good condition. They should be provided with new grates and they should be thoroughly cleaned. It is felt that they can be expected to give service for an additional period of 10 years, provided that the school is fortunate enough to retain the services of the present caretaker, who started in January of this year. This man appears to be much more competent that the general run of boiler room staff encountered in residential schools. If the following recommendations are carried out, it is felt that the heating difficulty will be overcome.

1. Install new radiator valves and traps on all radiators.
2. Install float and thermostatic traps on the ends of all steam mains.
3. Re-grade spring pieces and lateral connections to radiators and risers.
4. Remove and re-route some sections of the wet return piping.
5. Provide and install a condensation return pump and replace the cut-moded and damaged boiler return trap and air eliminator assembly.
6. Execute minor piping changes in the boiler room.
7. Remove gang closets and replace with individual tank units.

Indian Affairs. (RC 10, Volume 6216, file 470-5, part 9)
On verbal request of the Indian Affairs Branch, the above revisions are now being planned. It is our understanding that they are strongly desirous of having this work carried out as soon as possible. At this time, it is not possible to provide a close estimate of the cost of the above operations, but it is felt that the sum of $6,000.00 will be required.

Commenting generally, it can be stated that the interior decorations are not in a good condition. The roof leaks in several places, and some water comes in to the basement through the walls. The kitchen stove is practically burned out; and in our opinion, is a serious fire hazard. It should be replaced at the earliest possible moment.

When authority is received to get this work underway, we will take the necessary steps to have Mr. Gow call for tenders.

Chief Engineer

This will acknowledge receipt to the Department of the following articles requisitioned for use at the school:

Walk-in Refrigerator, in sections, delivered by Mr. P. Cosco of Sioux Lookout, including compressor and blower and necessary piping.

D.C. Motors, one for the compressor and one for the blower have not yet been delivered, but Mr. Cosco has ordered them from Winnipeg. The original motors, A.C., were not suited for operation here.

On General Turner's visit to the school on 19th October, 1948, the unit was out of action because the motor was not working and he arranged with Mr. Swartman that the latter would get after the local electricians in Sioux Lookout to expedite repairs. With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of June 21st, which bears your marginal notation of the 23rd instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

On April 27th, we forwarded plans and specifications covering heating revisions at the above to Mr. Gow, and requested him to obtain competitive tenders from reliable firms in the area.

Owing to the more or less isolated location of this school and due to the fact that contractors in that area are very busy, only one price was obtained. This tender was submitted by the John Plaxton Co., Ltd., of Winnipeg, who are presently engaged in work at the Sioux Lookout hospital and for that reason are in a particularly favourable position to take on the work at the school.

Their firm tender of $4,919.00 accompanied by a security deposit of $450.00, is within our estimate of $6,000.00. This matter was discussed with Indian Affairs Branch officials and it was indicated that authority should be given to have the work carried out by the above firm. It was pointed out that a contingency of 10% should be added to the contractors price to cover supervision, etc., and with that in mind, authority should be requested through an Order-in-Council to provide the sum of $5,400.00.

When written approval is received from the Indian Affairs Branch, we will request Mr. Gow to instruct the contractor to begin work at once. In the meantime, an Order-in-Council will be prepared for signature, requesting authority to have the sum of $5,400.00 set aside for this work; together with contract forms for signature by the Department of the contractor, so that work may be carried out with a minimum of delay.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Walk-in Refrigerator
Anglican Indian School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Referring to your conversation this morning with General Turner, hereunder, as requested, is a copy of a report just received from our Principal at Sioux Lookout. The arrangements with Ryan Bros. were made, of course, through your Mr. Davis' Office.

It will be appreciated if you will do something at an early date to ensure that this walk-in refrigerator is put in proper working order so that we may store foodstuffs in it without the risk of them being lost through failure of the refrigerating system. As you know it is both costly and inconvenient to buy foodstuffs on a basis of day-to-day requirements for even the numbers at this School during the holiday period.

Last Monday General Turner made arrangements for the Ryan Bros. to send a man to examine and if possible to repair the compressor unit so as to get the WALK-IN REFRIGERATOR working. The man came on Thursday from Winnipeg and after working at the motor from 10.30 a.m. till 5.30 p.m., he left after having no success. I saw him before he boarded the train back to Winnipeg and he said we would either have to ship the whole Unit to Winnipeg or have a completely new one. In the meantime, I have had meat and butter go bad in the Ice House. I am afraid I will have to purchase meat, butter and eggs, in fact all food that is perishable from the local stores until the Refrigerator is fixed. It has been out of working order since the 13th of June. Until last Tuesday we have been able to keep some meat and butter in the Ice House but this last four days it has been hopeless to try.

Yours sincerely,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Globelite Battery - Anglican Indian School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

In the last paragraph of your letter 470-5(E.l) of 22nd January, 1949, you requested that definite instructions be issued to the School that the new battery receive every possible care and attention. Such instructions were issued to our Principal on 24th January as per copy sent you on that date.

"We have for acknowledgment your letter of July 4th and in reply wish to advise that our Mr. Thurston recently paid a visit to the Residential School near Sioux Lookout.

The principal points that should be carefully watched are temperature and vibration. Never permit the temperature to rise over 120° F. This can be easily checked with an ordinary dry bulb thermometer by inserting same through the vent hole in the cover of one of the battery cells. Also, the battery should be cushioned in some manner to reduce excessive vibration. Our Mr. Thurston advises that when he called at the School, he noticed that the vibration from the engine caused the battery to excessively vibrate. We might suggest that cork approximately 1/8" thick be placed under the battery stand to eliminate this excessive vibration."

This matter is brought to your attention because, as both the engine (the Lister for driving the electric generator) and the battery referred to were installed recently by your Branch, it is presumed that you will want to give favourable and early consideration to the provision of the cork cushioning suggested by Globelite Batteries, Limited, so that the life...
of the battery may be prolonged by the elimination of the excessive vibration.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Boutilier:

The Director of the Indian Affairs Branch has passed to me an extract from your letter of July 10th with reference to the proposed repairs at the Sioux Lookout School and I am glad to give you the following information in connection with this project:

An officer of our Engineering and Construction Division inspected this school in the spring. It was found that major repairs to the heating system were necessary immediately and that some modernizing of the plumbing in the school was desirable as soon as funds could be made available.

We were directed by the Indian Affairs Branch to proceed with repairs of the heating system and, in consequence, drawings and specifications were prepared and tenders invited through our Winnipeg office from various contractors in the area, one of whom was the Amos Company of Sioux Lookout. This firm stated that they could not obtain qualified steamfitters and did not wish to tender on the heating work.

One tender only was obtained, that from the John Plaxton Company Limited, Winnipeg, and this has already been accepted from our side, pending its acceptance. As I have mentioned, the work will be carried out in accordance with designs prepared by this Branch and will be supervised by an engineer from our Dominion Water and Power Bureau, Winnipeg.

While the plumbing system is antiquated, it was decided by Indian Affairs to defer action for the time being on the overhaul of the plumbing installations, but I can assure you that when these operations are undertaken, the Amos Company will be given an opportunity to tender.

If there is any further information you desire in connection with this project, do not hesitate to write to me.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Gibson,
Director.

MEMORANDUM:

Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

You are advised that we have received a letter from Mr. Gow enclosing one firm tender covering the revisions to the plumbing and heating systems at the above.

Despite efforts by Mr. Gow to obtain additional tenders, only one bona-fide lump sum tender was received, and it is considered that the time required to obtain additional tenders would not be in the public interest.

The bona-fide lump sum tender of $4,819.00 accompanied by a security deposit cheque for 10% of this amount, was received from the John Plaxton Company of 244 Main Street, Winnipeg, Manitoba. This figure is less than our estimate and an analysis shows that the price is fair and reasonable for the work involved and we hereby recommend that the work be awarded to the aforementioned firm.

When this authority can be obtained, we will contact Mr. Gow and instruct him to advise the John Plaxton Company to start work.

Reverend Canon H.G. Cook, Superintendent of the M.S.C.C., has forwarded to us the following letter which he has received from the Principal of the above school:

"Re: Emergency Water Supply

I am very glad to report that the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Typhoon pumping unit has been delivered to the school.

The same has not yet been installed but the local Superintendent of Indian Affairs has been notified and the Agent for the Fairbanks-Morse engines, etc., mentioned the other day that he would have to send his man out to install it. We need a new concrete foundation-stand for it.

May I also make mention of the fact that despite the newness and usefulness of the engine and pump, if the work that was commenced and not finished last year with the connecting of the pump to the well the emergency water supply will be of little use in the winter. There is at present a pipe from the emergency-water-supply-pump-house into the lake which will freeze very quickly on a below zero day. Also the method of getting the water up to the school building by way of the firehose (3 x 50' lengths) is far from being satisfactory. One would hope that the emergency pump will not be required..."
but one wishes to have it satisfactory should the machinery, etc., be required this next and following winters."

We would like to reach the position where complaints from this school will be reduced to a minimum. Consequently, we would appreciate it if you would give careful consideration to the above letter, consult the Principal and let us know if you think there is any necessity for additional work, and if so, let us have an estimate of the expenditure that will be involved.

You will note from the second paragraph of the Principal's letter that he states that a new concrete foundation stand will be required for the pumping unit which has reached the school. If you consider that the stand is necessary, you may arrange to have it built, keeping the cost as low as possible.

An early reply would be appreciated.

Dear Sir:-

Re: Plumbing

Last Wednesday August 10th, we had Mr. O.J. Storsater from the Dominion Water and Power Bureau, 532 Dominion Public Bldg., Winnipeg, Manitoba pay us a visit to inspect the work done on the steam-heating by the Plaxton Co. recently.

While here he mentioned that his last visit two years ago was to inspect the boys' Playroom and Kitchen walls to see what could be done to stop the water flooding the said P.r and K. floors on rainy days. He was astounded when I informed him that the water still came in much to the inconvenience of all concerned.

Mr. Swartman brought him out but had to get back to a pressing engagement so I was a bit disappointed as I would have liked to have taken Mr. Swartman on a tour of inspection around the building to show him the deplorable state of the plumbing etc. However, while they were driving here, Mr. Swartman asked the inspector to examine the Plumbing in the Boys side of the building and send in his recommendations to the proper authorities.

Memorandum

Re: Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

With reference to Mr. Bethune's memorandum of September 23rd addressed to the Deputy Minister, bearing your marginal note of the 23rd instant together with copies of correspondence between the Minister and Mr. Benidickson in connection with the above, you are advised as follows.

A perusal of our files with reference to the above, discloses that the only complaint received was in connection with the heating system. This was registered in Mr. Hoey's memorandum of November 28th, 1947.

Early in March 1948, an officer from this Division was assigned to inspect the heating system and assess the requirements for its correction. At that time his attention was drawn to the plumbing system. From his observations it was deduced that the majority if not all the blockages reported were due to the carelessness and mischief of the pupils. This observation was not confirmed by the school staff during our officer's visit. Our officer found instances of excessive amounts of foreign matter having been wadded into various fixtures. There was also sufficient evidence to safely assume that indifferent attention had been given in the past to keep the plumbing fixtures up to a reasonable standard of cleanliness.

While we do not consider that the gang closet arrangement is as satisfactory as individual closets and tanks, it is a fact that on several similar installations in other institutions throughout the country similar conditions have been made to keep them clean. It is questionable if automatic flushing is sufficient to keep this type of water closet clean without daily attention being given by some responsible member of the school staff.

By the same token, it can be stated that the condition of individual water closets in several other schools which have been inspected in recent years, leaves much to be desired as far as hygienic conditions are concerned.

It is our considered opinion that any type of urinal or water closet in an institution such as the above should be cleaned several times weekly by a staff member and that flushing alone is not sufficient to maintain a satisfactory standard. It is also our opinion that if this duty were carried out, the installation of gang or range closets would not present a hazard to health.

Dear Doctor:

On September 28th I visited the Sioux Lookout Indian residential school and made a thorough inspection.

In general there has been a vast improvement under the present principal Rev. Wilson and I was very pleased indeed with the many changes he has made and with the present attitude of both staff and children. A great deal of painting has been done with brighter colors and the building is clean, which condition has not prevailed for several years. The children's body and clothes were clean and good discipline is maintained. I had the privilege of having dinner with them and there has been a great improvement in the way the food is prepared and served. I presume the Department dentist will visit the school this Fall as there is considerable work required. I feel that the Department should make an extra effort to alter a few discrepancies in their Department now that the school is being run competently and I would like to recommend the following:

1. The road to the school should be widened so that the snow plough could pass through and keep it open in the winter. At present the road is too narrow for a snow plough.

2. There is in wet weather a continuous seepage into the basement through the foundation. Often water is 1" or 2" deep and this constitutes a real hazard to the children's health not to mention the inconvenience of working in such a condition. I think most of this water comes from the roof and I would suggest that an eaves-trough be placed around the entire building and the water from same be conducted away from the building.
3. The boys' lavatory requires considerable work. The room itself needs plastering. The present 3 tubs should be removed as the shower room is adequate. All of the boys' toilet bowls should be removed and replaced by new ones. The present scheme is very bad and cannot be rectified. There is leakage from the present concrete toilet block which creates an odor through the building and the situation in general is unsanitary and a danger to the health of the children. This is inside work and can be done even after "freeze-up". I feel that the Department should undertake this work immediately.

4. There should be mechanical refrigeration supplied for the kitchen as the present one does not function and cannot be repaired. The large refrigerator is working well but the kitchen staff cannot go to the large refrigerator for small items as this would mean opening and closing the door of same incessantly and a low temperature could not be maintained. I would suggest that this new refrigerator be a kerosene type although the present electrical plant might possibly carry the extra work of an electric refrigerator which is fairly heavily loaded at present. All of which is respectfully submitted.

Yours very truly,

G. L. Bell, M.B.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Principal Wilson has enclosed in a letter the following information about equipment at the Sioux Lookout school which I think you ought to have.

(a) Typhoon Pump - The pump has been installed on a concrete base in the pump house but that is as far as it has gone. We will still have to thaw out pipes and hose in the winter before we can use it etc. There is no permanency about it at all such as having a pipe from the well connected so as the water will flow through the lead in to the school tanks.

(b) Electric Wiring - Mr. Swartman told me some time ago that the Indian Department supplied the money etc. and it was up to me to get men to do the work of all equipment around the school. The job that was done last Fall in connection with the electricity is still incomplete in so far that the wire leading from the school basement to the Cottage is still above ground. The man that Mr. Swartman employs for all his electrical work etc. for the Dept. is Mr. Lawler and I have gotten after him Mr. Lawler four times since last fall or last. Each time it is going to be done the next day or so. The wire that is on the ground at present is I believe to be used at Lac Seul Hospital and the man is waiting for a different kind of wire before he can make a permanent job. We have had heavy frosts and two falls of snow this last week and if he does not get here soon the wire will still be on the ground another winter.

(c) Fire Equipment - To date this equipment has not been sent.

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of December 6th, file 470-5 (E), and referring to paragraph 3 thereof I wish to advise that we will obtain the required information as soon as possible and report at an early date.

Reference your paragraph (4), concerning a school boat, I wish to advise that this craft is unserviceable, and since it is over twenty years old I believe the cost to recondition the hull would be out of question. Regarding the engine, I had it brought in for inspection and the qualified mechanic who examined it reported that the Kermath motor is obsolete and parts not available. This coincides with the Kermath manufacturers observations. The rings are seized and useless. The cylinder walls are worn 15/1000 which is well over the tolerance permitted. The valve springs installed are the wrong type and it is now impossible to obtain the correct springs for this type of motor. The crankshaft is worn about 2/1000 which is also over-tolerance. Generator and electrical system requires re-building or replacing.

The Principal of this school informed me sometime in the Fall that he had an offer of $500. for the motor from some party in Hudson, Ontario, but I was of the opinion that the prospective buyer could not be serious. Since the boat and motor is the property of the Department I would appreciate your advice with respect to the disposal of same. My suggestion would be to either write it off or sell it to the highest bidder with the understanding that the buyer be acquainted with the exact condition of the boat and motor.

I found that this site was in many respects admirable having good water for steamers and a southern exposure but on closer examination I found that we would have to interfere with some existing claims in order to get a sufficient area for school purposes; and it would be too close to the crowd, and freighting would be heavy as by steamer route it would involve a distance of over 50 miles and in winter or by canoe a distance of about 70 miles to reach a railway. In nearly every respect it would be suitable but it is out of observation of the travelling public and freighting would be very costly, and we would have too many coming every day to see the children and incidentally to consume our supplies of provisions. My dear Dr. Westgate,

I am enclosing herewith plan of suggested site for Indian School at Quibell, showing its location in the Township of Wabigoon, and a description of the property taken from the title deed. On this land we have located the bands of Indians who need the school, and you will notice how central it is for the whole area.

I visited the property and gave it a general look over. The land is broken into two sections by the Wabigoon River, one part being about 56 acres, the other about 13 acres. The land is good clay with some rock especially along the river. The larger portion is level with small timber most of it new growth poplar and willow. Five or six acres have been cleared on the smaller portion and cultivated for vegetables. A small log house is erected here. On the larger portion a small flat has been cultivated and abandoned a few years ago, but it has been allowed to grow. There is a good road in the smaller portion and another good road running north is connected to the edge of the N.W. corner by a road running east. This road is cut out and a creek crosses it near the bridge, but no grading has been done on it is quite in the rough for half mile. Both portions are just one mile distance from the Railway station. The river is a good size and there are two rapids, one just outside the property under the railway track, the other at the narrows as seen in the map.

The land has come on the market through the death of the owner, an old man who for some time did very little with it. Mr. H.P. Cooke, K.C., Kenora, has been appointed administrator of the estate. I have reason to think that the 12½ acres could be purchased for about $600. The land in the vicinity at Quibell is excellent. The whole township is taken up. It is splendid land for oats, clover, and alfalfa, and produces the finest vegetables.
