The Field Secretary begs to report that in accordance with instructions received from the General Secretary (letter dated April 27th) and in response to the request of the Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs (letter dated May 2nd) he left Winnipeg on Thursday morning May 14th (1925) in company with Mr. Orr, the Indian Department's Architect at Ottawa, and Captain Edwards, the Indian Agent in charge of the Kenora Agency, to visit the Lac Seul area for the purpose of selecting a site for the new Indian Residential School to be established there during the coming summer.

As the Department of Indian Affairs had expressed the opinion that the site chosen should be considerably further east than the station of Quibell on the Canadian National Railway, the first site recommended by Bishop O'Meara and supported by the Commission, the delegation took tickets as far as Sioux Lookout. On the way they were joined at Quibell Station by the Rev. M. Sanderson, Missionary to the Indians in the Diocese of Kenora, and who was officially deputed by the Bishop to represent his Diocese on this occasion.

As both the Indian Agent and the Indian Missionary were familiar with practically all parts of the area in question the delegation were greatly assisted by having them among their number.

On the way to Sioux Lookout which was reached at 6 o'clock in the evening, careful notes were made of the country in the vicinity of the town of Freda, and the Hudson Stations, with a view to closer observation on the return journey should necessity demand such action.

During the course of the evening some conversation was held at the Rectory with some of the leading men of the town who had been invited by the Rector for the purpose of furnishing information as to where the most suitable land for farming purposes was to be found in the surrounding country. Several places were suggested and it was decided that the most promising of these should be visited on the following day.

At 8 o'clock on Friday morning a start was made from the town dock in a motor-boat which was very kindly placed at the service of the delegation by the local Board of Trade.

This boat, however, began to leak so badly about a mile from the dock that another and larger one had to be secured. Then this boat arrived after a delay of about three-quarters of an hour. The party which consisted of Mr. Orr, Captain Edwards, Rev. M. Sanderson, Mr. O'Meara, Mr. Meddler (President of the Board of Trade), the Field Secretary, again embarked and made their way in a north-western direction along Pelican Lake to the spot where it narrows down to a channel of about one hundred yards in width and flows out with a good current through what are known as the Pelican Rapids.
On the south bank and just at the entrance to the narrows they found an area of about four acres of gently sloping land all of which had been cleared, and occupied for some years by a retired Canadian who kept a few farm. The buildings which he had erected were still standing, though in a greatly weather-worn condition. The party landed at this point, and after spending about one and one-half hours in examining the cleared and surrounding wooded area, came to the conclusion that it provided, in a remarkable degree, the most suitable site for an institution such as it was contemplated to establish.

As other sites, however, had been recommended to the south, south-west, and south-east of the town, it was agreed that these should first be examined before fixing on any decision. The party accordingly returned to the town, and, after lunch, proceeded to a speedy motor-boat owned and driven by Dr. Mitchell, to examine some of the other sites, which had been recommended. The first part of the course lay in a south-westerly direction across Pelican Lake via the outlet, then along the rapids which connect the water from Abram Lake at the farther end. After ascending the rapids the course lay across the Abram Lake in a northerly direction to a spot not more than a mile distant from the south side of the town.

The party went ashore at this point, and after making their way up an incline to a height of approximately 150 feet through a thick forest of Spruce, Poplar and Jack Pine, with some Birch and small Cedar trees were found growing as well, examined the area along the top. As the party did this examination they came to the conclusion that although the land when cleared would be suitable for farming purposes, and the fuel and water supplies would prevent no difficulty, a school established in that vicinity would stand in too close proximity to the town. They further concluded that as the land along the shore of Abram Lake had been surveyed and marked out into inside plots for summer residences, a school if established there stood in danger of being unable to secure sufficient space for all its activities, in addition to the danger of complications with the White communities which might in time surround it on the greater part of three sides.

As the other sites on the south and south-west sides of the town were found to be so remotely situated as to prevent insuperable transportation difficulties, and as those on the north side presented difficulties and possibly long delays arising out of negotiations which would have to be conducted with the Railway Company and the Dominion Government both of whom claimed ownership, in addition to its general unsuitability, and the price which would have to be paid for it, the delegation decided that the site at the Pelican Rapids which had been visited in the morning was undoubtedly the most suitable for their purpose in that district, and agreed to re-visit it again on the following day.

Through the kindness of the Superintendent of the Sioux Lookout division of the Canadian National Railway a car was placed at the disposal of the delegation on Saturday morning, and by this means of conveyance the Architect, the Indian Agent, and the Field Secretary travelled westward on the railway line as far as Pelican Station a distance of about 6½ miles. Leaving the railway line at a
point about half a mile to the east of the station they followed a trail through the bush which brought them out into the cleared area which they had visited on the previous morning. Their examination of the land, timber, water and other conditions which this area provided confirmed the opinion they had formed on their first visit, and they unanimously agreed to recommend its adoption as the site for the proposed new School.

Among the favourable and completely satisfactory conditions which it possesses for the purpose in question, mention may be made of the following:

1. Accessibility. As it is situated by overland route not more than 16 miles from Pelican Station on the Canadian National Railway, and not more than 7 miles from Sioux Lookout by water route, it is readily accessible to all who are responsible for its operations, its maintenance, and its administration.

Under this heading may be included the facilities for transportation of agents and supplies. This is a very important item and one which involves heavy expenditure at a number of our Society's Schools. The facilities which this site affords will reduce expenditure under this heading to a minimum.

2. Centrality. From the following table, when studied in connexion with a map of the district of the area in question it is clear that this site is centrally located in its relationship to the majority of the Anglican Indians in the Indian communities which it is intended to serve:

| Name of Band          | Total No. | Anglicans |
|-----------------------|-----------|-----------|
| Islington             | 229       | 157       |
| The Dalles            | 65        | 23        |
| Wabushkang            | 40        | 14        |
| Orono Narrows         | 182       | 62        |
| Eagle River/Wabigoon  | 170       | 15        |
| Ignace                | 67        | 3         |
| Les Seul              | 409       | 449       |
| Frenchman's Head      | 138       | 135       |
| **Total**             | **1360**  | **856**   |

3. Farming Land. It is estimated that not less than 100 acres of as good farming land as can be found anywhere in that part of Ontario will be available for farming purposes when the forest has been cleared away.

Part of the area of about four acres already cleared can be made available for gardening purposes with but very little labour.

As the Ontario Government has surveyed this part of the country the minimum amount of land which the School should have set apart for its use is as follows:
The west half (and if possible the east half also) of Portion 26 all of Portion 27 all of Portion 28

These portions comprise approximately half a section or 320 acres.

4. Lighting. Although the Ontario Government held all the land in the vicinity of this site in reserve on account of the possibility of developing water power from the neighbouring rapids, this reservation has now been cancelled. As the construction of a dam about 100 miles away at an inflow to Lac Seul is expected to raise the water level throughout all this part of the distance of about 5 feet sufficient power is not likely to be left in the rapids to justify the installation of a hydro-electric system. For this reason the installation of an ordinary electric lighting system becomes a necessity.

5. Building Area. There is ample accommodation for the main school building on the highest part of the cleared area.

Suitable sites are also available for the stock barns and other buildings, but some forest will have to be cleared before these can be erected.

6. Outlook. As the main building will face the east an unobstructed view of not less than three miles over the north-west arm of Pelican Lake may be had from the front entrance. A view of the upper Pelican Rapids may also be had from the north end and the rear part of this building.

7. Drainage. The drainage facilities leave nothing to be desired.

8. Boundaries. All of the north side and the greater part of the east and west sides are bounded by water. The Canadian National Railway forms the boundary on the south.

In addition to the above considerations the Field Secretary begs to state that as this site is heartily approved by the representatives of the Indian Department, the Architect will give his opinion that his Department would furnish the School, not only with all the necessary articles of equipment including live stock, implements, etc., in addition to the usual School furnishings but would undertake also to provide (1) a motor-boat for communication with Sioux Lookout, (2) telephone communication with Sioux Lookout, (3) to survey and build a road through the forest to Pelican Station, and (4) to clear a considerable part of the land for farming and gardening purposes.

In view of these considerations, when taken side by side with the extremely satisfactory conditions which the area described above provides for an Indian Residential School site, the Field Secretary begs to recommend that the site thus selected and described be recommended for adoption by the Executive Committee as the site for the new School for the Lac Seul area should be located.

I beg to submit my report with reference to the choosing of a suitable site for the proposed new Church of England Indian Residential School to be erected on the main line of the Grand Trunk Pacific in Northern Ontario.

On Saturday, May 9th, I called at the office of the Crown Lands Department in Toronto, and obtained all the information possible with regard to the nature of the country in the vicinity of Sioux-Lookout, and also land available in the township of Drayton, which is the only township surveyed in the vicinity of Sioux-Lookout. This Department furnished me with a blue print of the township, on which they noted in red all of the lots sold or patented. I also examined the surveyor's field notes of this township and noted the nature of the land in the different parts of the township, more especially the portions most suitable for farming operations.

On May 14th in company with Indian Agent, Mr. Edwards, Rev. Doctor Westgate, and Rev. Mr. Sanderson, an Indian Missionary and also an Indian, I left for Sioux-Lookout. On our arrival there we were met at the station by the President of the Board of Trade, Mr. Hodder, and other prominent citizens including Mayor G. Greer and Mr. G. E. Farlinger. The citizens of Sioux-Lookout were extremely anxious to have the school located as near their town as possible, and we discussed with them several sites which they suggested. Most of the sites suggested by them, however, were in my opinion too close to the town. We visited the locations suggested and of all the different localities visited we all agreed that the land situated at the Pelican Falls, lying between the falls and Pelican station on the Grand Trunk Pacific, was the most suitable from every point of view for the establishing of a residential school. The water approach to this site is located approximately six miles by boat on the Pelican Lake from Sioux-Lookout. We visited this location on the afternoon of the 15th and thoroughly examined the property from the lakeside.
MEMORANDUM:

On the morning of the 16th we obtained the use of the Railway Superintendent's gas car and drove to Pelican station, from where there is a good trail leading through the property. This gave an opportunity of examining the conditions from the railway side of the property. The site of the proposed school will be approximately 1½ miles from Pelican Station and a good road can be built at very little cost to the station. The Pelican Falls site is advantageously situated as it is on the main water route where launches can go to Magogual Mills Station east about 30 miles, south within a few miles of the C. F. R., at Dinorwic where is situated the Wabigoon reserve, and east to Webster Station and north to the west end of Lac Seul. All of these places can be reached without a portage.

Sioux-Lookout is an historical Indian site as it is supposed to be one of the last places where the Sioux fought the Ojibways before being actually driven from this part of the country. There is a very high hill near the station on which the Ontario Government have placed an observation tower, and it was at this place where the final battle was fought, all of the Sioux being killed with the exception of a young boy, who was adopted by the Ojibways. His family were the Ackwedance family and previous to the last election, when Paul Thomas was elected Chief, this family retained the Chieftainship for many years.

As all parties interested in the site for this school were agreed that the land above referred to at Pelican Falls is the most suitable from every point of view, I beg to recommend that application be made to the Ontario Government for the following lands: All parts of lots 27 and 28 north of the Canadian National Railway concession, part of lot 26 north of the Canadian...
National Railway, concession B; and the southern part of lots 26 and 27, concession C, the southern part of lot A, Lots 527, concession C, all south of the English river.

This property will contain approximately 350 acres. Of this acreage there is approximately 150 acres covered with light poplar which when cleared will make excellent farming land. There is also a small clearance near the falls of approximately five acres which will provide an excellent site for the building, with good facilities for drainage and water supply.

Attached hereto is a blue print of the township of Drayton, on which I have indicated in orange ink the above mentioned land. I am also attaching photographs taken at the different points on the property selected.

Sir,

As instructed by your telegram of 29th ult and No. 129-6-9 of the same date.

I proceeded to Sioux Lookout and met Dr Westgate. We visited the proposed site of the Sioux Lookout School as instructed.

Dr Westgate is of the opinion that the property which will be granted to us by the Ontario Government will be quite suitable for our needs at the present time providing the Ontario Department of Lands and Forests will let us have Lot #25 in addition to the parts of lots 26, 27 and 28 coloured black on the plan returned herewith.

The site for the building as originally agreed on between Mr Orr, Dr Westgate and myself was on the N.W. part of Lot 26, but as we are unable to get this the point on the N.E. corner of lot 26, will be quite suitable.

Dr Westgate would like to get lot 26 as there is some wood on it that would be suitable for cordwood. Perhaps later on if there is no development at Pelican Falls they would be willing for us to get a portion of the lots 26, 27, and 28 colored red on the plan as well as that portion coloured black they are willing to give us now.

The new location for the school is suitable in every way for the erection of the buildings as shown in pencil on the blue print.

The point is not very rocky, and the land is a clay loam, which would be suitable for growing garden produce and also there would be no trouble in the excavation for the buildings.

The location of the building would be about 15 or 20 feet above present water level.

The water supply could be got from the lake just above the rapids by means of a sump of the water which appears to contain a few animals but a filter could be put in as the water is the same all over these lakes.

As regards sewage disposal, this could go through a septic tank and empty into the lake in the "ay below the buildings where it would run away down stream under the building itself face E.N.E. on the new location.

Rev Claude Secret of Sioux Lookout would be of assistance in keeping an eye on things should the Department decide to have someone on the spot, he would be willing to act for a small salary in his capacity asatherman teacher at Macintosh School, but he would have to have very full instructions as to his duties.

Also a small gasoline launch would be required, this could be used by the Indians for transportation.

A telephone telegraph could be installed at very little cost to join the telephone at the tract there would be no difficulty in having this arranged with the Railway Company.

An unloading platform would have to be made at...
the East end of Pelican siding, as the road along side the
track to the station would not be feasible in the summer without
a large expense, owing to the swampy nature of the land. This
would cost very little and would most probably be put in by the
contractors for their own convenience.

Should any work such as clearing be necessary by
the Department I would suggest that Indians be employed where
possible as there are some very good workmen in the District.

I consider the site mentioned above every way
suitable for our purpose, and would suggest that tenders be
called for at as early a date as possible so that the work
can be far enough advanced to enable the Contractors to roof in
the buildings and so complete the buildings during the winter
months.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to my letter of July 29th relative to the selection of a site for the proposed new Indian Residential School for the Lac Seul area, I beg to inform you that further careful consideration has been given to this important matter as follows:

(1) On Saturday, August 1st, I proceeded to Sioux Lookout and was joined there by your representative on Sunday evening August 2nd.

(2) On Monday morning August 3rd your representative and I, accompanied by the Rev. L. C. Secrett, Rector of Sioux Lookout, and Dr. H. K. Mitchell who kindly conveyed us in his Motorboat, proceeded to the mouth of the Vermillion River. After going a short distance up this river, we returned to the bay into which it empties and landed on lot 26, in order to estimate the altitude of the highest point, and to make a close-up examination of the timber and the soil.

After completing this examination, we returned to the boat and followed a course close in to shore all the way round the headland to the N.E. of lot 26 until we reached the N.E. end of the small peninsula on lot 26.

(3) As this peninsula stands but a short distance from the point on the South side of the entrance to the narrows chosen in May last for the School site, but subsequently found not to be available, we decided to subject the same to a careful examination in order to ascertain if it possessed all the

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6216, file 470-9, part 1)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
requirements necessary for our purpose. Having landed on a large boulder which projected from the apex of the peninsula after which Dr. Mitchell returned to Sioux Lookout, the remainder of our party proceeded to examine the shore line of the peninsula and all the interior with the following results:

(a) The length and width of the peninsula appeared to be accurately set forth on the blue print enclosed herewith.

(b) The whole of the peninsula close down to the shore on all sides was covered with timber, chiefly spruce and poplar of varying sizes.

(c) As our party were without instruments, the exact altitude of the highest point on the peninsula could not be fixed, but from as careful an observation as we were able to make under the circumstances, we concluded this averaged not less than 20 ft above the water level.

(d) For a distance averaging about 100 ft. from the shore line along the N.E. and Eastern sides of the peninsula, land which did not rise more than a few feet above the water level appeared to be well adapted for gardening purposes, while the higher ground reaching practically all the way across the peninsula with a more uniform surface than was expected, appeared to us to provide the requirements necessary for the establishment of the proposed institution.

(e) Although some rocks and boulders appeared at the apex of the peninsula, none of these were found projecting above the surface anywhere throughout the interior of the peninsula itself. From up-turned trees as well as by other means we learned that the soil was chiefly clay. This was covered to a depth of some inches with leaf mould through which male fern and other wild plants were growing in great profusion.

(f) Towards the base of the peninsula on the West side a small area of water-logged soil was encountered, but as this was at a considerable distance from the higher ground on which the school and other buildings would be likely to be erected, it did not appear to present a formidable objection to the peninsula as a whole being utilized for the purpose under contemplation.

I am prepared to submit therefore, for your favourable consideration the following recommendations, all of which, will receive, I believe, the approval of your representative:

(1) That as the site selected in May last for the establishment of the new Indian Residential School for the Lac Seul area is not available, the peninsula projecting from the northern part of lot 26 be secured and utilized for this purpose.
(2) That as the northern parts of lots 27 and 28, and the N.W. corner of lot 26 are not now available for Indian Residential School purposes, the whole of lot 25 and those portions of lots 26, 27 and 28 shaded in black on the enclosed blue print, be secured at the earliest convenience, and a priority claim lodged for those portions of lots 26, 27 and 28 shaded in red, to be added to and included in the School's property as soon as they become available.

(3) That the Rev. L. G. Scottett, Rector of Sioux Lookout, be appointed Inspector of Construction, at a salary of not less than $75.00 a month, and authorized to engage labour, and proceed with the clearing of all that part of the peninsula required for building purposes.

(4) That the Inspector of Construction be likewise authorized to proceed with the clearing of not less than 50 acres the most suitable land for gardening and farming purposes.

(5) That a motor-boat, not less than 25 ft. in length and 6 ft. beam be provided (a) for the use of the Inspector of Construction, and (b) subsequently for the use of the School. (Sioux Lookout is about 7 miles distant by water).

(6) That the main school building be erected about 100 yards back from the shore-line at the N.E. end of the peninsula, with the front looking out across Pelican Lake in that direction.

(7) That the stock-barn and other buildings be erected to the south of the main school building, their exact location to be fixed after the land has been cleared.

(8) That a roadway be surveyed, cut, levelled and graded (where necessary) from the school site to the Pelican Station.

(9) That telephone communication with Sioux Lookout be provided. As this could possibly be done via Pelican Station the cost should not be prohibitive.

(10) That provision be made for fencing the south and west sides of the area to be set apart as School property.

(11) That the School's supply of water be drawn from the N.E. end of the peninsula and the sewage disposed of on the N.W. side, so as to be carried away by the current through the narrows on the N. sides of lots 26 and 27.

(12) That special care be taken in the construction of the reservoir which will receive the school's supply of water from the lake, in order that the larger animals may not be admitted.
The Secretary.

In addition to the above your representative and I were of the opinion that the erection of a small shed or warehouse at near Pelican Station as possible would in all probability be found necessary in order to receive goods direct from the train, but I have not included this in my list of recommendations as it has since occurred to me that the C.M.Railway might be persuaded to provide this for us.

I commend the recommendations which this letter contains to your favourable consideration and remain, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:- Re - Clearing of land at Sioux Lookout School.

In May last, I addressed a communication to your Department relative to various matters in connection with the new Sioux Lookout School, amongst them being that of clearing more land and the removal of the stumps etc., from the fourteen acres already cleared. Up to date I have not received any reply to my letter and consequently am not certain as to what action your Department may contemplate taking in this connection. I may state, however, that the Rev. J.F.J. Marshall, the Principal, during his recent visit to the School learned that you had called for tenders for this work and that one of the tenders was as high as $400.00 an acre. This amount appeared to me to be a somewhat exorbitant one, and greatly in excess of what was paid by your Department for clearing land at Alert Bay where the work was decidedly more difficult. After talking the matter over with the Principal it seemed to him and to me that if your Department were to supply the school management with a Tractor, blocks, cables, etc., the engineer who is now at the School, along with the assistance of the Farm Instructor whose appointment could be made on short notice, could undertake the removal of the stumps, and the preparation for seeding of the fourteen acres on which the trees have already been cut down. The assistance of one extra man who could be engaged by the day might be necessary to help in piling the stumps ready for burning, and in collecting and cutting the logs into cordwood. On making inquiry as to the cost of a tractor f.o.b. Winnipeg the Cocksburn Flow Co., informed me that they have a thoroughly good second hand tractor (Huber) 12-20 h.p. which they will release for $550.00.

If your Department purchased this, and I would recommend this action, and agreed to pay the salaries plus board of the three men referred to above, namely, Engineer $50.00 a month plus board, Farmer $50.00 a month plus board, and Day Labour $50.00.
a month plus board, the cost, apart from the initial cost of the tractor, cables, etc., delivered at the school, and that of the gasoline, would not exceed $250.00 a month.

In this way the whole of the 14 acres apart from that occupied by the buildings, could probably be cleared for a total expenditure of less than $2000.00 including the cost of the tractor, etc., whereas a contract at $400.00 an acre would amount to somewhere around $5600.00.

I commend this matter to your careful consideration and if you agree to this arrangement which I have suggested I shall be obliged if you will authorize Mr. Inspector Bunn to purchase the tractor, cables, blocks, etc., and ship the same to the school.

Believe me, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary, M.S.C.C.

**THE FLORIDA TIMES-UNION, JACKSONVILLE, FLA., SATURDAY, JAN. 8, 1921.**

**ACTOR AS A STUMP PULLER BIG SUCCESS**

Interesting Demonstration Staged Here Past Two Days on Duval County Farms.

The ease and facility with which land can be cleared of stumps roots and brush was demonstrated recently on the farm of John J. Logan, cut Kings Road, and the day preceding on the farm of Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Clifton near South Jacksonville, both in Duval county. The demonstration, which took place in the presence of a number of interested people, farmers and land owners, showed that the stump puller is more than a little satisfaction on noting how readily the heavy steel cables, to a stump of the largest dimensions, removed the root system of the ground, leaving only a hole in the ground to indicate where previously had been giant trees. Thousands of people who witnessed the demonstration saw that no farmer or land owner need be dismayed at the sight of stumps, that it is possible to remove them in a few minutes after the cables have been attached to the stump puller, anchored also to a tractor, and that the operation could be accomplished in a short time.

There were 247 permits issued, 51 of which were for homes. The building total in August was the highest ever recorded.

---

**THE MOUNT DORA TOPICS, MOUNT DORA, FLA., JANUARY 18, 1921.**

**EN AS CAREFULLY**

Machine Pulls A Stump A Minute

Stumps will no longer bring compensation to the minds of those who have tracts of land to clear before they have been filled with trees. The stump puller, attached to a Fordson has been tested on the Ingereoll Development. The puller is attached to a Fordson tractor, and that combination pulled up an average of fifty stumps per minute, which we were on the grounds with the puller attached. One hour later it actually did pull a stump a minute for an hour. A cable was run around a stump and drawn, a signal given to the man at the machine, and in one minute, out comes the stump, often a tree ten feet long, with the greatest ease. The cable is unhitched, and the pulling continues, for in the meantime another stump has been attached. One stump proved a bit stubborn, but what of that — power pulley was used, and our cable is great. We are drawing along the tall old monarchs, being dragged from its winter sleep. The puller has its own anchor stump loop at the end of the fifty minutes, but was soon moved away by the tractor. The work continued. With the cable which was attached to the stump, the same acres could be cleared without moving the puller. And the able little machine, after clearing the stump, will pull the stump, but the same machine will also pull the stump into one place, where it may be disposed of.

One has a great respect for that small piece of machinery when it does such a thing. The saving of time and of human labor is something to be considered in these days of decreased efficiency, and that little power stump puller is doing a most efficient and useful pieces of machinery that could have been invented for the clearing of a formerly wooded country.

IT COSTS 32¢ EACH TO BLAST OUT STUMPS WITH DYNAMITE

On February 19th and 20th, 1923, the Alabama Experiment Station, of Auburn, Ala., made a test in Crenshaw County to determine the cost of blasting stumps. The results were as follows:

Three acres of ground were stumped.

On the three acres there was a total of 67 stumps.

Average height of the stumps was about 24 inches.

The average diameter at the top about 14 inches.

Average cost of dynamite and labor per stump 32¢.

The above figures reveal at a glance the high cost of removing stumps by the blasting method.

Under average conditions stumps can be pulled with a Tom Huston Stump Fuller and a Fordson Tractor at one-third the cost of dynamiting. In other words, the same money that you will spend to blast out one stump with dynamite will pull three stumps with this Power Driven Stump Fuller.

Here's another reason why every farmer should pull his stumps instead of blasting them. A Stump Fuller not only removes the stumps, but also removes big lateral roots running out in every direction just under the surface of the ground. The blasting method often only removes the body of the stump, leaving many hidden snags and roots just deep enough under the surface of the ground to cause plow breakage.

Bales of hay required at the School are still lying near the railway siding as transportation is still impossible. Dear Sir,

In reference to your letter #129/6/9, July 10, 1930, taking up the matter again of the right of way on the north side of the railroad on Lots 25, 27 and 28, Con. B., Township of Drayton, for protection of the livestock at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

I judge that the Department were in the same plight and so was the school in question, so we carried on as best we could with fencing in our small pasture lot with the money allotted by you the same year, namely $115.22. Each year this was a proposition which always faced us and this last quarter I was able to save on vegetables an amount to purchase sufficient wire to fence in our east and west lines.

We have now received from the James H. Ashdown Hardware Co. eleven rolls of wire and we are starting in to erect our fences as soon as the frost goes out of the ground. We would be very glad if you would take this matter up again with the General Superintendent of the Canadian National Railways, Winnipeg as their part of the work depended on us having our side fences erected down to the right of way on the railway property.

I have several times, both in spring and fall, tried my utmost to locate the east line. I have even measured with 100 foot steel tape line, following the plan of the lot #2113, made out Feb. 1, 1921, under 129/6/9, Feb. 21, 1926. But each time have failed to locate any semblance of a line, stake or other survey marks. This spring I was talking to Mr. Dynes, the Dominion Land Surveyor in Sioux Lookout, and he said he would be glad to come out with his instruments and help us to locate the same, so we will make no mistake whatever in putting our fence on our own property.

We also anticipate continuing the fence on the west line from our north west corner down to the little bay, thereby saving considerable amount in fencing, as you will note by looking at the map, our north line would take about the same amount of fence as there is on the railway, and we are anticipating at some future time to be able to purchase the property to the north as stated by the Ontario Dominion Land Department in other letters to you regarding this matter.

Hoping that this meets with your approval and that you will be able to persuade the railway authorities to erect their fence early this summer, I am,

Memorandum

Acting Deputy Minister

The property in lots 26, 27 and 28, Cons. B and C, Township of Brayton, which was purchased for the purpose of the Sioux Lookout Indian residential school, has not been fenced. The South boundary of this property is the right of way of the Canadian National Railway but the railway company objected to fencing their right of way at this point until we had erected our fence on the East and West boundaries. The Principal of the school reported that he had purchased sufficient wire for fencing from savings he had made and was in a position to go ahead with the fencing.

The East and North boundaries of these parcels have never been surveyed and it is likely that the West boundary would require to be re-opened. The necessary survey could be made, if a surveyor at Sioux Lookout is employed, at a cost of from $100.00 to $150.00.

May I be authorized to issue instructions to Mr. R.F. Dynes, O.L.S., Sioux Lookout, Ont? He is the only land surveyor whom I know is located at that point and he has performed surveys in the immediate vicinity of the school property and would have knowledge of the location of the corner monuments in that vicinity. This fact and the fact that he is in the immediate locality would enable him to perform the survey more economically than a surveyor located elsewhere. The property is situated in the electoral district of Fort Arthur-Thunder Bay.

Chief Surveyor.

ATTENTION MR. R. A. HOEY

Dear Mr. Hoey:

When visiting Sioux Lookout recently I found that an opportunity appeared to have occurred at last to construct a road which would link the school with Sioux Lookout and other towns. I am sure that the desirability of this has often been raised in the past, and that the circumstances must be well known to the Department. May I just give my personal impression that the provision of a road would transform the situation of this school. It is a very costly and difficult process to maintain contact with Sioux Lookout by boat, and in the winter the only way our staff or students get to town is by walking 5½ miles on the railroad track. This is a cold and dangerous trip by reason of a number of open bridges. You will recall that two members of the staff have lost their lives on this trip in recent years and several have had narrow escapes. There is also the sense of isolation which creates discontent both among pupils and staff members.

I have realized that cutting a road through the dense bush represented a very costly undertaking, and have regarded it as something outside the bounds to present possibility. However, I now find that the Department of Transport has been compelled to take action by reason of an accident to one of its employees, whose speeder was struck by a train. I beg to enclose a copy of a map which has been prepared by the Civil Aviation Division of that Department and which suggests that something may now be possible in the near future. The provincial highway between Sioux Lookout and Hudson has been in existence for some time, and now a road is being carried through to the Radio Range, which is less than two miles from the school. At the time of my visit I walked to the Range and also along the trail already blazed through the bush. The bulldozer was then at work not very far away and I am advised that the preliminary work has now been done between the highway and the Radio Range. The coming of snow prevented the gang from going on with the work of grading and possibly graveling, but I was able to see the foreman who told me that if they could not finish now they would return as early as possible in the spring.

You will observe on the map that the link to our school has been surveyed and is shown in red. I understand that your agent, Mr. Swartman received a contractor's estimate for carrying this link through to the school, but I am confident that a passable road could be made for
very much less than this. I was advised by the foreman that Government machinery from Kenora was being used and would be available next spring from that point. On this basis the cost is very much reduced from that which occurs when a contractor is carrying out the work for profit. Mr. Cheales and I went through the bush as far as we could and came to the conclusion that only about a mile and a half would require to be bulldozed and cleared. The first link from the school to the railway is in use now and for nearly one-half a mile it could be carried on along the railway track, for the trees have already been cleared away. There is then a short stretch of bush until the Vermilion River is reached. Mr. Cheales believes that it would be possible for the school staff to build a bridge with poles so that this river could be crossed. Wood is being continually cut for fuel and if this road were in prospect the trees could be cleared during the winter as far as the river. Our hope would then be that the Department might be able to make some arrangement with the Department of Transport so that their machinery when on the ground might go through the remaining mile and a half to connect with their road.

I shall be grateful if you will kindly give consideration to this important matter and shall be glad to have the opportunity of discussing it further with you when in Ottawa on the 23rd or 24th. I am confident that the cost in these favourable circumstances would be reasonable, and that the gain in the happiness and efficiency of this school would be very considerable. If some arrangement could be made with the Department of Transport in the near future our school staff would be able to work at our end of the road through the winter. When I speak of staff I am happy to say that at the present time we are in a very favourable position, with four white men working for the school also two strong young Indians and an expert Finnish woodcutter.

Commending this matter to your usual kind attention, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

I wish to acknowledge Mr. Phelan's letter of February 19th File 129-6-9, with respect to the Bridge on the proposed road from the Radio Range to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

A few days ago I had occasion to visit Mr. Kelly of the Department of Highways at Kenora, and discussed the matter quite thoroughly with him. He is of the opinion that there is only one contractor in this area who might make a satisfactory job of the bridge. This is Mr. Peterson of Dryden. Mr. Kelly believes it would pay us in the long run to use crossbeams today and longer spans. He gave a plan of this type of bridge which is being submitted herewith, and stated that it could be varied for different types of bridges although this was their standard plan for bridges in use on secondary roads. You will note it furnishes a clear width of 18' and a loading of 20 tons. Actually the load would not be more than 15 tons, as I inquired as to the feasibility of having a three-pile bridge constructed, but Mr. Kelly was of the opinion that the difference in cost would hardly justify it and that his experience was that usually when small bridges were constructed, it was only a matter of a few years before they were used extensively for larger ones. However, there is the road itself to be considered. Possibly Mr. Hill, the Department of Transport engineer, would be in a better position to advise you as to the type of bridge which would be most practical to fit in with the size, type, and construction of the road.

Under the Provincial Municipal Roads Act, the Department of Highways will construct roads on a fifty-fifty basis, which will assist another farmer etc. It might be well to mention herein that assistance could be obtained on this project, as I am of the opinion that within a few years the road will be used quite generally by the public, as a slight extension of the road would give access to the Lac Seul waters beyond Pelican Falls. I believe this will be a very important factor in years to come.

Dear Sir,

You are aware, I presume, that last fall a line was surveyed for a road in to the Indian School. This line extends from a point on the already nearly completed Range Station Road, in a westerly direction crossing the Vermilion River, then parallel with the railway track to where the trail from the school joins the track. This point is three telegraph poles west of Mile Post Five.

A few days ago in company with Mr. William Ferriss, I followed this line through, and we both feel that, though it is perhaps the shortest way, it has several disadvantages. In the first place, it extends for half a mile or so along a moss-covered rocky slope, then across at least one half mile of swamp, in which a Bulldozer or Grader would not likely work. Again, there is indeed very little wood of any value along the whole line.

Having in mind the fact that we wish to follow the shortest route possible, and, at the same time keep to the best stand of timber, we decided to strike out another line. After tramping about the bush for two days, we finally found what we believe to be the best possible route for the road to the school. Crossing the Vermilion River, we struck out in a south easterly direction and followed a ridge which sloped gradually away to swamp on either side. Keeping to this ridge for approximately three quarters of a mile, we came to the narrowest place in the swamp at our left. Then, making a sharp left turn we crossed this slight depression—(about 300 feet in width), and were indeed pleased to find another similar ridge, running almost parallel with the former. Following this ridge for about one half mile, perhaps a little more, we came out on the Range Station Road at a point about one half mile further away from the Range Station than the point at which the original survey joins it.

Mr. Ferriss, who, aided me considerably in this work, is one of the best Indians I have met in my twelve years experience among them. For several winters now he has cut wood for us at the school. In the summer he works for District Away Engineer, Mr. Hill, Port Arthur, in clearing for Range Stations. He has also worked on road construction.

The new line as described above, and which we submit for your approval, has several advantages. In the first place it follows a ridge (high land, practically all the way) with sand and gravel near at hand to make it an all-weather road. It would require little upkeep. Secondly, there is a good stand of timber which could be reserved for the use of the school. Again, it does not approach as near to the site of the Range Station as does the original survey.

Mr. Campbell of the Engineering Branch called at this office today to discuss the proposed road to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School. Since the school department was also present, it was decided that a recommendation should be forwarded to have the clearing work on the right of way commenced immediately. There are three competent men (Indians) who are employed by the surveyor at present and could be hired for the clearing work. Possibly five or six other experienced Indian bush workers could also be hired locally. The clearing would allow the ground to thaw out. This is necessary before machines could work on the road. The prevailing rates for this type of labour are 45¢ and 50¢ per hour for Indians and non-Indians respectively. The clearing rate is $80.00 per acre, and $125.00 per acre for grubbing. It might be more satisfactory to let this job on a contract basis. There are 14 acres to be cleared, and 5 acres to be grubbed.

Mr. Campbell proposes a 66' right of way with a 20' centre strip grubbed or close-cut, leaving the roots in place. He recommends commercial timber fuel logs, except be cut in 16' lengths, be laid along the right of way. The willow falls, rotten logs, and tops to be piled along the right of way where they could be burned if necessary, or otherwise disposed of.

It is noted that Mr. Hill's estimate of April 37, 1944 lists a 60' right of way with grade 16' wide, while Mr. Campbell's estimate calls for a 66' right of way with grade 20' wide.

There is, of course, the matter of acquiring the property traversed by the road from the Ontario Department of Lands and Forests. I understand the procedure in this respect is to present a plan or sketch of the proposed right of way to this Department in Toronto, showing the length and width of the road, and also stating whether it is public or private. For the present, it is recommended that it should be treated as a private road. This would prevent other interests from securing the fuel wood which might be reached from the road.

Dear Sir,

Re. Proposed Road

A short time ago I wrote you in connection with the proposed road in to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

Mr. Swartman, Indian Agent, has since been in Ottawa, and I understood from him on his return, that a certain amount of money has been set aside for the construction of this road.

Soon after Mr. Swartman's return, Mr. W.A. Campbell, Construction Engineer, arrived here from Ottawa with instructions from his chief to survey a definite line, and to collect other information necessary before work could be commenced.

Mr. Campbell has ruled out the original survey made last fall as impossible. He has spent several days with Transit and Level instruments on the line which Mr. William Ferries and I blazed out previous to his arrival. Mr. Campbell thinks this a very good line with no rock work. Mr. Peterson, Construction Engineer of Fort Arthur and Dryden, walked over the line with us. He too considers it a very good line for this part of the country, along which a road could be made to the school in six weeks to two months time.

There appears to be a few little things delaying the commencement of this most important work. We would be obliged indeed if you would assist us in clearing them up, and send us the word to carry on at once.

First of all, the impression has been given, that the older boys at the school could do much of the clearing for the road. Perhaps I am somewhat at fault here, as I did mention to Dr. Alderwood this might be possible. We could have done some clearing weeks ago, had we any definite line to go by, but it is only this past week that a definite survey has been completed. One very good Indian, William Ferries, with two younger men, have been assisting Mr. Campbell, and they seem anxious to begin the clearing immediately the survey work is complete. Mr. Ferries will call in four or so more Indians to help in the clearing, which, with a crew of six men will require perhaps three weeks. If we do not give Ferries the word to commence clearing Monday the 14th inst., however, he will in all probability go back to his former work at the Airports, and it will be impossible to obtain any man of similar stamina and ability locally to foreman the job of clearing.

In his estimates Mr. Campbell is allowing so much for clearing. William Ferries who will probably be Foreman of the clearing crew will receive a certain amount per hour, the other men somewhat less. In addition we will allow them so much per cord for the wood to be cut.
We have been of the opinion too, that the equipment used in the completing of the road to the T.C.A. Range Station could perhaps be used for the construction of our road. On investigation we note that they stopped work on the Range Station road last fall at a place where the going is rather slow, with over a mile of rock and swampy land ahead of them... We wish to make it clear, however, that the line along which the school road will come, joins the Range Road at a point where it is graded; there appears to be a good sand road from this point to the Highway.

Mr. Campbell has been in telephone conversation with Mr. Hill District Airway Engineer, Port Arthur who is in charge of the Range Road construction. Nothing definite could be learned from Mr. Hill. He did not know when he could obtain machinery to complete the road to the Range Station; consequently he did not know for certain if this road would be completed this year. Furthermore, Hill could not say if the equipment used on the Range Stn. Road would be available for the work on the road to the school.

Mr. Campbell recently contacted Mr. Peterson who has all the equipment required, and is willing to commence work on our road in two or three weeks time; as soon as we get some clearing done.

Much credit is due Mr. Campbell for the way he has endeavoured to make a success of this venture, and may I strongly urge that his recommendations be adopted immediately that all unnecessary delay may be avoided.

Finally, your Department is aware that during the past three years two of the school staff have lost their lives on the Railway Track while walking home from town. Recently a young lady on staff fractured her arm and had to walk the Railway Track six miles to have the arm set. Hardly a month passes but some need arises for a quick trip to town. All of which emphasizes the great need for action on this road construction.

Even now, though the lake has been clear of ice for weeks, we have no engine in our launch, no smaller boat on which we could use an outboard engine, and the second hand outboard engine has been on the shelf for months awaiting repairs.

We are anxiously awaiting word from you authorizing commencement of clearing the right of way, that we may pass the word to the men who are here to do the work.

Thanking you,

Very truly yours,
(The Rev.) [Signature]

June 15th, 1946.

Re: Pelican Lake Indian School Road

In accordance with instructions in the last paragraph of your memorandum of May 1st, Mr. Campbell has recently completed the location of a road line connecting the above Indian school with the radio range road which latter connects with the Provincial Highway running into Sioux Lookout. The line finally adopted by Mr. Campbell was marked in the usual way with stakes on which was also indicated cuts and fills for construction purposes.

Mr. Campbell inspected the line located last season, and referred to in correspondence received from the Indian Affairs Branch. He found that while this line would be shorter than the one finally located, the topography is very rough consisting of low swampy ground broken with sharp rises of rock outcroppings. This was merely a cut line with no stakes to be found. It is estimated that it would have been necessary to move some 5,000 cubic yards of rock on this line, although no allowance was made for solid rock in the estimate. See the attached Indian Affairs File. Lengthy overhauling of material would also probably have been necessary. With these facts available it is estimated that it would have cost possibly $15,000.00 to construct on this line, that is, over $6,000.00 more than now provided.

Mr. Campbell estimates that $12,000.00 will be required for construction operations on the line selected, and while the transfer has not yet come through, it is understood from Mr. Keey's memorandum of the last instant, that $8,675.00 is being transferred. It will thus be noted that in order to complete this project, there will be required an additional $300.00.

It would thus appear that before any further progress can be made in arrangements for actual construction work, there are two major matters for attention:

1. Advice from the Indian Affairs Branch as to whether the required additional funds can be made available for completion of the work, and if not, whether they wish the project undertaken and carried as far as funds available will permit.

2. The obtaining of an understanding with the Province of Ontario with reference to permission for carrying on construction operations over what is understood to be land unallocated Provincial land.

The Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School is located on Lots 26, 27 and 28, Concession "B", and part of broken Lot 26, Concession "C", Drayton Township. As you are aware, the road to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School has now been completed, and like all new roads, it will require considerable maintenance for some time to come. There is also the matter of keeping the road ploughed during the winter months, unless advised from the local office of the Ontario Department of Highways that they are not in a position to attend to the ploughing due to lack of staff and equipment, particularly the latter.

It is recommended that the Department endeavour to obtain a 2 or 3 ton dump truck from the War Assets Corporation, as well as a snow-plough attachment for same. This would pretty well ensure the road being kept open throughout the winter and the truck could be used to haul gravel and fuelwood which are in themselves quite a problem at the School.

The road will be a great asset to the School particularly if it can be properly maintained. One of our difficulties insofar as recruiting pupils for this particular school is concerned, in the past, has been to overcome the argument advanced by the Indian parents that their children, when sick, are unable to reach the hospital without medical attention or hospitalisation. This argument was overcome to a large extent during the past summer as results will show, when it was pointed out that we would soon have a road to the School which would mean very little, if any, delay in providing medical attention.

Early this month there were two young girls sick at the school. At 4 in the afternoon it was decided they had pneumonia, and it was necessary to arrange for a stop on the main line, for the east bound passenger train, the following morning at 6.30. The girls were taken when the fire from the School to the Railway by team when the temperature was hovering around zero and placing them aboard the baggage car of the train. This is hardly fair to the children, and I see no reason, now that the road is completed, why the School should not have a good vehicle such as a station wagon, which could be used particularly in emergency cases of this nature.

Yesterday (Sunday) we had to arrange for a wood truck to proceed to the School in order to bring in another pneumonia case. And this creates a bad impression on the public as well as with the Indian parents, and with this in view together with the importance of safe-guarding the health of the pupils, the foregoing recommendations are made.

Memorandum:

Mr. Mills

Indian Residential School Road, Sioux Lookout, Ontario

Re: Final Financial and Construction Report

Clearing on the above road was commenced May 21st and construction completed November 15th.

Major quantities included 16000 cubic yards of material of which 220 yards were rock. 1800 cubic yards of gravel was excavated spread and compacted. A through truss bridge supported on rock filled cribs was constructed over the Vermilion River. Side and offtake ditches were excavated together with six heavily built culverts.

While the material at the north and south end of the project was sandy, the middle section of clay offered every obstruction. Heavy rains over a period of two months made construction very difficult. The finished grade however, is well consolidated and will give every wearing satisfaction.

Timber used on the bridge construction (with the exception of the decking) was white pine. Eight stringers were used, each length being 60 feet giving a mean river span of 50 feet. These stringers were exceptionally straight and the minimum diameter was 12 inches. These timbers were cut a mile from the bridge site, milled-to-size at water edge and towed to the bridge location. Cribs are rock filled with rock placed above water level on the river side of south crib, the north side crib being above water level. Cost of decking was higher than anticipated being $70.00 per M.F.B.M. During the latter stages of the road construction, material was hauled over the bridge for several days by tractor and six yard scraper, having a total weight loaded, of 31 tons. All logs used for the bridge were hand hewn.

A gravel pit of good stone calibre was located on the south end of the school road, and 1800 cubic yards were placed on the road. Gravel was placed in three lifts of two and three lifts of gravel. Due to heavy snow, a road width of twelve feet was cleared ahead of the graving but this initial spread of gravel can be widened as snow conditions permit.

Regarding the maintenance of this $12,395.00 investment. At the present time there is a half ton truck at the school, the use of which is forbidden on highway work. It is very necessary to take care of this investment. Any new road requires active attention and the school road is certainly no exception. While hauling gravel, some size of stock of gravel of limited yardage can be loaded at reasonable locations. Not only would this stock also be augmented but while the road is in its present state (offering good hauling) additional gravel could be spread. This could be done with the existing equipment at the school, sleighs only using the bigger bays at school for loading. Undoubtedly the acquisition of a three ton dump truck is more than necessary and would fit in well at school hauling together with maintenance work. The work to be done on each mile or any section of gravelled road must not be underestimated. I would like to suggest that Mr. R.A. Kelly, Provincial Highway District Engineer, Kenora, should be approached with the possibility of turning the patrol grader over the highway two or three times during the coming year. Since the Department of Transport will require a grader over their two mile section of Range Road, the divided cost of such grader would be very small.

It will be noted the construction cost of the road over each mile was $654.00; the preliminary estimate. An explanation of this might I point out the following contributing factors:

Due to heavy rains a washout occurred at Root Portage where the equipment rented for the school road was located. The contractor had to rebuild this work. This non arrival of the equipment during the month of July was both detrimental and unavoidable, July being the best construction month of the year. Consequently, therefore, was caused delay in the work other machines were working many days at a minimum of efficiency.

The final section of 2800 feet to be constructed was clay and the general effect of any machinery in clay can be readily visualized.

Again in order to get equipment on to the school road, it was necessary to fill in three swamps which accounted for sixty machine hours at $6.00 - $360.00. Finally, the mile section of the Range road which was made up of mud, waterlogged and not having any gravelled surface, was deeply rutted by heavily loaded timber trucks and was impassable. The only way to make this road passable was to have been defeated unless additional work was done on this section of the Range road. Two days were spent with the bulldozer and additional gravel placed to make the road passable, as a winter road. Tenders will be called by the Department of Transport for completion of the Range road in the early spring.

In conclusion, I would like to mention every assistance was given me by the Principal of the school and the Indian Agent at Sioux Lookout, Mr. Smartman.

Might I urge that the matter of completion of this 1½ miles of road be expedited, that work may be underway soon as ever possible. June and July are the best months by far for such work. If work not begun until Autumn it would be a battle with the elements.

Dear Mr. Swartman,

This past week I had occasion to visit the Sioux Lookout Residential School, and I experienced great difficulty in getting through the road. This road which was built by your department to service the school is in a very poor condition, due to heavy hauling being done over that particular section by a timber operator; if this road were only used for school purposes I am sure it would be in good condition, imperceptible, but heavy hauling has rutted it very badly, and the party using it for this purpose has not made any attempt at repairs.

I bring this to your attention because one of the considerations in your department constructing this road, was that it would furnish a quick means of transportation in emergencies.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa,

Enclosed herewith is a copy of letter recently received from Doctor Bell with respect to the Road to the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School.

We regret very much to have to admit that our position in regard to the road is somewhat ambiguous since, although some money has been spent by this Department, the work was abandoned through lack of labour and equipment, before access to the Radio Range was completed, so, whereas our Radio Branch is concerned, the road serves no purpose.

In March last we addressed a letter to our Headquarters, recommending the construction of an all-weather road from which we quote as follows:

"The School road intersects the Range Road at approximately the mid-point, one and a half miles from Hudson Road.

To provide adequate service to all concerned we are of the opinion that an all-weather road of higher standard than originally contemplated is desirable, and to this end a survey has been made and plans, profiles, cross-sections, specifications and estimates prepared, providing for a 66 feet cleared right-of-way with a 50 feet gravelled roadway at the intersection with the school road and a 16 foot road beyond to the radio range. The estimated cost is $20,000.00.

The cost of construction is almost equally divided between the two one and one half mile sections or, say $10,000.00 for the 20 feet road width portion in which the Indian School people are interested. We would not consider it unreasonable to approach the Department of Indian Affairs with the suggestion that they participate in the costs."

We are enclosing copy of a letter addressed to Dr. P.E. Moore, Department of National Health, by the Controller of Radio, indicating the action taken.

In view of the foregoing, we feel that we have very little authority so far as Mr. Stogryn is concerned, but we are addressing a letter to him that we trust will be helpful.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) E. F. Cooke
District Airway Engineer.
Dear Sir:

Re: INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ROAD
SIOUX LOOKOUT

Dr. G.L.Bell of Sioux Lookout, who is Medical Officer for the Indian School, had occasion recently to visit the School and experienced great difficulty in getting through with his car, particularly over the outlet end of the Range Road. The existing heavy rutting of this portion of the road is due to one Mr. Stegryn, who is hauling heavy loads from wood limits adjoining both the Range and School roads. Last year the Dept.of Indian Affairs spent $500 in hauling fill material and gravel on the Range Road in order to make that particular section passable. Stegryn immediately brought in a portable mill and soon the road was impassable. Engineer Campbell, who was in charge of the construction of the school road, had Stegryn (who recognized his responsibility) bring in trucks for two days and repair the damage.

With immediate possibility of an urgent call from the School of one hundred and fifty pupils, for a Doctor, we would ask if you could put sufficient pressure on Stegryn to keep heavy loads off the road and to keep that portion of the road in such condition that a car can get over the ground at any time. Stegryn is the only man using trucks on the road. He is also in the habit of leaving his truck on the road in such a position that cars cannot pass.

Yours faithfully,

Memorandum:

ACTING DEPUTY MINISTER

The Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario, has a pupilage of 135. This school, while owned by the Department is under the management of the Church of England and for many years they have urged on us the necessity of constructing a road from the school to the town of Sioux Lookout. In 1945 we constructed a road from the school to an existing road which runs from Sioux Lookout to a radio range station operated by the Department of Transport.

For the past year, the radio range road has become almost impassable owing to heavy traffic and as a consequence we have received complaints from the school management to the effect that the Department of Transport should be urged to repair their road. When the Surveys and Engineering Branch approached the officials of the Transport Department the latter expressed the opinion that we should contribute part of the cost of repairing the road due to the fact that traffic from the school travels over a section of the range road before reaching Sioux Lookout.

Recently I received a copy of a letter dated Dec. 10 which the Deputy Minister of Transport had sent to you. In that letter it was suggested that this Department should contribute $5,000.00 towards the cost of repairing the road. The balance of the cost would be paid by the Department of Transport.

There is no doubt that a road is required in order to provide necessary facilities for the Sioux Lookout Residential School. It is also evident from the information received...
that the condition of the road at the present time is extremely bad.

In view of the above, I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the inclusion of an amount of $5,000.00 in the supplementary estimates for the year 1947-48 in order that we might pay our share of the cost of repairing the road.

[Signature]

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of Maggie Fox, Pupil No. 0104, of the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential School at Sioux Lookout, Ont., who died at Sioux Lookout General Hospital (place) on April 17th, 1935.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The Inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law:

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. I29-6-23, re Simon Wesley,
Blacketone House, Via Hudson, Ont.

I have been acting for Mr. Marshall since last September and
I beg to say that I have had the children write their parents
once a month, that is, as far as we are able to get their
addresses.

In cases of sickness they have always been notified from the
School here.

In cases of death, of which I am sorry to say we have had three
this past winter, we have also written letters notifying of
death and condolence to the parents.

Copies of these letters are on file here.

In this particular case we had the boy sick for a while and
also sent him to hospital for a short period but at no time
was it considered very serious. He is now back at the School
and out playing with the other children and in fine trim.
A letter also went out from here notifying the father, copy of
which is on file here.
In a great many cases parents or guardians complain that they do not get their letters, that we are not able to help.

In future I will see to you getting a copy of such letters, sent on to the Department as requested.

I remain,

Yours truly,

Fred A. Mayo,
Acting Principal.

Dear Sir:

As I will be absent from Sioux Lookout for the next month and as my partner Dr. Allen who will be doing the medical work in the interval is not conversant with this case I thought I should write you before leaving.

Amos Jacob aged 11 years died at the Sioux Lookout Indian Residential school on March 1st. The school principal consulted me by phone about February 13th concerning this boy. At that time he did not appear to have any acute symptoms but I had him brought in to my office on February 21 and his chest was x-rayed. He was then returned to the school and put to bed as his chest plates in my opinion showed evidence of disease. This film was thereafter Dr. Marlatt of the Fort William sanatorium who gave a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. The boy was kept in bed and isolated from the rest of the pupils pending a sanatorium vacancy. On the forenoon of March 1st he developed a pulmonary hemorrhage and died.

It is my opinion that the principal and staff did everything possible for this boy and they exercised reasonable care and judgment and they followed my instructions in every detail.

We have your file containing reports on the illness and death of Amos Jacob. It is regretted that a death from tuberculosis should occur in the school, but occasionally in early pulmonary tuberculosis a small lesion may erode a blood vessel and cause a fatal haemorrhage.

I would appreciate further information on the case and am sending a copy of this letter to Dr. Bell for this purpose. Dr. Bell states the child had pulmonary tuberculosis, but does not give information on the stage of disease which I think is important. A copy of Dr. Marlatt's report on the film would likely give this information. It is important to know, as a check for contacts in the school should be done immediately, particularly if the child had disease before the acute symptoms appeared. Was the child examined, by x-ray, on admission last fall? Was this his first term at school or had he been home from school last summer? It is important to find out where he obtained the infection. A check for "spreaders" should be made in the school and if possible, and indicated, on his family at Lansdowne House. We may be able, in this way, to prevent further cases and deaths.

With reference to recommendations by Mr. Swartman on the school report, it is difficult, due to the isolated location of the school, to supply an adequate medical service particularly in winter or under adverse weather conditions. For this reason when considering construction of new schools, the accessibility of the schools for both medical and other purposes is important.

I understand that when Residential Schools are established, one of the requirements is that the school authorities must have a qualified nurse on the staff. Due to the shortage of nurses this is not always possible but at least an endeavour should be made to fulfil this requirement in isolated schools.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Asst. Director, Indian Health Services.

Sir,

In reference to a series of Suggestions concerning our Industrial Schools, I, in compliance with your kind invitation, beg to offer the following remarks:

1st Suggestion. Condition for admission: Commencing 1st Reader and Compound rules of Arithmetic.

In places where children have only the day school class and no other opportunity to practice, they would be placed under great disadvantage. Experience shows that attendance at day school, when children have not a word of English out of the class-room, would hardly qualify them for the matriculation examination. Once admitted in the Boarding School, pupils of ordinary talent could easily attain the standard.

Besides, some might not even attain the standard and nevertheless have great aptitude for the trades.

2nd Suggestion. 3 years for girls, 4 years for boys.

So much depends on the age and natural talent of the pupils that I would rather leave the question of time to the Directors of the Institutions.
Additional suggestions: To admit in the house school as Boarders only such as might have no opportunity of attending day school.

Well, but no restriction in admitting such as would avail themselves of the far greater advantages in the Boarding school. (Refer to the remark on the 1st suggestion.)

Further suggestions: Appoint an Inspector, enforce attention. Our Indians live principally by farming, fishing, trading. Besides for the market they take their families with them. Any regulation that might interfere with these various engagements would affect materially the resources the Indians have to provide for the necessities of life.
