I have carefully examined the blue print plans submitted for boys' and girls' buildings by the Rev. Jos. Seguin, the girls' building being a very substantial one, semi fire-proof 150 x 50 (average) four stories in height including basement which is mostly above ground steel frame concrete constructed with terracotta lining.

The basement contains a gymnasium 37 x 59 x 12 feet high. Girls' dining-room 37 x 42 x 12 feet high training kitchen, bakery and provision room, the balance of the basement being taken up with heating, fuel and laundry room.

There is also a room for W. Closets, but no lavatory indicated, probably it is their intention to install lavatory basins there and in gymnasium. These are not, however, indicated.

The ground floor contains the Staff dining-room, kitchen, parlor, nine rooms, private lavatory (containing one sink 3 water-closets and 1 bath) and two large class-rooms, each 24 x 36 x 13 feet high which equals floor and air space for 45 or combined for 90 pupils.

On the first floor there is Chapel, infirmary 24 x 26 with bath and attendant's room adjoining, two sewing-rooms 24 x 24 x 12, girls' cloak-room 12 x 26, lavatory 9 x 19, library 10 x 26 and 10 bed-rooms.

Flat dormitory is 12 feet high and dormitory is 60 x 38 and 60 X 45 and contains 61920 cu. ft. and air and floor space. 123 pupils, lavatory 12 x 12 containing W.closet, bath and sink, shower bath-room 9 x 19, two W.C. in dormitory, girls' wardrobe 24 x 24, teachers' wardrobe 9 x 19 and four bed-rooms. No lavatory basins are indicated and it is presumed that they will be placed in the dormitory without enclosure.
There are two separate staircases from dormitory to ground floor as well as fire escapes.

There is no ventilation system indicated or provided for. It is said that the building will be heated by hot water.

General.

The class-rooms provide accommodation for 90 pupils and the dormitory for 123-1/5, and all other accommodations is based on the class-room and dormitory dimensions, excepting lavatories and these will probably be placed open in dormitory and gymnasium.

As the training is industrial as well as scholastic and a portion of the children engaged in the industrial work while others are in class-room, the accommodation in dormitory will probably define the number the school will accommodate, viz., 123 pupils.

Boys' building is a three story frame on concrete foundation with a set off providing for brick veneering at a later date. The foundation is used for heating apparatus, bake-shop, meat-room, storage and vegetables, and is mostly below ground and apparently with very little lighting.

The ground floor contains gymnasium, boys' dining-room, kitchen and pantry, etc., two private lavatories, parlor, two rooms for Principal, private dining-room and infirmary 17 x 23, with bath W.C. and basin, and attendant's room adjoining.

In the gymnasium there are 9 W.C., but no lavatory basins indicated. On the first floor there is the staff-domestic chapel, library and staff-room dining-room, large common or recreation room, and two class-rooms, each accommodating 50 pupils and a private bathroom containing two W. closets, one bath, two sanitary basins.

The second or dormitory floor containing the boy's dormitory
dormitory with accommodation for 100 pupils, two large store room wardrobes, 12 bed-rooms, library and private lavatory, containing one bath, two W. closets and two lavatory basins. There is also two W. closets, one tub-bath and shower baths in the dormitory with a thin partition separating them from the room and 100 feet of trough type lavatory shown.

There are two separate staircases and two fire escapes allowing exit in case of fire. No system of ventilation has yet been determined.

General.

The dormitory and class rooms provide for 100 pupils and the other accommodation throughout the building is equal and in some instances greatly in excess of actual school requirements.

The only deficiency with regard to room is the infirmary which is not of sufficient size, unless it is intended to provide outside of the two buildings a separate isolation hospital. There are, however, a great many bed-rooms and it may be their intention to utilize some of them for sick rooms.

Memorandum

Mr Pedley,

The Rev. Father Paquin, Agent of the Wikwemikong Industrial school wrote the Department asking authority to remove certain lumber and machinery in the work shop, saw mill and one of the barns which they wish to utilize in the new school they are going to put up at Spanish River to replace the present school at Wikwemikong. These buildings were put up by and used in connection with the school and the framework will still be made use of by the school.

The Roman Catholic Missionaries have always had charge of the spiritual and educational needs of the Wikwemikong Indians and have devoted time and money to christianize and educate them. The Wikwemikong Industrial school is the result of their practically unaided efforts. Their reasons for now wishing to remove the Institution to the mainland were submitted to the Department, and received its approval. They intend constructing an up-to-date residential school building without asking grant from the Department, and it seems only fair that they should be allowed to
utilize the material in the buildings mentioned.

The Indians have contributed nothing to the building or up-keep of the present school, and the Roman Catholics will still maintain their mission at Wikwemikong and will be within their rights in doing so, as some 200 acres was set apart years ago for school and mission purposes.

The Wikwemikong Indians will still share the benefits of the new school and I consider that the Department would be justified in authorizing the removal of the material and machinery above referred to.
